M: This beer is on the lighter side of things but it isn't watery. Carbonation is adequate for the style and just slightly prickly. The light acidity gives the beer a semidry finish
O: Overall this beer is pretty good. The rose hips give the beer an interesting dimension. It could stand to be a little more tart but that's just a minor complaint.\xa0765 charactersSHODriver, Sep 23, 2017", '3.9/5\xa0\xa0rDev +8.3%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 3.5330 ml bottle into tulip glass, 14281602 code on the cap. Pours very hazy golden/orange color with a 2 finger fairly dense and fluffy off white head with good retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers. Nice dense soapy lacing clings around the glass, with a moderate amount of streaming carbonation retaining the cap. Aromas of tart lemon, lime, peach, pear, green apple, berry, guava, citrus peel, pepper, sea salt, wheat, bread dough, floral, hay, straw, grass, light lacto funk, and yeast earthiness. Very nice aromas with good balance and complexity of fruity/acidic yeast, rose hips/salt, and moderate bready malt notes; with good strength. Taste of tart lemon, lime, peach, pear, green apple, berry, guava, citrus peel, pepper, sea salt, wheat, bread dough, floral, hay, straw, grass, light lacto funk, and yeast earthiness. Light-moderate fruity/acidic tartness and yeast spiciness on the finish; with lingering notes of lemon, lime, peach, pear, green apple, berry, guava, citrus peel, pepper, sea salt, wheat, bread dough, and floral/yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Very nice complexity, robustness, and balance of fruity/acidic yeast, rose hips/salt, and moderate bready malt flavors; with a great malt/tart/spiciness balance, and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Light-moderate dryness from acidity as well. Medium carbonation and body; with a very smooth, moderately creamy/acidic, and lightly saline/sticky balanced mouthfeel that is nice. Zero warming alcohol as expected of 4.3%. Overall this is a very nice gose. All around nice complexity, robustness, and balance of fruity/acidic yeast, rose hips/salt, and moderate bready malt flavors; very smooth and refreshing to drink with the balanced acidity. A very enjoyable offering.\xa01,774 characterssuperspak, Aug 20, 2016', "3.9/5\xa0\xa0rDev +8.3%look: 4.5 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 4 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.75Thick cloudy yellow, like a yellow juice of some sort. So thick it turns dark near the bottom. Topped with a finger of fluffy white head.

Peaches, really fruity, a hint of lemon juice. A slight musty cellar quality. Almost a hint of fresh urine, and a hint of salt almost like the sea.

Salty, bitter, lemon juice, fruitiness is to the background. Hint of unripe peaches. The ureic acid is there, and little salty briny quality, as well as a hint of sweetness. Berry like quality as in tart berries as well.

Medium to almost thick juice like quality, sour dry puckering finish. A sort of tannic dryness to the finish as well.

Got this gem on wishbeer, drank in Chiang Mai Sept 21st, 2015. Less sour and salty than Westbrook's version, and more fruity in comparison. Still very interesting and worth trying.\xa0818 characterspatre_tim, Sep 22, 2015", '3.79/5\xa0\xa0rDev +5.3%look: 3 | smell: 4 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 5 | overall: 3.75Pours hazy as fruit juice, straw head.
Nose shows wheat, lemon rind, floral notes. Rather subtle.
Slightly acidic flavours, some herbal, floral and perfumous notes.\xa0164 charactersCrazyDavros, Mar 04, 2015']

name: Singlecut/Transmitter QBW Gose
review:
['3.88/5\xa0\xa0rDev -5.8%look: 4.5 | smell: 4 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 4 | overall: 3.75Hazy yellow with a ruddy head
The nose is citrusy. Taste is lemon plum and coriander. Could use more tart flavors and saltiness. 
Overall very drinkable but nothing special.\xa0176 charactersSammyJaxxxx, Jul 03, 2016', '4.01/5\xa0\xa0rDev -2.7%look: 3.5 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 4A: Hazy, pale, lemon with sizable but loose, soapy head. 

S: Bright and sharp coriander spice. Lemon. Fruit featuring some quince qualities...guava, starfruit, a little woody spice. 

M: Medium body with some tingle. Feels a tad low on carb.

T: Tart, lemony, melon with initial salty twitch playing for another sip. Slightly sweet and doughy malt profile.\xa0360 charactersorcrist_cleaver, Jun 19, 2016', '4.13/5\xa0\xa0rDev +0.2%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4Very light and modestly hazy yellow pour. Nose of lemon and salty seawater. Pop of salinity at the front end of the palette segueing into lemon/lime zest. Tart, but not full-on sour at all. Well-executed gose.\xa0209 charactersTomMorris, May 28, 2016']

name: Double Seesaw: Level Playing Field
review:
["4.29/5\xa0\xa0rDev +0.5%look: 4.5 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.5 | overall: 4.25This one pours a bright and vivid dark pinkish red color, with a small head, and lots of lacing.

Dragonfruit and passionfruit is almost always a dynamite combo, and it works well here in the aroma, with both coming through strongly. There's less prickly pear, and a light acidity on the nose.

The base gose is basically buried underneath all of the fruit additions. Luckily, the fruit itself is done well, with a significant juiciness and a pretty light tartness. It's crisp and finishes very cleanly, with no lingering acidity or other flavors.

This is light bodied and very drinkable - I could easily have a lot of these. It's very crisp.

This is basically juice, but it's very tasty juice, at least.\xa0706 charactersGreesyFizeek, Aug 01, 2019", '4.51/5\xa0\xa0rDev +5.6%look: 4.25 | smell: 5 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.5 | overall: 4.5Drank from a 1 pint can purchased at Trillium Brewing Company, Boston, MA
Canned on 03/06/19
Served in a tulip

The beer poured a gorgeous fuchsia color and was topped by a small, bubbly, bright white film that quickly dropped to a thin, lasting collar. Streaks and dots of lacing stuck along the glass.

The aroma was amazing. There was an intense, exotic tropical fruit presence. Passion fruit dominated. Dragon fruit and prickly pear were also noticeable but came in a distant second and third. Really punchy and bold with a terrific balance of fruity sweetness and crisp tartness.

The flavor profile was impressive but not quite as mind blowing as the nose. Nice tropical fruitiness up front. The dragon fruit and prickly pear might have both surpassed the passion fruit in intensity here. Tart passion fruit notes were definitely apparent though. Lemon notes kicked in mid palate and crescendoed as the beer moved along the palate. Nice crisp, wheaty tartness too. Touch of salinity on the finish. Some dry, earthy hop bitterness appeared after the swallow.

Very solid mouthfeel. Medium bodied for the style. The liquid contained a fine, zippy effervescence that turned creamy and smooth on the palate.

Of all the fruit-infused beers I have tried lately, none had a more astounding aroma than Double Seesaw: Level Playing Field. Also, being a huge fan of passion fruit, this beer particularly blew me away. All in all, an awesome job by the Women of Trillium. I hope to try more of their offerings soon.\xa01,511 charactersDamian, May 03, 2019', '4.87/5\xa0\xa0rDev +14.1%look: 5 | smell: 4.75 | taste: 5 | feel: 4.75 | overall: 4.7516 oz. can

Pours a striking cloudy opaque dark hot pink color with a frothy light pink foam head. Smells ridiculously tropical and fruity, big fresh passionfruit, dragonfruit, prickly pear, some wheaty malts, a touch of salinity, with inviting floral earthy herbal mild spice aromas. Tastes like huge fresh prickly pear, passionfruit and dragonfruit, citrusy tropical notes, berries, red melon, wheat, salt, with floral earthy herbal spice notes. Feels medium-full bodied, creamy with moderate smooth carbonation. Overall a really great fruited gose with passionfruit, prickly pear and dragon fruit.\xa0600 charactersStoutElk_92, Mar 10, 2019']

name: Never Letgo
review:
["4.21/5\xa0\xa0rDev +4.5%look: 4 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4 | overall: 4.25Pours an unlear reddish orange, with very little head.

Smell is tart and a bit earthy, with notes of pomegranate, lime and gooseberries.

Taste is just the right amount of tart, with nice notes of pomegranate, lime and gooseberries and a hint of salt in the finish.

Mouthfeel is thin, with prickly carbonation.

Overall, another nice Gose, which is a style The Veil doesn't get enough credit for. They make em good...\xa0419 charactersJamFuel, May 01, 2018", '3.99/5\xa0\xa0rDev -1%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4Look is berry juice with a small amount of off-white head. Fades quickly.
Smell of faint and it is hard to pick stuff out. I am getting subtle hints of lemon and berry.
Taste is tart and salty with a berry and lemon flavor.
Feel is refreshing and salty, with a light feel. 
Overall I was not getting any pomegranate flavor, but it was definitely a nice gose that would be good on a hot day.\xa0390 charactersBum4ever, Mar 26, 2018', "3.9/5\xa0\xa0rDev -3.2%look: 4.75 | smell: 4 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 4 | overall: 3.75Received as an extra in a trade.

A - Poured into my Duvel tulip a nice murky berry juice tinged gold, almost like grapefruit juice, with a thick two finger head that fades extremely slowly to leave a thin blanket.

S - Aromas of nice creamy wheat, very very faint lemon, nice bready/doughy yeast. Flashes of berry notes, light tartness, like seedy pomegranate. 

T - Taste is similar to the nose. Big doughy yeast notes up front, little bit of wheat, faint lemon tartness, nice salt aspect. The fruit aspect is quite subtle or at the very least overpowered by the base gose. Little lingering red berry tartness on the finish.

M - Mouthfeel is lightly carbonated, finish is a bit flemmy.

O - Overall this was a rather disappointing beer. Was excited for the addition of pomegranate juice but it really didn't translate well. Quite unfortunate.

Serving Type: Can\xa0864 charactersrudzud, Mar 22, 2018", "3.59/5\xa0\xa0rDev -10.9%look: 3.5 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.5On draft. Served in a goblet glass. Pours a slightly hazy, lighter yellow body with a slight pinkish hue to it, one finger white head, fair retention with no lacing. Smell is a fair bit of wheat germ, light lemon, bit of lactic acid, touch of pomegranate juice, although I'd probably have identified it as more of a tart raspberry had I not known what the fruit addition was. Touch of umami. Flavour is fairly straight-forward gose, tart wheat, bit of lemon, touch of salt, however the pomegranate isn't particularly strong here. It mostly shows up towards the end in a subdued fashion. Mouthfeel is lighter bodied, appropriately carbonated, slightly dry and mildly tart with a touch of pomegranate and lemon on the finish. I was hoping for a bigger pomegranate presence, though this gose is quite well constructed and flavourful on its own.\xa0841 charactersStevedore, Mar 19, 2018", '3.93/5\xa0\xa0rDev -2.5%look: 2.75 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4Whoa. This beer looks like pink grapefruit juice with pulp, with a fuzzy light pink ring of carbonation around the edge.

Smell is salty cracker, seaweed, Colby and a hint grapefruit candy.

On the tongue, Never Letgo is nicely tart and refreshing, clean and expressive, with flavors of pomegranate, toasted seeds, sea salt, and again a hint of peanut. Where is that coming from in these Veil beers?

The body is moderate with a light and bouncy froth, finishing semi-dry and velvety.\xa0484 charactersSabtos, Mar 14, 2018']

name: Never Never Calm Calm
review:
["4.31/5\xa0\xa0rDev -1.4%look: 4.25 | smell: 4.5 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.2516 oz. can from brewery, poured into Aslin anniversary glass

L: Nice big 2F fluffy white head with very good retention, laces of white uh...lacing, and a ring. Beer is an orange crush color with hints of bronze.

S: Big passionfruit smell backed with pineapple. If you don't know what passionfruit exactly smells like, this is a good way to find out. Also some citrus notes, a bit of yeastiness, and a whiff of salinity.

T: Largely follows nose. Lots of lovely passionfruit and pineapple, slightly sour. A bit yeasty and saline on the back end.

F: Lightish bodied, well-carbonated. Brisk and refreshing. Well-crafted and balanced.

O: Another superior fruited gose from The Veil.\xa0682 charactersIvoryFoxhole, Aug 28, 2019", "4.35/5\xa0\xa0rDev -0.5%look: 4 | smell: 4.5 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.5Like a tropical vacation in a glass. Pours a dark, murky shade of orange, with minimal head that disappears quickly. Smell is pure pineapple and passion fruit (surprise!), I doubt I'd guess with was a beer if I was blindfolded. Taste is similarly juicy, with a little bit of salty bitterness at the end. Body is light, smooth, and refreshing. Far from traditional, but by this point, I think everyone knows what they're getting into with Veil's fruited goses. This one is as untraditional and delicious as the rest.\xa0515 charactersalextastic, Jun 07, 2019", "4.29/5\xa0\xa0rDev -1.8%look: 4.5 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.5 | overall: 4.25This one pours a very hazy golden orange juice color, with a small head, and not much lacing. It looks thick.

This smells like, well, pineapple and passionfruit, and nothing else - just tart, drippy, fruity goodness.

This is absolutely delicious, but like most everything in this series - it pushes the limits of what beer actually is. It tastes thick and pulpy, like actual juice. There's probably more pineapple here, but the passionfruit isn't far behind. It's lightly sour, but not super sweet - it's more just authentic fruit puree, hitting you like a tsunami.

This is very drinkable - it basically goes down like pure juice. It's mildly creamy, and pretty clean.

Like the rest of this series, this is not really beer, but it's really delicious.\xa0754 charactersGreesyFizeek, May 22, 2019"]

name: Dos Ghosts
review: ['3.77/5\xa0\xa0rDev -5.5%look: 3 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 3.75Pours a cloudy pale gold, lots of carbonation, but just a small, bubbly head. Smells great, citrus and some leathery funk.\n\nThis is an excellent beer. Crisp, refreshing, sour, a little funky, salty...a great take on a gose. At 4%, I will drink a lot of this this summer.\xa0270 charactersJmatz, Jun 09, 2017', '4.03/5\xa0\xa0rDev +1%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4A traditional gose on all accounts, very refreshing, very tasty. Starts with a light yellow pour, head goes away very quickly. Hits the palette with a light feel and a lot of carbonation, almost like a pilsner. Giving way to tartness, leading into a hint of brine and fruit. Taste lingers and develops in the mouth a very long time. Very low ABV, great session beer. Well done again Pipeworks, you nailed it on the head as usual. Will I buy again? Definitely!!!!\xa0469 charactersLukas, Mar 24, 2017']

name: Green Star
review:
["4.21/5\xa0\xa0rDev +2.4%look: 3.75 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.75 | overall: 4.25Excited for a new Finback sour. Only really had tastes at the brewery awhile ago and I feel like everyone is getting onto them lately.

Cloudy looking for what is supposed to be a gose. A dark pale gold color is the best I can sum it up with.

The nose is quite fruity for a lime driven beer, and also a fair scent of sour funk. This smells a lot more sour than a run of the mill gose to me.

A lot of lime flavor, and maybe some sour green apple tinges as well. It's fairly straightforward and fairly well done. 

The first thing I feel is a super clean, super refined sourness. Finback does an excellent job with making sour beers as crisp as possible so the flavors shine through. The citric character of the limes is refreshing and has just enough sourness.

Another awesome one from Finback. I feel like Gose is a style that is finally being super well done in spite of it being mega trendy as well lately. This is an absolutely high tier one.\xa0948 charactersJsalz21, Oct 03, 2017"]

name: Honey Oat Gose
review:
["4.4/5\xa0\xa0rDev +22.6%look: 4.5 | smell: 4.5 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.5 | overall: 4.5Honestly not getting all the hate behind this one (unless there was an inconsistency in the quality of bottles put out). Very crisp and pleasant mouthfeel, light and slightly tart. Well balanced salt and slight honey undertones. One of the better gose that I've had, and super refreshing to match!\xa0297 charactersdiamondlie, May 20, 2016", '2.56/5\xa0\xa0rDev -28.7%look: 3.5 | smell: 3 | taste: 2 | feel: 3.25 | overall: 2.5Picked up at the farmers market. Shared with JLindros.

A - Poured into a Kate the Great tulip a nice crystal clear honey hue with a thin head that fades quickly to leave a creamy halo . 

S - Aromas of light lemons, nice honey. Rather yeasty, quite mineral heavy. Oats are faint, decent salt level.

T - Taste is similar to the nose, light lemons. Rather phenolic, light honey, faint tartness. Not overly acidic, really yeasty, the oats bring a heavy bready quality. 

M - Mouthfeel is brightly carbonated, overly so. 

O - Overall this was a really underwhelming gose. Flemmy, yeasty, overly carbonated...just sub par.

Serving Type: bottle\xa0642 charactersrudzud, May 19, 2016', '2.56/5\xa0\xa0rDev -28.7%look: 3.5 | smell: 3 | taste: 2 | feel: 3.25 | overall: 2.5Thanks to rudzud

Light fizzy head disappears instantly, slight hazy honey golden color.

Nose big yeasty, raw bread dough, raw bakers yeast, sour lemony funk, little acidic lacto like funk, some minerals, little vanilla cake which is maybe oats, little sweet honey.

Taste weird mineral think, effervescent carbonation flavor like a bitter hydrogen peroxide flavor, plenty more minerals and chalk, little yeasty raw bread dough, tart lemony sour funk but phenolic nasty funk, a bit of lemon peel dragged through the baseball diamond chalk and thrown into flaming garbage. A little bread dough from oats, perhaps honey picked from the ground.

Mouth is med lighter bod flemmy sticky creamy tart mild acidic tons of carb.

Overall horrible.\xa0739 charactersjlindros, May 19, 2016', '2.42/5\xa0\xa0rDev -32.6%look: 4 | smell: 2 | taste: 2 | feel: 4 | overall: 2.5500 mL bottle. Hazy yellow body. Smell is odd. Kinda like a pickle aroma. Honey. A bit acidic. Taste is equally unimpressive. Still has a pickle flavor. Light tartness. Lots of wheat and mineral saltiness. Light body. Blah.\xa0234 charactersAlieniloquium, Mar 08, 2016', "4.42/5\xa0\xa0rDev +23.1%look: 4.5 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.5On tap poured into a 12 oz. tulip. This one isn't as sour as Kent Falls' other Goses and the honey is very subtle but it's an outstanding beer. Definitely worth a try if you're a fan of the style.\xa0196 charactersSenatorSpaceman, Feb 16, 2016"]

name: Portsmouth Dunkel Gose
review:
['4/5\xa0\xa0rDev +1.5%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4Pours cloudy, orange brown, with minimal head. Taste is pumpernickel bread, lemon, dark wheat, and a decent amount of salt. The salt is never overbearing. This makes for an interesting fusion of styles that I would like to try again. I could see myself sipping several of these in the fall.\xa0294 characterstigg924, Sep 23, 2015', "2.93/5\xa0\xa0rDev -25.6%look: 3.25 | smell: 2.75 | taste: 3 | feel: 3.25 | overall: 2.75I picked up a bottle of this in the Portsmouth shop, as it seemed the most interesting thing they had available. I shared it at a recent tasting.

Poured a hazy medium brown color with a thin cap of white head that fizzled out pretty much completely rather quickly. Aroma of toasted cereal grains and sweet sugary malts; not much else. Taste was pretty bland, caramel malt sweetness, stale toasted grains, and maybe a hint of citrus. Not much else to say. Light-medium body, and not very good overall. Everyone at the tasting had a sip, and half the bottle remained untouched. 

Honestly I'm not really sure what the brewers were thinking with this beer. I mean, I can understand the lager part, I didn't really get anything otherwise comparable to a dunkel, and as for the gose part, maybe they threw in a dash of table salt and put the gose tag on it? Seemed like a patched-together mess, and I wouldn't get it again.\xa0919 charactersRifugium, Apr 21, 2013", "4.04/5\xa0\xa0rDev +2.5%look: 3.75 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4.5 | overall: 4Bottle with a best by date of May 2013 under the title Dunkel Gose Lager.

Pours an amber color with about a finger and a half of head, very bubbly, fades at a fast rate, not much lacing on the glass.

Smell has a strong aroma of banana and some other light fruity scents, touch of clove.

Taste starts out with a wheat-y like flavor, light fruit, banana creeps in, salinity is a bit low for a Gose but that's fine, body is very light and crisp, carbonation is very active without being annoying, a very refreshing beer and easy to drink.\xa0538 charactersdeltatauhobbit, Mar 14, 2013", "4/5\xa0\xa0rDev +1.5%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4Tap at the brew pub.

Light fizzy head, hazy golden yellow color.

Light citrus, light toasty malts and wheat, light saison like malts and touch of spices, some light musty dry rustic malt aroma.

Taste light citrus, light malts and wheat, touch spices and saison, nice hops like hallertau with light floral and touch grassy. Light fruit juice and citrus. Finishes dry with touch bready malts, citrusy lemon, light malts.

Mouth is lighter bodied, decent carb.

Overall nice, light but nice flavor, nice light hops that shouldn't fit but somehow does, balanced with a nice light malty wheat profile, very sessionable.\xa0617 charactersjlindros, Oct 16, 2011", "4.42/5\xa0\xa0rDev +12.2%look: 4 | smell: 4.5 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4 | overall: 4.522oz bottle poured into a Duvel tulip.

A - Pours a hazed medium pale amber color with an overdeveloped rocky 4 fingers of foam that fills the glass past the rim. Head has excellent staying power lingering for several minutes and delaying my ability to get a full pour in the glass. Large spots of lacing get deposited on the glass as it finally finds its way to the surface.

S - Musty smelling like an old cellar. Lactic sourness surrounded by gym socks and horse manure. Very funky...this has some potential. Some mild orangey fruitiness, pronounced graininess and perhaps a bit of spice too.

T - Interesting...almost like a funkified Belgian witbier. Light and refreshing flavors - citrusy oranges and lemons, lingering spices, some cloves, soft bready malt, lactically tart with some earthy and barnyardy funk overtones. I have to say I'm a bit impressed.

M - Thinnish and light bodied with a sharp, very high carbonation. Prickly and tingly, perhaps bordering on painful carbonation levels...a bit foamy and a light cooling sensation fills the mouth - probably as a result of the spices here.

O - I don't have much experience with this style so don't have a lot to compare this against - but I have to say I really like this beer. Way funkier and lots more character than I expected. Sadly, this is gone from the brewpub...hopefully it makes another appearance in the future. Until then, I think I'll be seeking out more of this style for comparison, given the enjoyment I got out of this one.\xa01,502 charactersportia99, Apr 23, 2011", '4/5\xa0\xa0rDev +1.5%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4I got this as a Christmas gift from a friend. I poured from a 22 ounce bottle into a snifter. The aroma has sour lemons and cloves. It has a little spiciness and sweetness up front with a very pleasant tart finish that lingers. The body is light and it is well carbonated. My first gose and I liked it, would definitely try another.\xa0332 charactersbonkers, Dec 29, 2010', '3.93/5\xa0\xa0rDev -0.3%look: 4.5 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 3 | overall: 4Thanks to EnronCFO for the bottle!!

Appears about the color of iced tea though hazy. Nice tan head falls slowly to a thick blanket.

Smells of wheat, spiciness, some malt and citrus.

Taste is Wheat, some banana a touch of salt and some spice on the dry aftertaste.

Body is medium and carbonation is very active..a bit too active for me.

Overall an interesting brew the carbonation is a touch rough but otherwise a tasty beer.\xa0429 charactersThirstyBird, Dec 23, 2010', "3.97/5\xa0\xa0rDev +0.8%look: 3.5 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4I had to buy this simply from the point that I figured something had to have gone wrong with one of the brews used for this blend. Like really, who sets out to blend a dunkelweizen and a gose, hell who even brews a gose nowadays lol. Anyways the flavors from this brew melided nicely, typical bavarian weizen yeast phenolics, bit of salt from the gose, wheat notes, nice brew. I do get a peppery note from this brew, did the Gose have a strong over the top peppery note requiring the blend? I did eat a couple taco's while enjoying this brew, maybe thats giving me the peppery note, but nice pairing none the less. This blend all came together rather nicely, nice brew!\xa0669 charactersbcastine, Dec 11, 2010", '4/5\xa0\xa0rDev +1.5%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4Pours the color and clarity of cider with a quarter inch, loose, off-white head that eventually dissipates into a skim. Nose is somewhat herbal and expresses cloves and a light fruit quality. Taste follows nose; however, a salty character is definitely imparted in the flavor profile. Mouthfeel is light-medium, with an even, mild carbonation. All and all, a very easy drinking an interesting beer. Having never had a gose before, I have nothing to compare it to; however, it was thoroughly enjoyable.\xa0501 charactersJwale73, Dec 04, 2010', "4.5/5\xa0\xa0rDev +14.2%look: 4.5 | smell: 4.5 | taste: 5 | feel: 4.5 | overall: 3.522 oz. bomber purchased Friday afternoon at the brewery and shared at dinner that evening. I went back the following morning hoping to pick up another bottle, but they were wiped out. I'll be back next weekend and hope it's still available on tap.

A: Pours a very cloudy orange-tinged tan with a nice, foamy head; a sticky lacing persists. Very pleasing to behold.

S: Very strong, crisp and slightly sweet smell, mostly of grains with a bit of spice, yeast and citrus. This is one I kept sniffing throughout dinner; extremely pleasant.

T: The taste seemed to evolve throughout a sip without being aggressive, maintaining a highly unusual level of interest, delight and discovery. It's much less sour and maltier than I had anticipated, with the two elements balancing each other very nicely. The taste moves from the malt to coriander, with hints of spice (though not the winter warmer variety by any means) darting about, finishing with a bit of a citrusy sourness and the slightest smattering of salt.

M: Sticky, medium-bodied.

D: This is an exceptionally good beer; the taste is very unusual without being challenging, and the smell is among the best non-hop forward beers I've experienced. The beer is quite refreshing at first, but towards the end the salt kicks in quite a bit. I don't think this is undesirable, but it does make a second glass a bit daunting. Perhaps with a different beer or a glass of water in between, it would be okay, but as is it drops the drinkability a tad. I still wouldn't change a thing.

God, I hope the Portsmouth Brewery brews this again!\xa01,581 charactersFrankLloydMike, Nov 29, 2010", "3.88/5\xa0\xa0rDev -1.5%look: 4 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 422oz bomber.
A) Pours with a two finger head. Settles to a tight, creamy head with sticky lacing. Cloudy body. Copper in color.
S) A bit yeasty. Citrus notes - similar to lemons. Grainy - wheat. 
T) Grainy and malty sweet up front. Moves with smoothness towards the finish. Ends with a slight lemon sour bite. 
M) Creamy. Fairly smooth. Medium body.
D) A nice brew. I'd have another.\xa0383 charactersu2carew, Nov 28, 2010", '3.85/5\xa0\xa0rDev -2.3%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.5I purchased this bottle at the brewpub after sampling the beer on draft. It's been in my cellar for two weeks I'm pouring it into a pint glass. The brewery describes this beer as such: "Gose is an ancient German sour wheat beer that is brewed with coriander and salt. We get the sour characteristic from a partial sour mash rather then using the Pedio in the secondary. In the Dunkel version we bumped up the malt profile and added some caramel malts to give some color and a little malt sweetness."

A big bubbly head rising as I pour into the center of the glass. It is tan in color and very fizzy. I can see and hear bubbles popping. The liquid is cloudy and colored orange and brown. An impression of movement can be glimpsed within the glass, compliments of tiny bubbles rising upwards. Some patchy lacing is left behind as the head settles.

Strong dark wheat aromas are detected when I inhale. There is a slight sweetness to the nose as well. Coriander spice can also be smelled.

An interesting succession of flavors is present in each swallow. It begins with wheat flavors. I can also taste lemon, banana, and coriander. The salt flavoring moves towards the front as I swallow. A slight bit of alcohol is present, along with the wheat, in the aftertaste. Also present here is a touch of sourness.

The beer has a medium body and slightly above average levels of carbonation. Plenty of coating is left on my tongue. Some stickiness is left on my lips. 

This is a pretty interesting beer, and my first exposure to the style. I find it to be very refreshing, even with the added salt. I think it would be great on a warm day in early fall. I probably wouldn't order more than one round at the pub, only because I like to try a variety of beers when I'm at a brewpub I can't visit often. I'll be able to finish this 22 ounce bottle easily. It is my only bottle, but I wouldn't mind if I had purchased a second, as this would be an interesting one to share with friends.\xa01,985 charactersToasterChef, Nov 26, 2010']

name: Cucumber Lime Gose
review:
['4.09/5\xa0\xa0rDev -4.4%look: 3.75 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4 | overall: 4Great summer beer. Nice and tart, easy drinking. Really like the balance in this one between the lime and the cucumber, much more lime than cucumber. Lime pops huge upfront and finishes clean w cucumber lingering.\xa0214 charactersSFC21, Jul 22, 2019', '4.41/5\xa0\xa0rDev +3%look: 4.25 | smell: 4.5 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.25Enjoyed at Copenhagen beerfest
A: Light fizzy head semi hazy
N: Cucumber, raddichino, sake, candied ginger, like sushi kinda, floral spices, malts
T: Tart flemmy funk, cucumber, but not earthy, a little lime zest, creamy toasty wheat
M: Med to lighter bod fizzy carb\xa0266 charactersjlindros, Mar 19, 2018', "4.63/5\xa0\xa0rDev +8.2%look: 4 | smell: 4.75 | taste: 4.75 | feel: 4.5 | overall: 4.5Enjoyed at the Copenhagen Beer Festival. Reviewed from notes.

A - Poured a nice hazy straw hue with a rather thin head.

S - Aromas of enormous fresh cucumber with bright lime notes. Smells like I've stuck my head into the cucumber patch in my garden! Little bit of salinity on the nose as well.

T - Taste is similar to the nose. Just incredible cucumber notes and bright citrus/lime, there is a good salinity note as well along with nice tart creamy wheat. Just spot on!

M - Mouthfeel is nicely carbonated, bright and crisp without getting flemmy.

O - Overall this was an incredibly impressive gose. Would love to get more of this in some format and enjoy in the summer. Just lovely.

Serving Type: on tap\xa0710 charactersrudzud, Mar 10, 2018", '3.38/5\xa0\xa0rDev -21%look: 3.5 | smell: 3 | taste: 3.25 | feel: 4 | overall: 3.75750 mL bottle. Kinda dull golden body. Small white head. Smells strongly of cucumber. A little lime with some accompanying acidity. Tastes pretty much the same. Lots of cucumber. Some lime. Moderate tartness. Salty finish. Light body. It’s not bad. Dangerous combination that works pretty well.\xa0296 charactersAlieniloquium, May 24, 2017']

name: Maracuja Passion Fruit Gose
review:
['4.1/5\xa0\xa0rDev -0.5%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4 | overall: 4Lactose in a sour is a good call. It helps maintain the fruitiness while keeping the acidity in check. Good stuff. Maracuja is a tropical, sweet and smooth treat that wont make you pucker after a sip, wish I had another.\xa0220 charactersBeanBump, Nov 24, 2018', '2.03/5\xa0\xa0rDev -50.7%look: 3.75 | smell: 2.5 | taste: 1.5 | feel: 3 | overall: 1.5Medium body & mouthfeel. Smell of over-ripe fruit, an artificial-seeming aroma. Tastes more like guava than passion fruit, but really it just tastes way too sweet... like Sweet Tarts candy with a nasty sugar & chalk aftertaste. I winced at the first sip, bravely tried a couple more, then gave up and poured the thing down the drain.\xa0333 charactersintransitive, Oct 29, 2017', '4.3/5\xa0\xa0rDev +4.4%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4 | overall: 4.522 ounce bottle into tulip glass; no bottle dating, but is a recent release. Pours slightly hazy golden amber/light orange color with a 1-2 finger foamy and fluffy off white head with decent retention, that reduces to nothing pretty quickly. Minimal lacing on the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of huge huge sour/juicy/tangy passion fruit, fruit skin, peach, pineapple, apricot, lemon, lime, green apple, grape, mango, melon, papaya, berry, sea salt, hay, grass, wheat, cracker, light lacto funk/pepper, and yeast earthiness. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of fruity/acidic yeast, passion fruit juice, salt, and moderate pale malt notes; with big strength. Taste of huge sour/juicy/tangy passion fruit, fruit skin, peach, pineapple, apricot, lemon, lime, green apple, grape, mango, melon, papaya, berry, sea salt, hay, grass, wheat, cracker, light lacto funk/pepper, and yeast earthiness. Good amount of fruity/lactic tart/sourness, fruit tang, and light yeast spiciness on the finish. Lingering notes of sour/tangy passion fruit, fruit skin, peach, pineapple, apricot, lemon, lime, green apple, grape, mango, melon, papaya, berry, sea salt, hay, grass, wheat, cracker, light lacto funk/pepper, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a while. Incredible complexity, robustness, and balance of fruity/acidic yeast, passion fruit juice, salt, and moderate pale malt flavors; with a nice malt/sourness balance. Increasingly puckering, but not astringent on sourness. Light-moderate dryness from sourness and fruit tang, increasing through the glass. Medium-high carbonation and medium body; with a very smooth, acidic, grainy, tangy, tannic, and saline balanced mouthfeel that is great. Zero warming alcohol as expected of 7%. Overall this is an amazing imperial fruited gose! All around incredible complexity, robustness, and balance of fruity/acidic yeast, passion fruit juice, salt, and moderate pale malt flavors; very smooth and quite refreshing to drink; despite the increasingly lactic/tangy/tannic/drying finish. The Lacto is pretty intense, but not totally overpowering. Enormous amounts of juicy fruit and yeast complexity; and a nice malt backbone to help control the acidity. A bit more salty/saline than most I’ve had before, but it doesn’t throw off the balance at all. A highly enjoyable offering.\xa02,361 characterssuperspak, Jul 29, 2017', '3.92/5\xa0\xa0rDev -4.9%look: 3.75 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 4Poured from 22oz bottle into Chimay goblet.

L - Pale, orange gold fizzy pour, very soda-like

S - Pineapple, passion fruit, sharp tartness.

T - Saliva inducing sour saltiness. Tart passion fruit.

F - Juicy, carbonation is supportive. Alcohol is not noticeable at all.

Sour patch soda with a kick. Turbo powered option for those that like hard lemonades.\xa0359 charactersREDAMI, Jul 15, 2017', "4.29/5\xa0\xa0rDev +4.1%look: 4.25 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.25Look - hazy copper color with an initial head that doesn't last with no real film
Smell - really tart sour ale scent
Taste - very tart with lots of tropical fruit. Not sure what passion fruit taste like so I can't really say it taste like what's in it
Feel - pretty think was a light crisp carb
Overall - fantastic!\xa0316 charactersdrdiesel9483, Jul 10, 2017", '4.32/5\xa0\xa0rDev +4.9%look: 3.75 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.25L) The beer pours a lovely, hazy amber color with intense carbonation. The head forms with rather large bubbles and dissipates fairly quickly.

S) The smell is wonderful! It is incredibly passion-fruit forward, with many other tropical notes in there such as pineapple or stone-fruit. There is a crisp acidity that can be detected in the nose.

T) The taste is far more sour than the nose would indicate, but is absolutely delightful nonetheless. The passion-fruit dominates the palate, with notes of unripened peach and apricot. There seems to be a honey-like sweetness coming from the malt itself that lends itself perfectly to the intense lactic and citric acid profile. Little salt.

F) High carbonation. Very full bodied for the style.

O) Quite a nice gose, would recommend and buy again. Manages to be both assertive with its flavors and well balanced as a whole.\xa0870 charactersDewsby, Jul 02, 2017', "4.21/5\xa0\xa0rDev +2.2%look: 4 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4 | overall: 4.25Intensely tart and chocked full of tropical fruit fare, Rhinegeist's rendition of Liepzig's sour, salty and spicy ale trends much more sour, seeming berlinerweiss-like in its sheer acidity but seductive still with its tantalizing passionfruit charm.

Golden, orange, peachy and rich with haze, the ale seems to carry the appearance of fruit juice with extra pulp. Billowing with froth, the ale falls still shortly after. But the nose is enlivened with the nose piercing tang of tropical sassy fruit and a hint of stone fruit marmalade to follow. Lightly herbal and musty, the scent precedes a sweet fruit taste of pulled candy, saltwater taffy and lifesaver.

Across the palate, the ale sheds the bulk of its sweetness and the wheat and grain underpinnings support the sourness in much the same what that pastries do. High passionfruit stuns the tastebuds with strong sourness and the acidic twang of apricot, peach and grape. Lightly winey, the beer sings a sangria tune into a finish of lime, crabapple, sourdough and cellar-like mustiness.

Finishing sour, sharp and acutely acidic, the medium light bodied beer lays tracks of sour candies on a medium short aftertaste and an afterglow of musty peach wine.\xa01,209 charactersBEERchitect, Jun 28, 2017"]

name: Wildberry Sorbet Gose
review:
['4.21/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4 | overall: 4.255 oz pour on tap. Tons of berry flavor with a hint of lime and moderate tartness. Not an over-the-top beer, surprising for a Decadent Ales offering. (Thank you for not ruining this beer with vanilla!)\xa0200 charactersLucular, Aug 02, 2019', "4.33/5\xa0\xa0rDev +2.9%look: 4.25 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4 | overall: 4.25If you think that all Decadent Ales are insulin shocking sweetness disguised as some sort of IPA, then think again. The tartness, succinct flavor and complex fruitiness of their berry soaked gose shows that they are much more than just sugar and cream.

Pouring nearly blood red in color, there's no mistaking Wildberry Sorbet's fruits. Siding slightly on the hues of lavender and pink, a frothy wheaten head builds on the rim and draws in the senses with jaw tightening tartness of citrus, wine and succulent berry fruits with a hint of burlap scented must. Hard candy and saltwater taffy frame the beer's candied sweetness upfront with a juiciness usually reserved for fruit punch.

The acidity of the Germany styled sour ale begins to wash the sweetness and breadiness off of the middle palate as the full berry medley springs to lift. Raspberries, strawberries, blackberries and blueberries all make a huge jammy impact on taste but without the sweetness of jellies or jams. Green apple, lime, gooseberry, yuzu and tamarind sourness ensure that the late palate is pleasantly acidic with the berries giving strong impressions of fruited red wines with a light earthen must of sourdough and weathered woods.

Medium bodied for sour ale, the beer's strong acidity is far more sour than is required for gose and its fruit impression overtakes anything resembling wheat, salt or coriander-like, but the beer's hard-to-identify base taste is easily made up for by the acute tartness and the berry punch.\xa01,501 charactersBEERchitect, Jul 16, 2019", '4.21/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4.25 | smell: 4.5 | taste: 4 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.25Appearance - Pours dark reddish color with a huge pink head excellent retention. Stings of lacing.

Aroma - No need to even get the glass close before the raspberry comes out. I cannot say that I pick up all the fruit in this but the raspberry and blackberry I really pick up. Light vanilla as well.

Taste - Really tart other than the raspberry nothing really singles itself out for me. Not as much vanilla but a good bit of salt which I like.

Feel - Light bodied, slightly prickly carbonation pretty dry finish.

Overall - Really well done Gose great flavors crushable and easy drinking.\xa0590 charactersDragginballs76, Jul 10, 2019', '4.25/5\xa0\xa0rDev +1%look: 4.25 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.25Pours a ruby red color, hazy, ample micro carbonation, creamy pink bead. Light raspberry aroma. Great raspberry / strawberry flavor, light, not too sweet, nice little sour pucker at the end. Very light and refreshing, would buy again. Wish it was a little lighter abv.

7/3/19
16 oz can, no date, but I assume it is fairly fresh.
4.25 rating\xa0345 charactersTony210, Jul 03, 2019', '4.28/5\xa0\xa0rDev +1.7%look: 4.5 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4.5 | overall: 416 ounce can into tulip glass, canned in 6/2019. Pours very hazy deep ruby red/orange, light pink/purple color with a 1-2 finger dense and rocky light pink head with fantastic retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Nice dense spotty soapy lacing clings on the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation. Fantastic appearance. Aromas of huge juicy/tart/tangy raspberry, strawberry, blackberry, blueberry, fruit jam/skin/seed, lemon, lime, citrus zest, orange, peach, plum, pear, apricot, red/green apple, currant, red grape/wine, sea salt, hay, straw, grass, wheat, cracker, biscuit dough, light peppercorn/lacto funk, and yeast earthiness. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of berries, lemon zest, fruity/acidic yeast, and pale/wheat malt notes; with big strength. Taste of huge juicy/tart/tangy raspberry, strawberry, blackberry, blueberry, fruit jam/skin/seed, lemon, lime, citrus zest, orange, peach, plum, pear, apricot, red/green apple, currant, red grape/wine, sea salt, hay, straw, grass, wheat, cracker, biscuit dough, light peppercorn/lacto funk, and yeast earthiness. Light-moderate fruity/lactic tartness, fruit tang, and light spiciness on the finish. Lingering notes of tart/tangy berries, lemon, lime, citrus zest, orange, peach, plum, pear, apricot, red/green apple, currant, red grape/wine, sea salt, hay, straw, grass, wheat, cracker, biscuit dough, light peppercorn/lacto funk, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a while. Incredible complexity, robustness, and balance of berries, lemon zest, fruity/acidic yeast, and pale/wheat malt flavors; with a fantastic malt/tartness and tangy fruit balance; with no cloying/puckering flavors after the finish. Light-moderate increasing dryness from lingering tartness and tangy fruit. Medium carbonation and light-medium body; with a very smooth, moderately creamy/bready/grainy, fairly acidic/tangy/tannic, and lightly saline mouthfeel that is fantastic. Zero warming alcohol for 6%. Overall this is an incredible fruited gose! All around fantastic complexity, robustness, and balance of berries, lemon zest, fruity/acidic yeast, and pale/wheat malt flavors; very smooth and refreshing to drink with the modestly acidic/tangy/tannic/drying finish; fantastically soft feel, not overly lactic/salty. Fantastic balance of super juicy/jammy berries and Lacto complexity; with a great pale/wheat malt backbone against acidity. Light residual sweetness with lingering acidic/tangy dryness. A highly enjoyable offering, and amazingly spot on style example.\xa02,552 characterssuperspak, Jun 26, 2019']

name: Badisch Gose
review:
['3.38/5\xa0\xa0rDev -14.9%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.25 | taste: 3.25 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.5Pours a clouded pale yellow with a bigger, soon receeding head.

Smells of wet hay, grass with a bit of salt and flowery citrus.

Drinks light and refreshing, light bodied with a higher carbonation.

Tastes of bread dough, citrus zest and cardamom, together with koriander and a lighter peppery note. Turns sweeter then with caramel malts adding a bit complexity to the flavors, as well as a note of sea salt. Finishes clean and crisp with a little more hay and straw, entangled into a profound maltiness.

Quite okay and well balanced, with nothing in particular standing out in this.\xa0585 charactersaleigator, Aug 23, 2019', "3.92/5\xa0\xa0rDev -1.3%look: 4.5 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 4 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 4L:
-pours a hazy straw golden with a medium,foamy,white head
-medium carbonation visible
S:
-huge coriander note,lemon,banana,clove,pineapple
T:
-Follows the nose plus salt and bread dough.
F:
-medium to high carbonation
-light to medium body
O:
Certainly not a Gose,there's no lactic acidity here.
It makes for a very nice Witbier though.\xa0339 charactersdrmeto, Apr 19, 2017", '3.87/5\xa0\xa0rDev -2.5%look: 3.75 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.75Pours a light straw-gold with slight haze and small-to-medium head that left without lacing. Nose is nice bright lemon, some acidic tartness, and some light hops rounds it out. Taste is not as exciting. Very straightforward with citrus, but lacks necessary tartness. Refreshing and crushable, but I want that twang! Overall, a good beer that screams to be more than it is.\xa0377 characterscaptaincoffee, Sep 09, 2016', "3.85/5\xa0\xa0rDev -3%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 4 | overall: 3.75Hazy bright yellow color with a bit of white foam. Aroma is quite interesting. At first I get a punch of fresh hops but with lemon juice in the background. Taste starts like a witbier. I get coriander, wheat sweetness, a bit of banana and just a int of lemon and lime. No tartness at all. Light to medium body with effervescent mouthfeel. It's a nice beer but I don't really know why they call it a gose. It's not tart, maybe a bit salty but mostly it's like a hoppy witbier.\xa0475 charactersCiocanelu, Jul 19, 2016", '4.11/5\xa0\xa0rDev +3.5%look: 3.75 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4From the bottle, it pours a hazy amber with a small head, quickly dissipating to a thin ring. The nose detects some citrus, along with the scent of the sea (probably entirely in my mind, however). The flavor is subdued, slightly salty at the end. Yum!\xa0254 charactersBeerAndGasMasks, Jun 27, 2016', "4.24/5\xa0\xa0rDev +6.8%look: 4 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.25Slightly hazy straw color with minimal head and no lacing. 
The aroma makes me think of what a Hefeweizen might smell like if there were a Shandy/Radler/Alster version: banana-like Hefeweizen notes, wonderful lemony tartness upfront and additional coriander, along with some underlying graininess to it. 
Taste reminds me more of a tart Saison than a Gose, with very faint saltiness at the end, but which does become more pronounced as the beer warms. 
Overall, a really great beer, especially for summer. I'd like to see them do a fruity version, as is common these days with the style.\xa0587 charactersmoose1980, May 22, 2016", '4.24/5\xa0\xa0rDev +6.8%look: 4 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.25Will have to revisit this one (to write a proper review), as I only had half a small bottle -- and that not in ideal circumstances. Also, my first Gose, so unsure of the style. But whatever, it was a wonderful beer and I look forward to our next meeting :-)\xa0257 charactersTomais, Dec 28, 2015', '4.3/5\xa0\xa0rDev +8.3%look: 4 | smell: 4.5 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.25Picked this up at a great beer shop in Darmstadt, Germany, Maruhn Welt der Getränke. Cloudy yellow-orange pour with a one finger foamy white head with good retention and lacing. Huge perfumey, citrusy hop nose with hints of lemon zest, orange blossoms, coriander, white pepper, and tangerine. The taste is dominated by the citrus hops as well with hints of lemon, coriander, white pepper, orange zest, and some nice subtle saltiness on the finish. The mouthfeel is light bodied, crisp, and very refreshing with huge drinkability. Overall, this was a really pleasant surprise and a really well done interpretation of the style, especially considering this was from a German macro brewery. All it was really lacking was a bit of sourness. Highly recommended!\xa0764 charactersbeerdrifter, Jul 19, 2015']

name: Never Never Backdown Backdown
review:
['4/5\xa0\xa0rDev -2.9%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 416 ounce can into tulip glass, canned on 3/20/2018. Pours opaquely murky green color with a 1-2 finger dense and fluffy off white head with great retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Nice spotty soapy lacing clings on the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of big juicy/lightly tart/tangy apricots, fruit skin/pits, lemon, lime, orange, peach, pear, green apple, melon, white wine, hay, straw, grass, sea salt, wheat, cracker, light lacto funk/pepper, and yeast earthiness. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of apricots, fruity/acidic yeast, and moderate pale/wheat malt notes; with great strength. Taste of big juicy/lightly tart/tangy apricots, fruit skin/pits, lemon, lime, orange, peach, pear, green apple, melon, white wine, hay, straw, grass, sea salt, wheat, cracker, light lacto funk/pepper, and yeast earthiness. Light-moderate fruity/lactic tartness, fruit tang, and light spiciness on the finish. Lingering notes of tart/tangy apricots, fruit skin/pits, lemon, lime, orange, peach, pear, green apple, melon, white wine, hay, straw, grass, sea salt, wheat, cracker, light lacto funk/pepper, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a while. Great complexity, robustness, and balance of apricots, fruity/acidic yeast, and moderate pale/wheat malt flavors; with an awesome malt/tartness and tangy fruit balance; with minimal puckering flavors after the finish. Light-moderate increasing dryness from tartnness, tangy fruit, and carbonation. Medium-high carbonation and medium-full body; with a very smooth, creamy/bready/grainy, fairly acidic/tangy/tannic, and lightly saline balanced mouthfeel that is great. Zero warming alcohol as expected of 5.1%. Overall this is an excellent fruited gose! All around great complexity, robustness, and balance of apricots, fruity/acidic yeast, and moderate pale/wheat malt flavors; very smooth and easy to drink with the mellowly acidic/tangy/tannic/drying finish. Not overly lactic or salty. Insanely enormous apricot presence; with spot on base style balance. A very enjoyable offering as expected.\xa02,101 characterssuperspak, Aug 04, 2018', '3.6/5\xa0\xa0rDev -12.6%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.5Ok so I know I need to definitely stay away from the triple fruited additions then. This crosses the line for me from tart beer to just tart viscous fruit juice, much prefer the single fruit additions\xa0200 charactersVeganUndead, Apr 05, 2018', '4.35/5\xa0\xa0rDev +5.6%look: 4.5 | smell: 4.5 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.5 | overall: 4.25Never Never Backdown Backdown - The Veil
Double Apricot Gose - 5.5% abv
Canned 3/20/18 (9 days ago)

L - 2 finger yellow head atop a glowing yellow body.

S - apricot, salt, sweetness.

T - huge apricot front. Salty middle. Surprisingly not at all sweet. No bitterness, no booziness.

F - medium body and feel.

O - the definition of a summer beer.\xa0348 charactersCanConPhilly, Mar 29, 2018']

name: Never More
review:
["4.56/5\xa0\xa0rDev +8.3%look: 5 | smell: 4.5 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4.75 | overall: 4.5Enjoyed poured from the tap at Lyon Bière Festival #3

The whole thing is perfectly balanced all along. The fruit seems so fresh. Never lactic, it's got the fruit tartness. Insanely juicy. 

More more more!\xa0310 charactersBruno74200, Apr 23, 2018"]

name: Maverick & Gose
review:
['3.77/5\xa0\xa0rDev +3.6%look: 4 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.75First had poured from 12-oz. can, with paper label, into stange. An unaggressive little gose, with elements of a Czech Pilsner, good for an Indian Summer afternoon.\xa0164 charactersBigGold, Oct 22, 2017', "4.07/5\xa0\xa0rDev +11.8%look: 4.25 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4.5 | overall: 4Review from BA Mag Issue #118 ( Nov 2016 )

Tasty, Authentic, Tart, Salty
It's very refreshing to run into a brewery’s beer where the simple fundamentals are met, even if it’s a style so newly resurrected that most consumers don’t have a clue about its origins or understand what it is supposed to be. That kind of hands-on education I can really respect. This no frills version of a Gose from Second Self comes across as authentic, enjoyable, and most of all, very drinkable. With a beer like this in their lineup, they are surely a brewery to watch. [Jason]

Look 4.25 | Smell 4.00 | Taste 4.00 | Feel 4.50 | Overall 4.00\xa0630 charactersJason, Jun 22, 2017", '3.75/5\xa0\xa0rDev +3%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.75even with the dry hop, this beer is somewhat bland and uninteresting as the style goes. the other interpretation however, which i am back and forth on, is that its just delicate and nuanced, and that i should appreciate such a clean and bright beer that was soured in this method. its a nice contrast to the hazy messy cheesy sloppy overly acidic kettle soured or sour mashed beers that are everywhere right now. this is so much more refined, tidy, and pretty, so even though it doesnt taste incredibly pungent or anything, its pretty well made beer and i appreciate the subtlety. its clear, which is uncommon in gose, light honey colored with a short lived smidge of white head. the aroma shows a little citrus hop character and just the slightest lactic tang. no herbaceous smell from the coriander, no cereals from the wheat. the flavor is kind of like that too, not much happening on the malt front and very little body. a little citrus kick and a little clean bitterness from the hops in front of a barely even tangy sourness, incredibly reserved for the style. the tartness is less than even say a cranberry, its really refreshing because of that. i like the salt, i can taste it and feel it, and its also just the right amount. there is a little less for it to bring out, so it just sort of stands on its own which is cool. this is amazingly easy drinking, a true crusher for the style, the lighter acidity helps with that. i wish for a little more carbonation, but its pretty awesome as it is. unexpected, i liked this more and more as i drank through it. one can just is not enough...\xa01,593 charactersStonedTrippin, Dec 18, 2016', '3.88/5\xa0\xa0rDev +6.6%look: 3 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4Appearance: Pours a scantly hazed, very pale yellow body with a thinning, white layers of suds.

Smell: Gentle hints of floral, citrus. Light graininess. Subtle brine and coriander accents.

Taste: Softly tart, lemony atop very faintly bready malts. A welcome salinity turns to some herbaceousness, a bit more citrus and floral coriander. Drying, lightly tart finish.

Mouthfeel: Light-bodied. Medium carbonation.

Overall: A solid, likable gose.\xa0446 charactersChainGangGuy, Jul 17, 2016', "3.85/5\xa0\xa0rDev +5.8%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 4 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.75A: Pale yellow with a 1/2-finger head
S: Light, mostly wheat/malt, a bit of herbs, citrus, yeast and sea salt
T: Sea salt up front followed by citrus, herbs, spice, lemon then a yeast/salt finish. Light and subtle but the complex
M: Light-bodied, a bit salty & spicy
O: This isn't one to quaff but to contemplate. The flavors & complexities are there, just subtle\xa0363 charactersONUMello, Jul 15, 2016", "3.13/5\xa0\xa0rDev -14%look: 3.25 | smell: 3.25 | taste: 3.25 | feel: 3 | overall: 2.75Gose's are quickly becoming the new 'tropical/citrus ipa'... Too many people trying to make them and only a few really standout. I root for these guys as a local ATL brewer (and GT alumni on top of that). 

This is just a Gose - slightly above average. Drinkable, slightly tart, citrus and white sparkling wine (?) notes come through. Body extremely light. Pretty forgettable beer unfortunately

Great name, nice guys - probably wouldn't seek this one out again\xa0464 charactersBloodbuzz99, Jul 03, 2016", '2.42/5\xa0\xa0rDev -33.5%look: 3.5 | smell: 2.75 | taste: 2 | feel: 3 | overall: 2.25On tap

Pours a fairly clear golden color

Smells like some spices, kind of like their Thai Wheat

Taste is insipid, some ginger, a touch of salt, hardly any acid, and no real lactic fermentation character. Did they just pour a little lactic acid and salt in their Thai Wheat to try and hop on the gose hype train? 

Tastes lazy and uninspired\xa0343 charactersbrewfunk, Oct 25, 2015', "3.46/5\xa0\xa0rDev -4.9%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.25 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.5Appearance - gold in color, typical. Smell - weird smell can't pinpoint it. Taste - very slight fruit but mostly salt and slight spices. Overall - it's ok, nothing outstanding, but good.\xa0186 charactersExtol, Sep 29, 2015"]

name: Best Maid Sour Pickle Beer
review:
["1.27/5\xa0\xa0rDev -61.5%look: 3 | smell: 1 | taste: 1 | feel: 2.5 | overall: 1I had to give this a try...even as a gimmick. Though let me just say up front, this is bad, don't get it unless you like hurting yourself.

A: Pours a pale yellow. A small white head and light lace. Giving some pity points here.
S: OK, this is horrible. Vinegar, onion, and garlic garlic garlic. Briny and I shudder every time I put my nose to the glass.
T: Nope, just nope. I can't get that oily vinegary, onion, and garlic brine out my mouth. No acidity to help, at least I can't tell if it is there. This is a bad joke.
M/O: Slightly carbonated brine water. Again, more pity points being added. Can't drink more than a few sips and i'm done.

I mean, I know this was just suppose to be a gimmick. Though I do really like pickles, in any form. So thinking maybe there is some guilty pleasure to be had here. But no, just don't even try. Nothing redeemable here. Though, apparently the reaction was so big for Marin House they are making this again, and are contemplating having this be a year round. That is a mistake, everyone, including me, will try this once just cause...then it will be a joke forever and nobody will buy it (or even finish the one they purchased) ever again.\xa01,202 characterschamp103, Nov 03, 2019", "2.24/5\xa0\xa0rDev -32.1%look: 4.25 | smell: 2 | taste: 2 | feel: 4 | overall: 1.5Received a six pack in a trade. On paper it looks like a good idea...

A - Poured into a Kate the Great tulip a nice hazy golden hue with a thin white head that fades to leave light wisps. 

S - Big aromas of, well, pickle juice. Garlic, dill, sour tartness.

T - Taste is similar to the nose salty, garlic, sour, mote salt, vinegar.

M - Mouthfeel is lightly carbonated, crisp.

O - Overall this was a really really weird beer. Sure, it drinks like pickle juice but that's not really a good thing. Without the garlic this would probably be decent but there's just so much aggressive garlic on the nose and taste that utterly ruins this beer. A shame.

Serving Type: can\xa0671 charactersrudzud, Aug 24, 2019", '1.86/5\xa0\xa0rDev -43.6%look: 3 | smell: 2 | taste: 2 | feel: 2 | overall: 1No thanks, and I mean seriously wtf rudzud

Light foamy head, no retention, little lacing, hazy straw blond color

Nose friggg bad, sour sour vinegar, tons of picked garlic and onion, dill, spice, seriously wtf

Taste salty vinegar brine, super pickle brine, no beer character, just salty pickle brine

Mouth acidic brine

Overall, no, just no!\xa0344 charactersjlindros, Aug 21, 2019', "2.36/5\xa0\xa0rDev -28.5%look: 2.75 | smell: 2.25 | taste: 2.25 | feel: 2.5 | overall: 2.5This beer is ture to its name. Best Maid Sour Pickle Beer tastes just like Best Maid Pickles-made in Mansfield Tx since 1926. It is exciting to see two local companies come together for an inspiring project. I'm not a fan of pickle juice and by extension the beer was equally running against my taste. However my family loved Best Maid Sour Pickle Beer. For pickle juice lovers this is the beer for you.\xa0403 charactersjeschaefer, Aug 19, 2019", '2.95/5\xa0\xa0rDev -10.6%look: 3 | smell: 3 | taste: 3 | feel: 2.5 | overall: 312oz can, wine glass, canned 

Normal beer yellow with initial head that completely vanishes. 

Pickle juice with sour beer behind it. 

If you suspect that this beer tastes like someone took a base Gose or other sour and added gallons of pickle juice, you’d be right. It has that bright dill and vinegar acidity that we all love pickles for, but there just isn’t much beer here. 

The body has some weight to it and it does manage not to be too much. It finishes salty and a little herbal, like pickle juice. 

I cannot understand the very high ratings this is receiving on here. Martin House added pickle juice to a base sour and while it would make a good michelada or beery Mary, it’s not a good beer.\xa0711 charactersbrewerburgundy, Aug 17, 2019']

name: Tom YUM Thai Gose
review:
['3.54/5\xa0\xa0rDev -8.5%look: 3.5 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.25 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.75I had this beer four years ago at their location in Ormond Beach and it was superb...the saltiness and the spice balance was spot on.....today I am at their Port Orange location....trying the same style of beer and the spicy hot is gone...however I still enjoyed it. HOG\xa0270 charactershogrider, May 09, 2019', '3.8/5\xa0\xa0rDev -1.8%look: 4 | smell: 3.25 | taste: 4 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 4On tap at the brewpub in Port Orange, FL.
Very pale, lightly hazy golden body with a good white head. 
Mild tropical aroma with a mild for style flavor. Good balance between the salt, tartness, yeast and grains. Refreshing. 
Light body with medium carbonation.\xa0260 characterschinchill, Nov 06, 2017', '3.96/5\xa0\xa0rDev +2.3%look: 3.75 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 4Pours light cloudy yellow color with a huge white foamy head no lacing but head lasts forever
aroma is pretty much lemon/lime and tons of spices and peppers.
Taste pretty amazing they pulled this off in a gose but light saltiness lots of spicy hot pepper flavor and a balance of light lemon.
Light bodied good amount of heat and some dryness
overall would be hard to drink many of these but a well done gose that hits their mark.\xa0429 charactersDragginballs76, Sep 12, 2017']

name: Mojito Gose
review:
["4.09/5\xa0\xa0rDev -1%look: 3.75 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4 | overall: 4L - Pour a straw colored body that is very clear with a frothy one finger eggshell colored head. The pour really reminded me of how a cider usually pours. Given the base beer, I guess that's to be expected.

S - The salty gose base is definitely not covered up by the hints of rum and mint.

T - Tart and salty at first, as it should be. The rum barrels round out the edges of the beer and the mint is a unique addition.

F - Light bodied and medium carbonation. It has a dry finish.

O - The gose is a great beer by itself. The rum barrels smooth it out and the mint adds some complexity.\xa0594 characterscvm4, Jan 29, 2017", '4/5\xa0\xa0rDev -3.1%look: 3.5 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 3.25 | overall: 4Appearance: Arrives with a slightly hazy goldenstraw color, no head and no lace

Smell: Smells like a Mojito, with the lime and mint coming through

Taste: The lime and the salt are pronounced with hints of mint and sugar developing; a bit of lactic sourness pervades the finish

Mouthfeel: Light body with very low carbonation

Overall: Surprised at the poor carbonation at the brewpub but this would be much better if properly carbonated\xa0444 charactersbrentk56, Aug 02, 2016']

name: Blood Orange Gose
review:
["3.86/5\xa0\xa0rDev -7.2%look: 4 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.75Aroma is like that powdered lemonade. Tons of tart blood orange and lemon juice. Literally like a carbonated blood orange juice without the color. Lacking a bit of the saltiness. Not very complex, but it's very true to its name. It gets a 77.5/100.\xa0248 charactersDaverCS, Jun 29, 2016", '4.53/5\xa0\xa0rDev +8.9%look: 4.25 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.75 | feel: 4.5 | overall: 4.5Appearance: Arrives honey colored and cloudy; with a head that retains well; good lacing action

Smell: The blood orange dominates the aroma with wheat bread tones backing it up

Taste: Tart, from the outset, with the blood orange dominant throughout; wheat bread flavors underpin and the finish has a moderately salty character

Mouthfeel: Light to medium body with moderate carbonation

Overall: This is an incredible beer that rings all the bells, from the distinctly sour tones of blood orange to the underlying malt character and, finally, to the precision saltiness on the finish\xa0590 charactersbrentk56, Jun 20, 2016', "4.52/5\xa0\xa0rDev +8.7%look: 4.75 | smell: 4.5 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4.5 | overall: 4.5On tap at Salud in Charlotte NC. Didn't know that AZ made good beer , but this one is legit . Orange is very distinct on the back end of the taste . Impressive\xa0159 charactersTuckersmth, Jun 10, 2016"]

name: W4
review:
["4.05/5\xa0\xa0rDev -0.7%look: 3.5 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 4Hazy, peach-orange colored body; decently thick, foamy head. Lime and salt aroma; clean sea. Muted sea salt infused beer; lime and other mixed citrus qualities. Medium-light body; salty with a citrus tang and dryness.

This is probably one of the first gose beers I've tasted that actually seemed to exhibit a truly sea salt character. That said, the rest of the beer fits in nicely. Well-balanced with a bit of lightness to counterbalance the almost margarita-like quality of this beer.\xa0487 charactersbeergoot, Jul 16, 2018", "4.17/5\xa0\xa0rDev +2.2%look: 4.25 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4 | overall: 4.25Pours a slightly opaque yellow/orange with a huge fluffy white head that is incredibly well retained and left a decent amount of lacing. Smells of lime, floral notes, coriander and like I'm at the beach getting fresh ocean spray. Taste is tart lime up front, salt, coriander, floral notes, more citrus on the finish. Light bodied, very lively carbonation, mild to moderately dry mouth feel. Very refreshing, tart and crisp.\xa0423 charactersEMH73, Oct 01, 2017", '4.24/5\xa0\xa0rDev +3.9%look: 4.5 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4 | overall: 4.25L: Pours a pale mostly clear yellow with a beautiful tight-knit head and lively carbonation. Excellent head retention and very impressive lacing for the beer’s strength.

S: Big floral hop notes when poured with some bright citrus. Salt, sweaty funk, brine and wheat. The coriander begins to pop more as the beer warms along with some grassy hop aromas. 

T: A good deal more salty and tart than the aroma lets on. Tart citrusy lime is the predominant flavor, with lemons, some floral hoppiness and an ephemeral salty, puckering citrus finish. Very bright, very balanced.

F: Light body with lively, somewhat pillowy carbonation and a drying mouthfeel.

Overall: One of the most balanced goses I’ve had to date, with really nice bright citrus characters. I’d certainly buy this again.\xa0791 charactersthepenguin, Jan 14, 2016', '4.1/5\xa0\xa0rDev +0.5%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4 | overall: 4On tap at Gingerman in NYC.

Pours a hazy yellow color with white head. Super sour, lots of citrus, some salt and floral notes, and bready malts. A pretty solid beer, especially the taste.\xa0188 charactersmdfb79, Nov 10, 2015']

name: Never Forever³
review:
["4.27/5\xa0\xa0rDev -4.3%look: 4 | smell: 4.5 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4 | overall: 4.25This one pours a thick and ridiculous looking bright orange color- it looks pulpy and it's completely and utterly opaque, with a small head, and lots of lacing.

On the nose, it smells like so much and so little at the same time- it's super all super intense and Goya level juicy passionfruit on the nose. However, other than this, there's nothing. This looks to be one (delicious) note.

There's a bit more going on in the taste, as it's very sour- much more sour than any of the other Never beers that I've tried. As expected, there's a ton of authentic and somewhat overwhelming passionfruit flavor, balanced by the blinding sourness.

This is medium bodied, with a very, very juicy mouthfeel, and a good level of carbonation.

These Veil beers are starting to move out of the real what is actually beer, and I'm not truly sure how I feel about it. Nonetheless, this is a very fun beer and I had a good time drinking it.\xa0923 charactersGreesyFizeek, May 22, 2018", "4.24/5\xa0\xa0rDev -4.9%look: 4 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.25On draft. Served in a goblet glass. Body is murky golden-orange, one finger white head. Good retention. Smell is tart passion fruit, more passion fruit, and even more passion fruit. Tons of it, yet it doesn't have that stomach-churning battery acid smell that I was looking for based on the amount of fruit tartness in the beer. I like it. A bit of seaweed, minimal spice. The fruit is front and center here, and it shows on the palate. Tons of passion fruit tartness, a bit of that crisp tart lemon and wheat from the base beer. Not really getting salt, but at this point I am not expecting that. Mouthfeel is medium-lighter bodied, good carbonation, more and more passion fruit on the finish.\xa0694 charactersStevedore, Apr 04, 2018", '4.81/5\xa0\xa0rDev +7.8%look: 4.75 | smell: 5 | taste: 4.75 | feel: 4.75 | overall: 4.75Received as an extra in a trade and shared with JLindros. Canned on 3/13/18.

A - Poured into a Kate the Great tulip a nice hazy murky yellow, not gold, hue with a yellowish thin head that fades to leave nice lacing and a thin wispy head.

S - Big aromas of passion fruit galore. Huge tropical notes, lightly sticky passion fruit paste. Super aromatic.

T - Taste is similar to the nose with excellent tart tropical notes, huge passion fruit. Finish is nice and salty with very little wheat notes. 

M - Mouthfeel is nicely carbonated, medium body, little flemmy.

O - Overall this was a very good fruited gose with phenomenal passion fruit notes. Spectacular beer.

Serving Type: can\xa0684 charactersrudzud, Mar 25, 2018', "4.75/5\xa0\xa0rDev +6.5%look: 4.75 | smell: 4.75 | taste: 4.75 | feel: 4.75 | overall: 4.75Thanks to rudzud, canned 3/13
Head is basically yellow dandelion colored grapefruit color, the legs are basically just thick orange juice pulp, murky pureed mango passion fruit color

Nose is incredible, just loads and loads of fresh passion fruit, so much fresh passion fruit, passion fruit puree and a little tartness, maybe a touch of tartness, very little gose the only reason it's not a 5

Taste brings big passion fruit, less than the nose, but again layers of thick fruit pulp, like drinking passion fruit pulp blended into a smoothie, fresh passion fruit, tart, a little creamy wheat mixed in too, a bit of salt on the finish too, juicy fleshy with a touch of bitterness

Mouth is med to thicker bod with loads of fleshy pulpy, decent carb but a bit light, a little flemmy

Overall another incredible beer, so much great passion fruit pulp and a bit tart, so enjoyable\xa0876 charactersjlindros, Mar 25, 2018"]

name: Cucumber Lime Gose
review: ['5/5\xa0\xa0rDev +27.9%look: 5 | smell: 5 | taste: 5 | feel: 5 | overall: 5One of the best goses I ever had and only one of its kind. Smella like pickles with tastes of cucumber lime sourness with a touch of salt. Very well done.\xa0156 charactersBenHoppy, Dec 21, 2017', '4.54/5\xa0\xa0rDev +16.1%look: 4.25 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.75 | feel: 4.75 | overall: 4.75This cloudy gold beer smells slightly cucumber but moreso pickles yet taste is phenomenally refreshing with its cucumber sour flavor. A damn good gose.\xa0152 charactersBenjolovesbeer, Aug 21, 2017', '3.88/5\xa0\xa0rDev -0.8%look: 4 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 412 ounce bottle into tulip glass, bottled on 6/28/2017. Pours lightly hazy pale golden/yellow color with a 1 finger dense white head with good retention, that reduces to a thin cap that lingers. Light spotty lacing clings on the glass, with a light amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of huge cucumber; with some lemon, lime, pear, apple, wheat, cracker, herbal, and yeast earthiness. Nice and pleasant aromas; way too strong on cucumber, but not offensive. Taste of big lightly tart lemon, lime, cucumber, pear, apple, wheat, cracker, coriander, sea salt, herbal, and yeast earthiness. Light-moderate fruity/lactic tartness and light yeast/coriander spiciness on the finish. Lingering notes of tart lemon, lime, cucumber, pear, apple, wheat, cracker, coriander, sea salt, herbal, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Great complexity, robustness, and balance of fruity/acidic yeast, coriander, salt, cucmber, lime, and moderate pale malt flavors; with a great malt/tartness balance, and zero puckering flavors after the finish. Lightly increasing dryness from tartness. Light-medium carbonation and body; with a very smooth, moderately bready/grainy/acidic, fairly saline, and lightly sticky balanced mouthfeel that is great. Zero warming alcohol as expected of 4.4%. Overall this is a delicious gose. All around nice complexity, robustness, and balance of fruity/acidic yeast, coriander, salt, cucmber, lime, and moderate pale malt flavors; very smooth and refreshing to drink with the mellowly tart/acidic/drying finish. Really well balanced classic gose and fruit/vegetable flavors; very flavorful for the low ABV. If the nose was more balanced, I’d have no complaints. A very enjoyable offering, and very nice style example.\xa01,749 characterssuperspak, Aug 12, 2017']

name: Ice Box
review:
['2.59/5\xa0\xa0rDev -31.8%look: 2.75 | smell: 2.5 | taste: 2.5 | feel: 2.75 | overall: 2.75CAN:

Currently #28 in the top Mississippi beers list. "Lemon gose." "Ale with natural flavors." 3.5% ABV. 118 kilocalories per can.

Artificial and a bit syrupy, leaning heavy into the artificial lemon flavours at the expense of authentic fresh flavours. Why not brew this with actual lemons - say, meyer lemons? Salt is barely noticeable. I don't taste any coriander. Not sour enough either. I'm missing that briney sea salt twang the gose style is known for.

Not a bad summer sipper, but it fails to impress or to deliver in terms of basic fundaments of the style. If this is one of the top 50 beers in the state, it seems the state doesn't have much to offer...

C- / BELOW AVERAGE\xa0686 characterskojevergas, Jul 28, 2019', '3.56/5\xa0\xa0rDev -6.3%look: 2 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.75Pours a hazed amber wit a pinky of beige head. Zero head retention & lacing 

S: Some citrus notes, a little lemon 

T: Lemony notes, a little tartness, slight saltyness up front. More of the same as this warms, the lemon sweetart component gains strength. Finishes tart, a little dry with a bit of lemon sweetness

MF: Light bodied, slight carbonation 

Very drinkable, approachable take on the style. I could put some of this away in the Summer\xa0453 charactersrusspowell, Dec 19, 2018', "3.79/5\xa0\xa0rDev -0.3%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 4 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.75Clear light gold color with white cap and lacing.

Aroma of mild malt and light citrus.

Taste is just a bit puckery at first displaying a tartness that is nicely matched with the lemony citrus and a pinch of salt. Sort of Shandy meets the Surf. I would say lemon is the most prominent flavor with perhaps lime following. It's a nice blend that does come together in a pleasing whole and finishes dry.

Medium texture with balancing carbonation.

I'm puzzled why this is a Sept-Oct release when it so clearly identifies with Summer activities. It's pleasant none the less and easily drinkable.\xa0597 charactersSquire, Nov 08, 2018", '3.97/5\xa0\xa0rDev +4.5%look: 3.5 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 412 oz can dated 4/24/18. Poured into straight walled pint glass. 

Pours a darker-than-expected honey-straw color with a head of 1/2 finger that dwindles to nothing. 

Nice salty-sweet aromas with nutty malt, clover honey, and lemon shaved ice; 

Flavor is tart and mildly puckering, heavy on the flavor. Honey malt, lemon sherbet, lime, orange sherbet, cilantro, lactic acid, slight sea salt, and wheat malt. 

Feel is crisp and pleasantly creamy, with a good snap and pucker to it. 

Overall, a very enjoyable Gose beer. Very pleasantly surprised.\xa0549 charactersThe-Adjunct-Hippie, Oct 25, 2018', '3.25/5\xa0\xa0rDev -14.5%look: 3.25 | smell: 3.25 | taste: 3.25 | feel: 3.25 | overall: 3.25The beer pours out a hazy pale golden straw color, with a very thin white head----------- the aromas are of wheat, spice and floral notes(very subdued nose)-------------- the flavors are of wheat, grass and light lemon, the beer has a thin mouthfeel with a tart dry finish--------------- overall this beer was good I wish the lemon and lactose stood out more though\xa0365 charactersdertyd, Jul 04, 2018', "4.5/5\xa0\xa0rDev +18.4%look: 4.5 | smell: 4.5 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4.5 | overall: 4.5Lemon Icebox Gose has a medium, stark white head, a hazy, very bubbly, golden appearance, with minimal glass lacing and lots of white specs, suspended, throughout. Aroma is of lemon shandy, and the flavor is of lemon Gatorade, Popeye's biscuits, some lactic action, and no bitterness. You could think of this as Miller High Life Light with lemon juice, salt, and a dash of powdered milk, added. Mouthfeel is medium, and Lemon Icebox finishes mostly dry. 

RJT\xa0459 charactersRonaldTheriot, Nov 23, 2017", '4.06/5\xa0\xa0rDev +6.8%look: 4 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4First had on poured from 12-oz. can, stamped on bottom, "CANNED BY KEAZY ON 09/18/17," into stange. Except for the surprising clarity, complementary addition of lemon zest, and crushable 3.50 ABV, a straightforward interpretation of the style, with all elements well-represented.\xa0279 charactersBigGold, Nov 05, 2017']

name: Never Scared
review:
['3.87/5\xa0\xa0rDev -8.9%look: 4 | smell: 3.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4 | overall: 3.75The Veil Brewing Co. "Never Scared"
on tap at the brewery on 17 June 2017
$5 / 6 oz.

Notes: Has the appearance of a glass of grapefruit juice with a short head that immediately drops to just a thin collar of white. The lacing is of course limited as well, leaving only tiny spots behind. The aroma is tart with an odd fruitiness that's like citrus rind, brine, and maybe a little bit of guava. It's a little off-putting to be honest, the mucky, briny part at least. The flavor is sharp, definitely tart, but perhaps not all the way to full-on "sour" if that makes any sense; and the guava comes through.
