name: Blackberry Gose
review: ['3.49/5\xa0\xa0rDev -7.4%look: 3.25 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.512 oz can split with my wife. Pours a slightly cloudy not-very-purple. I expect a blackberry gose to look better than this! Moderately tart with some wheatiness and blackberry flavor. Overall pretty meh.\xa0203 charactersLucular, Sep 30, 2019']

name: Raspberry Kissing Giants
review:
["4.51/5\xa0\xa0rDev +5.4%look: 4.25 | smell: 4.5 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4.75 | overall: 4.5This is probably one of my favorite beers from Proof. However, this review is based on the most recent batch, which probably isn't my favorite batch. Nonetheless, an awesome beer!

Look: Not the look of a De Garde fruited gose, however it still looks great, pinkish-redish clean looking beer, but not as great as their last batch

Smell: bread yeast, salt, funky tartness, then you get some berry sweetness

Taste: Sour upfront, everything you look for in a gose, but the raspberry isn't hugely prominent

Feel: this was a surprisingly full feeling beer which I don't come to expect from your everyday gose, but it was smooth and refreshing.

Overall: kind of hard to compare things to De Garde, which I feel should almost be the standard for fruited sours in America, however this is an awesome beer by a relatively new brewery, and one of my favorites.\xa0854 charactersFSUlaw-and-brew, Dec 31, 2015"]

name: Jopen / Birrificio del Dugato - Coastal Gose
review:
["3.96/5\xa0\xa0rDev +19.3%look: 3.75 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 4Pours a slightly cloudy pale straw coloration with a medium, fizzy head. Smells of light wheaty, biscuity malt and citric acidity, with a hint of sea salt coming through as well. Taste follows the nose, with notes of wheaty malt, zesty, acidic citrus notes and just a hint of hay and coriander coming through as well. Finishes with a mild acidity and some sea salt lingering in the aftertaste. Smooth mouthfeel with a medium body and carbonation.

This is a great classic Gose with a mild acidity and salt level, as well as a very nice, mellow balance. I couldn't really detect any seaweed, but there is a rather pleasant, if subtle, coriander note to this.\xa0657 charactersSnowcrash000, Feb 02, 2019", '4.17/5\xa0\xa0rDev +25.6%look: 4 | smell: 4.5 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4.25Bottle, 6m to bb.

Hazy paleness, quickly dissipating foam, continued small scale bubbling from the bottom of the glass. All good.

Aroma is as should be, fresh saltiness mixed with citric notes.. but there is an exciting layer of sweet floral notes.

Taste adds tartness in moderation, emphasis on the sea but nothing of the seaweed that I can detect. Perhaps seaweed when fermented creates those floral notes? Very nice. 

Overall a very good gose with a nice balancing floral aspect.\xa0486 charactersKooVee, Dec 29, 2018', '3.91/5\xa0\xa0rDev +17.8%look: 3.75 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.75Pale blonde with thin ring of head.

Aromas of dough, sea salt, moss/lake water, and coriander.

Very bright. Tart, slightly salty, with lime and limestone character, light hibiscus, and a murky freshness I can only attribute to seaweed.

Light, easy, and carbonated.

Overall, a standout Gose. Try it.\xa0302 charactersThe-Adjunct-Hippie, Jan 15, 2017', '3.23/5\xa0\xa0rDev -2.7%look: 3.5 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 3 | feel: 3.25 | overall: 3.25Too salty. Good Gose just use the salt to accentuate the flavors rather than being really salty. It is a balance that is not well executed in this. The tartness is more citric than lactic but that doesnt bother\xa0210 characterssafaricook, May 28, 2016']

name: The Ocean Swallows The Sun
review:
['4.21/5\xa0\xa0rDev +4%look: 4 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4 | overall: 4.25Appearance - Pours somewhat murky burnt caramel color with a thin white head that dissipates very quickly.

Aroma - The rose hips and hibiscus come out right away, there is also a good amount of saltiness in the aroma. The oak is very light but noticeable as well as a light funk.

Taste - Big blast of rose hips and sea salt, a light floral flavor come in right after along with a slight floral flavor.

Feel - Light bodied well carbonated a slight syrupy finish.

Overall - A really well done gose, rose hips works very well with the salt.\xa0541 charactersDragginballs76, Jan 27, 2018', "4.25/5\xa0\xa0rDev +4.9%look: 4.25 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.25I'm not a connoisseur of goses, but The Ocean Swallows the Sun is one of the finest I've ever had. The hibiscus and rose hips smell tremendous, and they impart a delicious fruity, floral aroma to the taste as well. The sea salt is well-balanced and nicely contrasts the floral notes.

Excellent beer!\xa0300 charactersVidblain, Jan 26, 2018"]

name: Life Itself
review:
["4.14/5\xa0\xa0rDev +2%look: 4.25 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4Enjoying this beer on a warm summer night here in Cleveland. Poured from a 16 oz can into one of my pokal glasses, this beer pours a pretty clear, dark pale golden color with lots of streams of little bubbles rapidly and continuously rising ti the beer's surface a white head that's about an inch thick when first poured that eventually settles to a thick ring surrounding the inside of the glass along with a big cluster swirl of a film layer of foam and good lacing. Aromas of some bready malts and certainly some wheat along with lime notes and also a hint of lactose. A very similar flavor profile is found here, with a nice bready malt and wheat backbone for the flavor profile that's followed by a very nice lime zest that adds just the right amount of tangy sourness and a nice hint of lactose. The addition of the lactose is certainly interesting, but I feel it sort of masks/diminishes the other flavors a bit. Just a slight touch of herbal and floral hops. Has a crisp, smooth, slightly prickly, medium mouthfeel with moderate carbonation. Has a clean, slightly dry finish and aftertaste. An interesting take on this style.

Eric\xa01,147 charactersneenerzig, Jul 17, 2019", '3.52/5\xa0\xa0rDev -13.3%look: 3.5 | smell: 4 | taste: 3.25 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.5Served on tap in a 16 oz (475 ml) tonic pint glass at Good Beer, just around the corner for St. Mark's Place in Manhattan, NY.
A: Pours a cloudy, green-golden-orange color with an off white, one finger head, low retention (not even a rim) and no significant lacing.
S: Aromas of sea salt and lime predominate.
T: Semisweet, saline, and maybe a touch tart. The palate follow the nose with the addition of caramel, red berry, and coconut notes. No appreciable bitterness, but coconut seems to trail as an aftertaste.
M: Medium bodied with no more than moderate carbonation. Smooth and somewhat creamy.
O: This drank very well, but I didn't care much for the aftertaste. Didn't quite capture the billed elements of "Key Lime Pie," although I'm note sure that was really ever the point. Not bad, but would pass on a second.\xa0822 charactersVoxRationis, May 04, 2019', "3.84/5\xa0\xa0rDev -5.4%look: 3.5 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 4 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.75A: The beer is crystal clear yellow in color and has a light to moderate amount of visible carbonation. It poured with a quarter finger high white head that quickly died down, leaving lacing on the surface and a collar consisting of medium-sized bubbles around the edge of the glass.
S: Light aromas of limes are present in the nose.
T: The taste is somewhat sour and has flavors of limes with notes of graham crackers and hints of lactose.
M: It feels light- to medium-bodied and slightly tart and creamy on the palate with a moderate amount of carbonation.
O: This gose is a nice representation of a key lime pie. It wasn't overly sour and you could pick up flavors of all of the ingredients in the taste.

Serving type: can\xa0728 charactersmetter98, Nov 17, 2018"]

name: Daybreak
review:
['3.76/5\xa0\xa0rDev -1.3%look: 4.25 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3 | overall: 412oz can into IPA glassware 
Look: A medium gold, hazy, good head with great retention, decent lacing 
Smell: A hard hit of coriander, light wheat and pilsner grains, slight salty citrus, buried hops. 
Taste: Tart saltiness, lemony, grapefruity, sour, after taste is like a receding wheatiness. Gets less sour as you drink. No hopiness. Malty on the back end. 
Overall: A good beer. Would buy again and it is the only beer that I have found that my girlfriend enjoys. Thanks Intuition Aleworks!\xa0494 charactersGACraftAdvo, Mar 25, 2019']

name: Peach Llorona
review: ['4.5/5\xa0\xa0rDev +4.7%look: 4.5 | smell: 4.5 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4.5 | overall: 4.5Poured a light yellow with an off-white head. Aromas and flavors were super juicy peach and apricot and stone fruit. Not as tart as the grapefruit llorona or the plum llorona, but this was by far the juiciest/fruitiest of the bunch, in my opinion. Really great.\xa0261 characterscrob3888, Mar 13, 2016']

name: Egon's Revenge
review:
["3.5/5\xa0\xa0rDev +2.9%look: 3.5 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.5A soft pale yellow with a white cap. Faint aromas of tart plum with plenty of wheat and hints of saline. Flavor was lightly tart, more of a wheaty beer. The saline was also dialed back with made for a easy drinker that anyone could enjoy. I'd say this was in tune to a classic Gose without too much gimmick.\xa0307 charactersRi0, Sep 19, 2015", "2.94/5\xa0\xa0rDev -13.5%look: 3.25 | smell: 3 | taste: 3 | feel: 2.75 | overall: 2.75Thanks to Don & Tom for this one!

Pours a pale gold, bright clarity, rising carb trails. Thin layer of compact foam, breaks apart quickly, leaving behind minimal lacing.

Aroma is faintly smoky and grainy, a little odd. Maybe this is more of a Lichtenhainer?

Grainy and watery, odd twang and a light smoky note. Light astringency and honeyish malt. Thin bodied, doesn't have much punch to it. Not all that tart, and not much if any coriander/salt presence. It's ok but ultimately doesn't really coalesce.\xa0506 charactersemerge077, Sep 29, 2014"]

name: El Grito Göse Lager
review: ['3.78/5\xa0\xa0rDev +1.3%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 4 | overall: 3.75the lager aspect of this is what makes it intriguing to me, there are enough lightly tart gose types with lime juice in the wrld now, but i am unaware of any that has been lagered like this. perhaps soured in the traditional way and then only fermented with lager yeast? maybe just extended time in the fermenter at cold temperature when the ale yeast was close to finished. either way, i think its a success, although i could take a little more yeast character in this, if its a lager strain, its awfully light, and lost largely to the acidity and lime, but there is a nice crispness to this. at the same time though, if i didnt know it was lagered, i might just appreciate it as a crisp and dry example of the style without really knowing it, its not obvious unless i really think about it. i like how fresh the lime is, and how reserved the salt is, it lets this stay light and natural and simple, more drinkable than many, which is awesome with these summery session type flavors. not too sour either, and clean in that regard, with some very light fresh wheat and pils type malts in here supporting. overall a well made beer, i think its unique process should be more obvious in the flavor, not just the feel, but its a cool thought and i hope to see more of it in kettle sours moving forward!\xa01,298 charactersStonedTrippin, Oct 01, 2018']

name: Jose the Rose Gose
review: ['3.75/5\xa0\xa0rDev -4.3%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.75we had fun with this one, a really spritzy gose type, stronger than most in this category, brewed with grapes from what i understand, but doesnt have much color to it, just hazy and pale and without a lot of head hanging around but with plenty of carbonation. it smells funky too, more wild than a normal lacto souring, some cool tang and straw and harvest elements, salty too, drying and briney in the finish, intensely flavored but rather complex and unique too. light cheesiness like their other wilds had, and some grapey brightness, good acidity, floral like hibiscus or something too but very natural, not overdone. the fruit is well fermented out here, its refreshing to me and not all that winey, despite some cool white type grape tang. fun stuff, like their others i had a little less refined than it could be in my opinion, but something cohesive and unique enough. good carbonation, weird yeast mix, subtle on the grapes. i bet this will age pretty well as it dries out even more and the funkiness comes out...\xa01,022 charactersStonedTrippin, Apr 24, 2018']

name: Brawndo Thirst Mutilator
review: ['4.1/5\xa0\xa0rDev -4.2%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4 | overall: 4Pours a clear green with a huge very pale green head that recedes to a ring and leaves no lacing. Smells slightly sour with some wheat and lime. Tastes of lemon, lime, wheat medium sourness and a hint of sweetness. Think Gatorade with sour gummy worms. Light bodied, medium carbonation, medium tartness with a dry but not puckering, mouth feel.\xa0348 charactersEMH73, Oct 30, 2019', '4.21/5\xa0\xa0rDev -1.6%look: 3.75 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4Pours a clear yellow with hardly a head on it. Gives off a lemon Gatorade kinda smell. This is one of the most sourest beers I’ve ever had. Very quick to make you pucker up.\xa0175 charactersThe_Snow_Bird, Feb 10, 2018', "4.38/5\xa0\xa0rDev +2.3%look: 5 | smell: 4.5 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.5 | overall: 4.25I mean, you get what you get with a gatorade inspired sour beer. But on the bright side, it's got electrolytes, and as we all know, that's what plants crave!! It looks like it tastes, which is a good thing in this case.\xa0219 charactersjoemochas, Jan 23, 2017"]

name: Never Never Giveup Giveup
review: ['4.65/5\xa0\xa0rDev +10.2%look: 4.75 | smell: 4.75 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4.75 | overall: 4.75Really thick and murky purple color with pink head. Aroma is full on passion fruit and forest berry yogurt. Taste follows with berry yogurt and passion fruit on top, tart, milky and smooth. Medium plus body with medium carbonation. Spicy berries with pits on the aftertaste. Excellent fruit sour.\xa0296 charactersCiocanelu, Mar 02, 2019']

name: Subterranean Exoskeleton
review:
['2.89/5\xa0\xa0rDev -25.7%look: 3.5 | smell: 3.25 | taste: 2.75 | feel: 3 | overall: 2.5Not sure what was going on here. I know the description said black gose, but pour was a dirty brown, minimal fruit on the nose which was dominated by coffee, and the flavor was just sour coffee. Possible infection, drain pour\xa0225 charactersVeganUndead, Jun 24, 2019', "3.89/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4.25 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.5In respect to the brewer, I ended up adding this as a gose, however, from the numerous amounts of goses I have had in my own life (observations and experiences with German brewers and judges) this is not a true gose.
This was poured into a stange.
The appearance was a mild brown to dark purple color with a sturdy semi-rocky cap of an off white foamy head softly dissipating to leave some messy lace.
The aroma captured some sweet to tart blueberry and plum up front with a subtle assembly of sour cherries and milk sugar/creamy vanilla in the background.
The flavor has a great salt level playing with some sour cherries, blueberries, subtle dark chocolate and milk sugar. Sticky aftertaste of cherries, dark chocolate and milk sugar.
The mouthfeel was about medium bodied. Some sessionability to it but also, not too much. Good carbonation. Nice ABV. Salty and cherry to slightly dark chocolate -like finish.
Overall, I liked for me, but you're lead astray if you think this is a gose. Where's the soured wheat? Still, it's brewed well enough want to reach for again.\xa01,070 charactersLone_Freighter, Apr 13, 2019"]

name: Cannonball Lime Gose with Sea Salt
review:
['3.79/5\xa0\xa0rDev -1.8%look: 3.75 | smell: 4 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.75I didn't have an appropriate beer for #WatermelonWednesday but I still wanted to #BumptheHump with something fruity, but not sweet. It helped that this one came along in furtherance of The CANQuest (tm), so it ain't all bad. 

From the CAN: "The Place Where We Drink"; "Drink Local"; "Cannonball is a bright and thirst-quenching sour wheat ale based on the top-fermented beers originally brewed in Goslar, Germany. Unlike the traditional version, we've added bright and intense limes to balance the briny and savory notes from the sea salt."

I will cop to agitating the CAN before Crack!ing open its vent. It was identified as "unfiltered" & since a Gose CAN have haziness to cloudiness, I was not wrong in so doing. I also went with an inverted Glug just to ensure that things were fully in suspension. It worked out well as I got two fingers of dense, foamy, rocky, bone-white head that stuck around briefly & became mere wisps. Man, the nose was evident from the outset - loads of lime, plenty of salt & a slight funk. Phew! Mouthfeel was medium. The taste was more tart than sour, but the saltiness was definitely present as was the lime citrusiness. My lips were puckering and smacking in response. Mmm. Like tone77, Gose is not my go-to style, but this was quite pleasant to drink. Finish was very dry, quite salty and with the lime addition, it just made me ready for a beer (or a glass of water). Phew!\xa01,411 characterswoodychandler, Feb 28, 2018', "3.59/5\xa0\xa0rDev -7%look: 4 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.5A thanks to the founding father of the canquest, woodychandler, for this beer. Poured from a 12 oz. can. Has a golden color with a 1/2 inch head. Smell is strong of limes. Taste is limes, a bit sour, light salt. Feels medium bodied in the mouth and overall, I'm not a fan of this style, but this one ain't bad.\xa0310 characterstone77, Jan 17, 2018", '4.06/5\xa0\xa0rDev +5.2%look: 4 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4Manayunk Brewing Co. "Cannon Ball"
12 fl. oz. can without production codes or freshness dating
$1.83 @ Weis Market, Conshohocken, PA

Notes via stream of consciousness: Hazy golden and amber body with a bit of a brass sheen beneath a short head of bright white that drops quickly, although that's entirely expected for the style, so all OK there. The aroma clearly exhibits lime, and it's salty as well... or did Jimmy Buffet just walk by? Kidding. It's quite pleasant and makes you want to take a sip. The flavor follows and it's not nearly as tart as some versions, which in my mind is much more of what a Gosebier is supposed to be, or at least was. There's some lightly wheaty malt to it as well, which is something that's also often misplaced in the production of a modern day Gosebier. The salt remains, and gives it another component although it's still very much a one-trick pony. It's actually fairly salty too, whereas in some versions it can be quite faint. So what else to say? Refreshing. Medium-light in body and moderately crisp. What's the alcohol on this? 4.1? Yeah, I could drink a few of these given a lot of idle time while on a camping trip or day out fishing - and ha!, could there be a better lawnmower beer?! One of the better designed American Gosebiers I've had. Nicely done!\xa01,301 charactersNeroFiddled, Jul 24, 2017']

name: Hidden Pickle
review:
['4.12/5\xa0\xa0rDev +16.1%look: 4 | smell: 4.5 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4Poured from the bottle into a Flying dog goblet glass.

Real nice golden lemon body color, with a hint of brass darkness to it. Fluffy topped light white head, fine in bubbles, settling to a good but small crowned puck.

Oh this is cool on the nose. Definitely copious amounts of dill, with touches of briney pickle and matching salty character. Faint sense of mild lacto/funky like character in the mix as well, very neat aroma and mouthwatering as well. Pickle fans will be happy.

Palate is less of a surprise. Light but solid malt chewy body. Faint touches of light salt, mixing with a slightly lighter touch of pickle juice, and more actual malt sweetness. Finishes with a good amount of dill and a light wheat density of bread.

A pretty good solid flavored gose, with the pickle angle a good addition, but is not overly strong or blown out.\xa0854 charactersSmakawhat, Nov 19, 2019', '3.25/5\xa0\xa0rDev -8.5%look: 3.5 | smell: 2.75 | taste: 3.25 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.5Looks similar to pickle juice, I guess. The aroma is god awful, like the pickles have gone bad......Taste, on the other hand is not that bad. Great pickle flavor and the tartness is exception. def will get the acid reflux active but I actually enjoyed the taste and surprisingly clean, refreshing finish\xa0303 charactershophugger, Nov 04, 2019', "3.5/5\xa0\xa0rDev -1.4%look: 3 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.5(12 oz bottle, enjoy by 01.27.20; purchased single off shelf... decanted into fat tulip)

L: crystal-clear, yellow-amber liquid; fleeting white foam on pour... after the head/collar all but vanishes, added the bottle dregs, giving the liquid a murky haze, cat's eye glow; did some flecks of ground spice make it through?

S: moderate pickle spicing apparent: dill, mustard, coriander - intensity of the spicing seems to diminish rather quickly, but never completely disappears... from the start, the underlying wheat pokes out a little; as the spicing fades, the overall 'gose' aromas (coriander), which were almost entirely buried, do rise up enough to where it does smell like a gose with a lil something extra; but the aromas are altogether relatively muddled

T: gose-forward flavors upon first sip, spicy coriander and a medium lactic bite in its finish... 'peppery' note partly mustard seed-derived?, (dried) dill in the back a bit... nutty, bread-crusty wheat malt swell in the finish, which lingers in the aftertaste, really relatively malty at its core... moderately salty; begs for a more sharp tang, more pop and zest to its spices

F: subtle shallow plush wave in its body up front, washing out quietly with a tiny tart touch and heat in its finish... wakes up the palate a little, has a nice enough dryness - perhaps I should've sipped this at a colder temp, as the carbonation is weak

O: at least to me, a brilliant flavor concept for a gose, but still expresses core gose flavors at its fore... flavorful, but not very dynamic - playing it safe or just on the decline?... I may be willing to grab a sixer, but they might be a bit aged by now, eh? (1578)\xa01,669 charactersBouleboubier, Oct 14, 2019", '4.16/5\xa0\xa0rDev +17.2%look: 4 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4 | overall: 4This beer is quite refreshing with the Gose/salt to leave a very clean finish. Dill aroma and flavor is noticed but not overpowering. Very mild tart and not sour at all. Good 1 and done summer beer, but not sure Dill flavored beers are very sessionable.\xa0259 charactersbubseymour, Jun 08, 2019']

name: Gosuhhh, Dude? Pineapple/Cherry
review: ['3.98/5\xa0\xa0rDev -2.2%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 4Tasted in a Rastal Teku from a one pint can on August 25, 2018. Look is cherry red with a thin head. Smell and taste is sweetened fruit. Feel is less tart than it should be.\xa0173 charactersHopheadjeffery, Aug 27, 2018']

name: Boldly Gose
review:
['3.59/5\xa0\xa0rDev -7.7%look: 3.25 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.5Look - Golden in color, transparent, and a small head with some retention.
Smell - mostly malts in the smell, with a bit of tartness that is complemented by light fruit flavors (berries).
Taste - malty, light tartness, and a bit salty. Pretty typical Gose in terms of taste, and quite refreshing.
Feel - light bodied, high in carbonation, and low in ABV.
Overall - this one is nothing to write home about, but is a nice and refreshing Gose that is true to its style. The blackberry flavors as advertised are not too pronounced, but the beer is still able to display its own distinct flavors.\xa0591 charactersProfundobaso, Oct 10, 2019', "4.04/5\xa0\xa0rDev +3.9%look: 4 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4 | overall: 4Blackberry-tinged variant of Gose.

Pours a medium amber color. Nose has a bit a blackberry to it, and some salt and yeasty notes, as well. Tastes a tad of blackberry, moderate saltiness, just a bit sour -- really a nice, refreshing combination for summer fare. Mouthfeel is light and crisp, but not overly carbonated. All in all, it's a well-balanced take on the Gose style, and one I'll seek again when I can. I've had some other fruit/floral Goses and have decided they seem to be a pretty good idea!\xa0514 charactersPsychromatic, Jul 16, 2018"]

name: Thai Lime Gose
review:
['3.96/5\xa0\xa0rDev -0.5%look: 3.75 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 4On tap at Vermont Tap House.
The appearance was a light straw yellow color with a fair transparency about it. No head and no lace.
The aroma had a nice sweet to sour lime pulp up front and then playing with a "sour-ed wheat" portion and then some saltiness.
The flavor was moderately sour with a good puckering trying to stifle the lime notes, but honestly the more I sipped the more I thought that the lime felt strongly about coming out to want to play more with the taste. Slight aftertaste of the sour-ed wheat and salt, lime steered away in this department.
The mouthfeel was between light and medium bodied with a great sessionability about it. Carbonation felt fine. ABV was 3% and actually felt like that. The finish was somewhat salty.
Overall, pretty nice gose done with a Switchback sort of twist. I like the idea and they did a nice twist with this.\xa0861 charactersLone_Freighter, Oct 08, 2017', "4.06/5\xa0\xa0rDev +2%look: 3.75 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 4L - light and straw colored. Typical gose, but without any sort of haze. 

S - salt and funk. 

T - salty lime! I sorta get the Thai Asian feel. Lip puckering goodness. Nailed the flavor profile. 

F - light and floaty. Nothing special here. Crisp bubbles. 

O - probably the favorite of the six beers we had. It's very different from the others and a nice outward excursion into wildness.\xa0389 charactersagreenman19, Aug 13, 2015"]

name: Guava Gose
review: ['3.56/5\xa0\xa0rDev +1.7%look: 3.25 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.25 | overall: 3.5Saint Archers Guava Gose pours a very hazy light gold with a thin white head. Little to no head retentive which is not abnormal for the style. There is a hint of the guava in the aroma but mostly just the salt and wheat. On the taste the carbonation and tart take the front seat with the salt and coriander taking the back seat. Refreshing on a hot Las Vegas day.\xa0363 charactersBrolegario, May 20, 2018', '3.75/5\xa0\xa0rDev +7.1%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.75Slightly cloudy light golden yellow pour with a foamy white head. Tart guava and salt aroma. Taste is salty with a briney quality and a tart guava fruit presence.\xa0162 charactersKaribourgeois, May 16, 2018', "2.35/5\xa0\xa0rDev -32.9%look: 3 | smell: 3 | taste: 2 | feel: 2 | overall: 2.25Just... don't. Can hardly detect any guava here, but there's a pinch on the nose if you really use your imagination. Flavor is meh, and has that same taste that most mass-produced goses now have. Body is just as bland and disappointing. As a fan of the style, I try a new one whenever I see it. More often that not, however, I'm let down, and this was no exception.\xa0365 charactersalextastic, May 15, 2018", '3.68/5\xa0\xa0rDev +5.1%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.5The beer pours out a pale golden straw color, with a thin white head------------ the aromas are of wheat, tartness, guava, grass and salt--------------- the flavors are of over ripe guava, salt and wheat, the beer has a thin mouthfeel with a salty tart finish-------------- overall this is a nice fruited gose, light and refreshing with some funky over ripe fruit coming through\xa0378 charactersdertyd, Apr 26, 2018']

name: Salty Lips
review:
['3.03/5\xa0\xa0rDev -19.6%look: 3.5 | smell: 3 | taste: 3 | feel: 3 | overall: 3Poured into a tasting glass at the brewery. What is not noted in the name/description is this is a pickle gose.

A: A light golden color with some nice lacing. Head was hard to determine on the pour.

S: Believe it or not, dill pickle smell! Pickle mixes with some sourness and maybe a bit of the salt. Mostly pickle smells though.

T: Tartness up front with...you guessed it, dill pickle flavors. There is some slight tart fruit mixed in, but the pickle is the overwhelming flavor. A bit of yeast and salt mix with the pickle to give a dry tart puckering finish.

M: Light, good carbonation, dry.

O: Ok, this was a first. Interesting beer, not one I would get again and not one I could finish an entire pint glass of. Thank god for the tasting glass. Sorry Cape May, love lots of your beers, not this one.\xa0822 charactersKadonny, Aug 16, 2016']

name: Lychee Tangerine Gose
review: ["3.8/5\xa0\xa0rDev -5.7%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.75Hazy bright straw yellow color with a bit of white foam. Aroma is lactic, slightly mineral but also fruity. Taste starts sour with lots of lemon notes but also quite salty. Light, dry, effervescent body. It's quite good but I would have liked more intense fruit flavors.\xa0270 charactersCiocanelu, Jan 13, 2017", '3.82/5\xa0\xa0rDev -5.2%look: 3 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4500 mL bottle. Hazy pale yellow. No head. Smells of tangerine, wheat, and lychee. I’m amazed that I actually recognize lychee. Tastes pretty sour. Sour lemon and orange. Wheat. Lychee comes through as an aftertaste. Light body with a moderate sourness. Nice.\xa0260 charactersAlieniloquium, Dec 16, 2016']

name: Mango Pineapple Popsicle
review:
["4.46/5\xa0\xa0rDev +1.1%look: 4.25 | smell: 4.5 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.5L: Had this beer on-tap at The Answer Brewpub, poured into a snifter glass. Had a bright orange color and a thick, opaque consistency. There was little to no head or lacing. Looked a lot like orange juice.

S: A super-enticing aroma of pineapple, mango, salt, wheat, and citrus.

T: Tasted of a hint of wheat (mostly in the finish - and not much of it), light sea salt notes, a bit of citrus (orange, in particular), and lots of tropical fruit (mango, pineapple). A dynamic, fruity, and fairly tart flavor. It's not as complex as other beers, but it's incredibly focused and quite flavorful.

F: A below average amount of carbonation with a smooth, lively finish. Light-bodied.

O: A wholly enjoyable version of a gose. Very much a drinkable beer.\xa0747 charactersavalon07, Mar 04, 2018"]

name: Gosefish
review: ['3.74/5\xa0\xa0rDev -3.9%look: 4 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.75hibiscus and cranberry in this one, and i think their gluten free motif works a little better in this sour ale context with the adjuncts than it did in their belgian wit, but i think its cool that they are bringing these kinds of styles to the gluten free folks. i assume this one is as well. its got a nice rose pink color, but not much head. the aroma is cool, not overdone with either of the additives, but both really come through naturally. the hibiscus is more tropical than floral or perfumey, and the cranberry contributes a mouthwatering tartness and juiciness that melds well with the bacterial sourness in this. the flavor is like that too, good balance between the interesting elements, well paired, and maybe some rice or something in the base here, a grounding sort of starchiness to it, passable for raw wheat or something more conventionally found in the style. i like this having a little body, way more than their wit had, it feels right for the style. still a little lighter on carbonation than i want it to be, but overall a really cool beer that i might choose even though i am fine with gluten, a very high compliment for one of these indeed. the cranberry is awesome at the end, the hibiscus isnt overdone, and the sourness is clean. good job with this, if i was a gluten free person i would be so stoked that these guys exist...\xa01,352 charactersStonedTrippin, Oct 05, 2018']

name: Endless Ride - Mango & Apricot
review: ['3.78/5\xa0\xa0rDev -4.5%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 4 | overall: 3.758/11/18...bright orange gold with light foam. Thick visual. Fruity nose, tropical. Slight sour. Fruity. Quick, not tart. Heavier tilt to the mango. Very nice;.\xa0159 charactersKTCamm, Sep 03, 2018']

name: Smash
review:
['3.63/5\xa0\xa0rDev -9.3%look: 4.5 | smell: 4 | taste: 3.25 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.75A: pour a very hazy apricot - thick like apple cider.

S: good smell of sour and crushed fruits

T: big burst of hazy citrus and puckering sour. Not as salty as expected and left some aftertaste.

M: A little bigger than a typical gose.

Seems like they were going for the Gose but still have a lot of the haze they’re known for.\xa0331 charactersRyanPoff, Nov 24, 2018']

name: To 11
review:
['4.5/5\xa0\xa0rDev +5.6%Appearance - The Gose was a cloudy golden yellow color with a modest white head.

Smell - The beer smells like a wheat beer for the most part, but you are really able to get the salt and sour in the aroma. Wow.

Taste - On the initial taste, I detect lemon before the saltiness comes in. It is truly amazing as it is salt in liquid form, but it will not give you sodium overload. Toward the back, the sour ntes become more apparent. In a sentence, this is liquid salted wheat with a sour aftertaste. Delicious!

Mouthfeel - The mouthfeel runs fairly thin as the style should. It leaves a nice sour coating on the tongue.

Overall - When I left the pub, I made sure I told the brewers how good this gose is. If this was bottled or canned, I might never have to trade for Westbrook again.\xa0786 charactersJohnnyHopps, Aug 17, 2014']

name: LMFAgOse
review:
['4.09/5\xa0\xa0rDev +3.5%look: 3.75 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4 | overall: 4Appearance - Pours deep pink color with nice white head that dissipates quickly. Not much lacing.

Aroma - Light tart fruit aroma, blueberry and strawberry the watermelon seems to be light and on the end. 

Taste - Nice tart blueberry and juicy melon. It has a puckering flavor but not over the top. The watermelon again is at the end along with something else maybe honeydew. There is saltiness for sure on the finish which works great with the tart fruit.

Feel - light bodied well carbonated pretty dry finish and tart.

Overall - A well done gose great fruit flavors and well balanced.\xa0589 charactersDragginballs76, May 29, 2017', "4.18/5\xa0\xa0rDev +5.8%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.25Pours a clear and transparent, very light, blue-hued pink color, with decent effervescence and a finger of blue-tinted, fizzy white head that's very quick to dissipate into a thin crown.

I actually got a big blast of watermelon aroma when I cracked the can -- which is weird, because I don't think of watermelons as being particularly pungent. 

When I stick my snout into it, it's definitely very tart, with a hint of blueberry underneath, and what I'll call an expectation of saltiness.

Wow. There's some muddled light melon and blueberry up front, a wonderful tangy tartness mid-palate, a little kiss of salt and the some mild blueberry tartness in the aftertaste. Really nice mix of flavors. It actually sort of bounces back and forth between the watermelon and the blueberry each time I sip it. The saltiness also grows over time, with a definite soft, sea salt quality to it. 

It has a surprisingly slick mouthfeel, with the tartness and salt making it just a little puckering, too.

This is just a great gose, with the fruit complementing the classic flavors perfectly and not at all overdone. Canned on 10/21/16.\xa01,130 charactersthebeers, May 01, 2017", "3.87/5\xa0\xa0rDev -2%look: 4 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 4 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.75Pours a reddish orange, with a thin layer of foam. 
Smells like vague fruity mixed berry kool-aid, blueberry sure. 
Moderately tart, verging on sour. Some berry flavors, mixed berry bubblegum, kool-aid, vaguely savory but not salty.
Light bodied with ample carbonation at first that ebbs away slightly over time. Overall it's fairly quenching but doesn't really grab much attention. Kettle-sours can only go so far, the added fruit here sounded good but just reminds me of fruit punch.

The name of this beer reminds me of an old Kids in the Hall skit with Scott Thompson...\xa0574 charactersemerge077, Nov 22, 2016"]

name: A Nice Slice
review:
["3.78/5\xa0\xa0rDev -0.8%look: 4 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 4 | overall: 4Pours a clear effervescent light straw color. Thin spritzy white head dissipates almost immediately. Rather effervescent. 

Aroma is light and barley there, but notes of wheat, slight tart lime, and some grains. 

Taste follows the nose with some lightly tart wheat and grain notes. A touch of lime and graham cracker comes through. Im not getting much cinnamon. The vanilla does come through as the beer warms. Its not very tart at all - it just kind of teases you with tartness, but lacks any assertiveness. A touch of sweetness pervades the flavor profile, but it is not overly sweet. 

Feel is light and drinkable. Quite refreshing. 

Overall this is one of those beers that is solid, but with some tweaking and refinement it could be great. I'd love to see more tartness with the lime taking a more prominent role in the profile. As it is, I look forward to revisiting this one again over the summer.\xa0905 charactersFBarber, Jan 28, 2019"]

name: Tropical Gose
review: ['4/5\xa0\xa0rDev -7.6%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4teamwiggum, Aug 19, 2018', '4.37/5\xa0\xa0rDev +0.9%look: 4 | smell: 4.5 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4 | overall: 4.25DigitGrowler, May 21, 2018', '4.5/5\xa0\xa0rDev +3.9%look: 4.5 | smell: 4.5 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4.5 | overall: 4.5kybeerdrinker, Apr 13, 2018', '4.17/5\xa0\xa0rDev -3.7%look: 4.25 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4 | overall: 4.25crbnfbr, Dec 04, 2017', '4.96/5\xa0\xa0rDev +14.5%look: 4.75 | smell: 5 | taste: 5 | feel: 4.75 | overall: 5skibb, Oct 16, 2017', '4.06/5\xa0\xa0rDev -6.2%look: 4 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4scottspencer, Sep 30, 2017', '4.25/5\xa0\xa0rDev -1.8%look: 4.25 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.25kylehay2004, Sep 23, 2017']

name: Barn Phantom Gose With Blueberries
review:
['3.88/5\xa0\xa0rDev -2.8%look: 4 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4Aroma is sweet blueberry liquor and mild cough syrup. The flavor is blueberries, fruit, mild salt, malts/wheat and a medium tart/slightly sweet finish.\xa0152 charactersjzlyo, Jul 14, 2018', '3.54/5\xa0\xa0rDev -11.3%look: 4.5 | smell: 3 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 4 | overall: 3.75Russell and Richard of the Lafayette Beer League make beer review videos. Check out our videos of Barn Phantom Gose with Blueberries. 

Talking about Beer: Triton Brewing Barn Phantom Blueberries
https://youtu.be/Z8Cm2mx8ihc\xa0224 charactersLafayette_Beer_League, Jun 08, 2018', '3.6/5\xa0\xa0rDev -9.8%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.5not a bad beer, but i didnt find the blueberry flavor to be very natural tasting in here. its like blueberry candy, or the blueberry syrup you can put in your pancakes at dennys. its a shame too, because its really potent and lingers long here, interrupting but not quite ruining a really pretty solid base gose. the lactic profile is clean enough here, its not too sour to drink a fair amount of, and the salt aspect is just right, briny but bright, full of flavor. the wheat base is very light, but this doesnt feel watery, and its quite well carbonated. i thought this about the mango version too, but if you took the fake and overdosed tasting fruit out of these, you would have a really nice gose on its own. to me the blueberry has a light metallic element and a lot of sweetness, and the level is high, its forced it seems, and it sort of cheapens the whole thing. i have a had a lot of excellent fruited goses now, and in my opinion, subtle fruit accenting the subtle flavors of the base beer is the way to go, and this one is way over the top. they couldnt have used real blueberries for this could they have?\xa01,118 charactersStonedTrippin, Oct 25, 2017', '4.37/5\xa0\xa0rDev +9.5%look: 4 | smell: 4.5 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4 | overall: 4.25Pours bright magenta with a bubblegum-pink head that disappears quickly and a subtle (not "fake" smelling) blueberry scent. Not overly tart, although surprisingly carbonated. Up front it could be regular Barn Phantom until the blueberry shyly comes out and lingers in the aftertaste. A good session pick for sour lovers.\xa0322 charactersHotSelma, May 15, 2017']

name: Gose To Mexico And All I Got Was This Lousy Shirt
review:
["3.73/5\xa0\xa0rDev +1.9%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.7512oz Can

Canned: 4/21/16

Big thanks to Mark for passing one of these along one day last week! Thanks!Gose to Mexico...is one of the most vibrantly colored beers I have ever seen. As a matter of fact it looks like red Kool Aid, it's that bright. Good clarity runs throughout as carbonation streams to the surface from a from a few spots at glass bottom. A crackling, active foam rises to a finger in height on the pour, it's also tinted red, but eventually fades a a surface skimming. Interesting looking beer, this is.

It's funny, with a vibrant color I can't help but expect something different in the nose but what I get is gose all the way with a backend fruity tartness. Tangy, soured wheat leads it off and is the star of this show. A touch of ground coriander pops up in the middle before the additions come in. Wet stone and a softly metallic character, iron mostly, come through thanks to the addition of lacto while the prickly pear adds a soft, yet unspecific, fruity sweetness. A little popcorn-y with a touch of diacetyl.

That wheat twang hits off the bat, slightly soured and delicious. Faint coriander runs the middle along with hard water. Some of that minerality and wet stone comes into play again on the palate, and I like it. The salt kicks in on the finish, nice and even handed. There is a touch of diacetyl here and there but it tends to clear up as the beer warms. Again, the prickly pear brings some vague fruity sweetness, and a little earthiness, to the finish. 

The body sits squarely between light and moderate with a zippy carbonation that keeps the whole moving. There is a coating quality to this beer which is odd for such a light body. A little tartness hits the sides and back of the tongue. Honestly, it leaves a film of sorts after each drink. It's easily drinkable and highly refreshing but that film kind of throws me a bit.

Gose to Mexico... is a good beer from the folks at Hailstorm and Arrowhead. It's bright and refreshing. A good summer sipper for sure and the 6-pack format doesn't hurt either. A touch tart, a touch fruity, and salty enough to get your salivary glands working in anticipation of the next sip. Certainly worth a shot.\xa02,186 charactersjoe1510, May 01, 2016"]

name: Salz Weizen Gose
review:
['3.89/5\xa0\xa0rDev +15.1%look: 2.75 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 4 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4I am so thankful to have supporters of The CANQuest (tm) like my people in Altoona! They inquired of me as to whether I had gotten any of Riepstine's Pub's CANned beers & when I replied that I had recently reviewed the IPA, they sent me some of the others, including this one. That's pretty cool! Also, many thanks to this site for an almost-immediate approval of the pic. 

From the CAN: "'Where It's All About The Beer!'"

The CANQuest (tm) is really shifting gears now! If you look at my reviews, I have gone from APAs to AIPAs to DIPAs and now I am getting ready to segue into a bunch of beers from the same brewer (a horizontal), but I need to lead up to it first.

The Crack! opened onto yet another brimful craft CAN and I could not CANtain my excitement. An inverted Glug and my glass began rapidly filling with a CANbination of liquid & foam to the point that I felt CANpelled to back off. Settling, I was left with two fingers of foamy, bone-white head with decent retention. Color was a cloudy Yellow-Gold (SRM = 4 - 5). Nose smelled of sea salt and I am speaking from experience. I put in 15.25 years in the US Navy before taking early retirement and 9.5 of that was aboard four different ships. Sea spray/sea salt has an unmistakable scent that is completely unlike common iodized table salt. Standing in the bow, getting the spray in your face, in your nostrils & in your sinuses is a smell that will always linger. The coriander gave it a flowery, black pepper bite. Mouthfeel was medium-to-full, much bigger in the mouth than I anticipated. The taste was salty, as advertised. Hoo boy, was it salty! Ever been swimming in the ocean and gotten a mouthful of water? That's what this was like. It was saturated with sea salt. I wonder if the Germans brew it with this much salt. It was like gargling with salt water. Finish was dry (duh!), salty and immensely refreshing. The low ABV makes it a definite CANdidate for the summer cooler and CANbined with its thirst-quenching nature, it would be great during the summer. The only CANcern would be the taste. I do not mind salt, but it may not be for everyone.\xa02,121 characterswoodychandler, Jan 29, 2016', "4.25/5\xa0\xa0rDev +25.7%look: 3.5 | smell: 4.75 | taste: 4 | feel: 5 | overall: 4Poured into a standard pint glass: color is gold, head is brighter white but dissipates quickly to a feint ring.

Smell is near brine with some fresh cracked coriander and a touch of biscuit - gose all the way.

Taste is a little tart, then saltiness overtakes this brew - one of the few goses' I've had where you can actually taste the salt, which i think is the intention of the brew. Coriander is pleasant and near freshness. 

Mouthfeel is crisp, sharp, tart and extremely full - again what I envision when thinking of a salty beer with sourness.

Overall - a gose that seems to push near what I have read about actual gose style but still a bit too much sourness, but the salt level is way more noticeable than most other examples. The mouthfeel seems to be where the style is in my head tart and strong saltiness.\xa0819 charactersmvanaskie13, Nov 30, 2013"]

name: Sweetgrass Local 7 Session Gose
review:
["3.55/5\xa0\xa0rDev -2.7%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 3.25 | overall: 3.5Local 7 Session Gose is a beer so pale it's nearly colourless. Later on, after the sediment is introduced, it looks beige and has the complexion of wet sand. It has such a faded, almost bleached tone that you'd think it was left in the sun for a month. A light effervescence is the only sign of life. 

Only after it warms up considerably is there any evidence of coriander on the nose. Such an aromatic ingredient aught to be more apparent, or so I'd like it to be. There's also nothing in the bouquet to indicate the style's patented sourness either. Everything so far is very subdued. 

There's enough protein in this grain bill to muddy-up the complexion but not to weigh down the mouthfeel. This drinks as light as it looks, with delicate apricot and orange zest flavours and only a light, fleeting trace of coriander. Many sips taste of stale grain resembling dry bread or plain crackers.

Too much salt is worse than too little, granted, but this really lacks in that saline/mineral presence that distinguishes the style. Same goes for the characteristic sourness; this recipe doesn't offer nearly enough of that salty/sour interplay that makes Gose so incredibly refreshing. 

If you ask me, Local 7 Session Gose was brewed with too gentle a hand and isn't exactly true to style. Its somewhat tequila-like floral and citrus notes are pleasant but don't make up for the lack of spice, salt and sourness that define the style. Mind you, these judgements are reflective of personal preference.\xa01,500 charactersbiegaman, Jul 24, 2015"]

name: Anything Gose
review:
["3.69/5\xa0\xa0rDev +2.2%look: 3.5 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.25 | overall: 3.75330 mL bottle picked up at the LCBO; best before 01/12/2018, which hopefully translates to Dec 1 and not Jan 12. Served slightly chilled and reviewed from notes.

This gose has a lightly hazed, goldenrod-coloured body, capped off with one finger of sparkling white foam that proceeds to fizzle away within a couple of minutes. A ring of froth continues to cling to the perimeter, but there's nary a smudge of lace to be seen. The aroma is low-key yet inviting, with lemon rind and zestiness overlapping with some light lactic acidity. There are also faint suggestions of lime and lychee, as well as a salty, briney quality to the nose.

It tastes of bready, wheaty sweetness, with notes of grain husk, passion fruit and grapefruit coming through mid-sip alongside the aforementioned lemon-lime tartness. That lactic acid sourness is also present, but in a less potent and/or central capacity than in many of the other goses I've had, which may make this more approachable than most. Hints of berries, lime and coriander linger into the fruity, slightly salty aftertaste. Medium in body, with average carbonation levels that impart a small amount of crispness to what is otherwise a rather smooth, slick-feeling light ale. For that reason, this is not as refreshing as I tend to expect this style to be - though I suppose it's nearly as sessionable.

Final Grade: 3.69, a B grade. Black Isle's Anything Gose is good enough, but I don't think I'd call it great. The citra hops were a fine choice, with their citrusy, fruity qualities working out quite nicely, particularly on the nose. However, the sourness is definitely a bit lacking in intensity, and the mouthfeel is also not as spritzy and thirst-quenching as I'd prefer. Worth taking a flyer on; I enjoyed my two bottles and may be back for more, though I'm not in a big hurry to do so.\xa01,840 charactersthehyperduck, May 16, 2018", '3.52/5\xa0\xa0rDev -2.5%look: 3.25 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 3.25 | overall: 3.5330 ml bottle served cold into a pint glass. LCBO purchase for around $3.30 CDN. A Gose from Scotland? Gotta try this. Best before 01/12/2018. Not sure if this is December 1 or January 12. If January 12, please get your product here faster, I bought this less than a month ago.

Appearance - Pours a mildly hazy rich golden color, leaning more on the orange spectrum than yellow or green. A half finger of head rests on top and has some modest staying power.

Smell - Hints of lemon and something kind of sweet in behind, maybe a little like gooseberry or blueberry. Plenty of wheat in there as well and hints of coriander.

Taste - Hints of tartness, a touch sour, but overwhelmingly greainy with bits of lemon too. Not as tart nor as salty as many in the style, and has a little bit of fruity sweetness in play as well. Kind of like gose meets pale lager with a fruity sweetness in the finish. Interetsing and stuill refershing, but not quite as much as a traditional lemon forward gose is.

Mouthfeel - Medium-light bodied, good carbonation, a touch chalky on the finish.

Overall - Anything Gose, while a playful pun or words, is a fine attempt at a gose, but lacks a little bit extra salt and lemon bite to make this the thirst quenching brew it desires to be. While I really do like the fruity sweetness at the back end, I would probably pass on a second offering as many local goses are quite good right now.\xa01,415 characterstaxandbeerguy, May 09, 2018']

name: Spin Dive Summer Gose
review:
["3.8/5\xa0\xa0rDev -0.5%look: 3.5 | smell: 4 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.75473 ml can served cold into a tulip. LCBO purchase for $3 CDN. 

Appearance - Slightly hazy rich gold color capped with a finger of light fluffy white head. Modets retention and not much lacing.

Smell - Very fresh, with wheat, lemon and salt not surprisingly being present but what ups the game is the distinct lime aroma. Quite pleasant and a nice little twist.

Taste - Like the nose with wheat, lemon and lime showing through. Some pepper at the end and mild salt throughout. Pretty refreshing flavorwise. Flavors on the thin side, but doesn't hurt it much in this style.

Mouthfeel - Medium-light bodied, modest carbonation and salty finish. 

Overall - A pretty tasty and refreshing summer gose. The lime is a nice little addition and this is pretty easy to drink. Worth a try.\xa0783 characterstaxandbeerguy, Jun 02, 2018", '3.89/5\xa0\xa0rDev +1.8%look: 4 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 3.75This beer pours a hazy golden colour and the head is a frothy white.

The smell is fresh white bread, citrus hops, and a bit of lime. This transfers to the taste. There is a really nice tartness to this beer that I think reflects the sea salt, black pepper, and lime.

The beer is light bodied and the finish is quite smooth.

This would go well with nachos.\xa0358 charactersMichaelGennings, May 27, 2018', "3.49/5\xa0\xa0rDev -8.6%look: 3 | smell: 3.25 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.75473 mL can from the LCBO; dated Apr 5 2018 and served slightly chilled. Reviewed from notes.

Pours a lightly fogged golden-blonde colour, managing to generate a paltry half-centimetre of loose, soda-pop foam that quickly scatters. A paper thin collar is the only thing that sticks around for more than two minutes' time; no lacing, either. Falls a bit flat visually, and the aroma doesn't improve matters much - it's extremely faint, and remains that way even as the brew warms. I'm getting subtle notes of lemon, lime and wheat husk, and maybe some salty ocean air, but I can't convince myself that anything else is there.

Fortunately it does taste a fair bit better than it smells. Wheaty grain husk and some crackery pale malt sweetness provide the appropriate backup, with citrusy flavours of lime juice and lemony tartness coming through clearly by mid-sip. The lime almost seems to overtake or assume the role of any lactic acidity that may be present. Hints of black tea; it finishes with some lingering lemon-lime tartness, which give way to a salty aftertaste that takes a few moments to reveal its mild black pepper spiciness. Light in body, with moderately assertive carbonation that briskly prickles the palate, working nicely in conjunction with the peppercorn spiciness. Crisp and pretty refreshing, in addition to being very easy to toss back.

Final Grade: 3.49, a B-. Lake of Bays' Spin Dive Summer Gose is a better stab at this style than I expected it to be. The lime is a nice addition, blending seamlessly with the baseline salty-sourness of the gose style, and I am also partial to the black pepper notes that come through on the back end. A good beginner's gose; the low levels of lactic acidity (largely subsumed by the lime sourness) are unlikely to turn off the newbies. I'd recommend giving it a shot as soon as possible, while the cans are still fresh, instead of putting it off until August and taking your chances with old stock.\xa01,961 charactersthehyperduck, May 17, 2018", "4.75/5\xa0\xa0rDev +24.3%look: 4.75 | smell: 4.75 | taste: 4.75 | feel: 4.75 | overall: 4.75Straight up one of the best goses out of Canada. I've tried everything from Collective Arts to Leipzig to Westbrook to Wakefield to Trillium to this, and this is straight up one of the best goses to grace my tastebuds. Keep doing exactly this and you will succeed as a brewery.\xa0277 charactersStormAles, May 17, 2018"]

Lots of tart cherry, but a nice lactose sweetness to round things out. Very drinkable goes. Has a lime like citrus flavor as well.\xa0172 charactersmothman, Sep 05, 2018']

name: Blueberry Lime Gose
review:
["4.06/5\xa0\xa0rDev +2.5%look: 3.5 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4 | overall: 4.25Pours a dense, dark purple color with a thin, fizzy, purple-tinted head that's quick to dissipate. Zero lacing.

Sour, tart aroma with a definite blueberry quality and what's probably some pretty strong lime right underneath. It's very strong smelling and a little discordant at first.

The taste follows the nose. Big blueberry juice fruitiness at first, almost to the point of creaminess, followed by strong lime. It's very tart and definitely salty. 

Pretty heavy bodied for the style, with strong carbonation.

Man, I wish I had some Tex-Mex to go with this. A tequila-barrel aged version would be interesting. I might actually try a McGyvered version of that with my next pour. The salt and lime are coming on strong the more I drink it. Reminds me of a '90s grunge feedback loop. I like it.\xa0807 charactersthebeers, Apr 06, 2018"]

name: Pinch Of Salt
review:
['3.81/5\xa0\xa0rDev -5.7%look: 3.75 | smell: 4 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.75L- Somewhat hazy golden/yellow with small off-white head that dissipates quickly 
S – Lemon and yeast 
T – Lemon up front and throughout – but not overly sour or bitter, just light and crisp. Notes of sugar, yeast, and wheat on the back end. 
F – Light to medium bodied with a moderate amount of carbonation – crisp, light, refreshing 
O – A decent gose with some nice bright, crisp lemon notes\xa0406 charactersLifesAnesthesia, Jul 07, 2019', '4.02/5\xa0\xa0rDev -0.5%look: 3.5 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 4Since I spent a couple/few days celebrating CANada Day on 01 July, it only seems right & fitting to spent this four-day weekend drinking, reviewing & rating AmeriCAN-owned & made beers. I am beginning today with the theme of fruit-adjuncts. Cheers!

From the CAN: "Lemon Chiffon Gose"; "Test Your Taste". I will be reviewing this as a Leipzig Gose with a ChANge Request sent. 

I did some in-CAN CANgitation before Crack!ing open the vent so as to ensure that any flocculate was in suspension. Following the Crack!, I went with a heavy-handed Glug to form a rolling, fizzy, foamy, soapy finger of bone-white head that faded as quickly as I poured. Bye! Color was a slightly-hazy Straw-Yellow (SRM = > 2, < 4). Nose smelled like the way that Goses should always smell, IMHO! Salty & lemony, like lemonade out on the weatherdecks while underway. 

I was never a huge fan of the military lifestyle, but I LOVED getting underway! Nothing like it before or since & I would love to find some way to do a cruise again. The salt spray, the salt air, it was all a great feeling. We were not supposed to take food from the Mess Decks, but drinks were authorized. Coffee, iced tea, lemonade, all of it, usually out on the fantail, smoking cigars & telling sea stories of inport visits. Mmm, what a life! 

Mouthfeel was kinda thin & watery, but such is the nature of the style. CAN't dun them too hard as a result. The taste struck a VERY pleasant balance between salty and lemony-tartness. Both were easily discernible & quite tasty as a result. Finish was dry, as adding salt to beer is wont to do, never mind lemon juice! It was quite thirst-quenching on this hot, humid Summer's day, but one was satiating. YMMV.\xa01,707 characterswoodychandler, Jul 05, 2019']

name: Sunshine Gose
review:
['3.59/5\xa0\xa0rDev -10.3%look: 4 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.5Poured from a tallboy can into a Dogfish Head tulip

L: Clear light golden pour with 2 fingers of fluffy white head. Nice ring of lacing.

S: Tart and funky.. lemon and grains.

T.F: Follows the nose. Tart lemon and wheat. Grain and a bit of funk... some sea salt towards the finish. Light bodied and well carbonated. Easy drinking... with some citrus at the finish.

O: A solid Gose. Ticks most of the boxes for the style and very easy drinking. Great beer for a post-lawn mowing treat.\xa0498 charactersEMV, Jul 01, 2019']

name: Coconut Cream Pie Gose
review:
['4.08/5\xa0\xa0rDev -0.5%look: 4.25 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4Thanks goes out to Buck89 for this brew.

16 oz. Can
Canned On: 10/12/18

Poured into a Tree House glass a pretty nice cloudy pale yellow color, very nice carbonation, with a very nice thick/creamy/fizzy two-finger white head, which leaves some nice sticky lacing behind. The nose is malty, yeasty, with a nice little coriander note, coconut, some vanilla, tart. The taste is pretty nice, malty, yeasty, with a nice little coconut, coriander, tart, nice vanilla note. Medium body, ABV is hidden very nicely, with a nice little dry/bitter finish. Overall, a pretty tasty brew. Thanks John!\xa0588 charactersWasatch, Dec 06, 2018', "3.97/5\xa0\xa0rDev -3.2%look: 4.5 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4This flavor profile in a gose base doesn't work all that great at the front end, but the saltiness at the back is remarkably successful at pulling it all together. I'd say the marshmallows are clearly the most detectable of the adjuncts.

Really unique brew from this bunch.\xa0274 charactersThe_Mancannon_of_Slothrop, Oct 22, 2018", '4.16/5\xa0\xa0rDev +1.5%look: 3.75 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.2516 oz can poured into a snifter. Moderately hazy golden color with a modest white head. Some lacing. Aroma was heavy sweet coconut, vanilla, meringue, and slight lemon. Smooth coconut flavor initially on the palate, followed by a gentle lemony tartness. Vanilla and marshmallow were mixed in, with slight graham cracker. None of the flavors were overbearing and they all played well together. Clean and refreshing.\xa0414 charactersBuck89, Oct 19, 2018']

name: De Berry's Treasure
review:
["3.35/5\xa0\xa0rDev -4.8%look: 3.75 | smell: 3 | taste: 3.25 | feel: 4 | overall: 3.5600 mL bottle from the LCBO; dated Jun 11 2018 and served well chilled. 

Pours a translucent pinkish-apricot colour, along the lines of watermelon juice. One centimetre of loose, bubbly white head is produced atop, then proceeds to fall apart within two minutes' time; a frothy collar of bubbles sticks around afterwards, paired with a scant coat of lace. Smells quite vegetal, earthy, and a bit dirty... I'm getting an almost mushroom-like odour, punctuated by faint hints of raspberry and rhubarb. I was expecting a much fruitier aroma based on its appearance, so the oddness of the bouquet kind of threw me for a loop.

There's a lot going on here, and not all of it is complementary, so the first few sips left my taste buds a bit, um, disoriented. There some grainy malts and gritty, crackery wheat buried within the profile, but the rhubarb is what carries things along, remaining dominant through to the tail end of the sip. Suggestions of apricot and black plum come through, with hints of raspberry, blackberry and earthy pine resin finally surfacing at the finish, lasting on into a moderately fruity-sweet, weakly salty aftertaste. Slightly tannic quality, which I must assume is related to the black raspberry. Light-medium in body, with spritzy carbonation that sprightly tickles the surface of the palate, giving a bit of prickliness to this brew's generally smooth mouthfeel.

Final Grade: 3.35, a B-. De Berry's Treasure is a strange one - more of a fruit beer than a gose, with the sea salt playing a rather minor role overall (in comparison to the rhubarb and, to a lesser extent, the raspberry), and virtually no sourness whatsoever. I don't entirely dislike this beer, but its disparate flavours do not come together as cohesively as I'd hoped - I don't know if it's the hops and the rhubarb or what, but some aspects of the profile simply seem to clash in an unappealing way. I polished off my glass pretty easily, but I don't think this is something I'd buy again, or recommend.\xa02,001 charactersthehyperduck, Aug 17, 2018"]

name: Easy Gose
review: ["3.67/5\xa0\xa0rDev -2.7%look: 3.5 | smell: 4 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.75There's a very interesting - and rather intense - fruit aspect to the aroma. I do get a lot of salinity and coriander (though minimal sourness; it's not needed here), but I love the citrus character. The flavor is a little different. Coriander and vanilla cream opens it up, with lemon, saline, and lacto slowly sneaking onto the taste buds. Simple, but tasty. It feels light, fizzy, and a bit sticky from the lacto. Certainly, this is worth the time of any Gose lover. I love how sneaky the sourness is in particular.\n\n3.67/5: A damn good house gose; I'd buy it if I found it in 6 packs\xa0588 charactersThisWangsChung, Apr 26, 2016", "3.98/5\xa0\xa0rDev +5.6%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 4Pretty good gose. Salty enough to make a presence. Nice sour and tarty note in the taste and smell. Nice cloudy lemon color. Hops are also a bit lemon That mixes well with the Belgian spices. GET IT. It's a fairly easy drink.\xa0225 charactersHattedClassic, Apr 25, 2015"]

name: Põhjala / To Øl - Ginie (In A Bottle)
review:
['3.4/5\xa0\xa0rDev +8.6%look: 3.5 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 3 | overall: 3.25A 330ml bottle with a best before date of 12th July 2017, poured into a d’Achouffe tulip glass.

Appearance: It poured a hazy orange colour with a less than one finger white head that dissipated quickly and left only sparse lacing.

Aroma: Mango, lemon, lime, touch of ginger and floral notes.

Taste: Lightly salty, lemon zest, lime juice, berries and lightly spicy.

Mouthfeel: Light bodied with low to moderate carbonation.

Overall: This was a bit disappointing considering the last Põhjala x To Øl collaboration I tried (Taanilinn Cognac BA) was a stunner. Perhaps it was the high hopes… The fruitiness was nice but carbonation was too low for a Gose.\xa0662 characterskitch, Oct 27, 2016', '4.13/5\xa0\xa0rDev +31.9%look: 3.5 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4 | overall: 4Hazy orange/amber with sediment, very thin head, low retention.
Smell - rose, rye bread, juniper, spices.
Taste - slightly sour, wheat, lemon, spices, gin hues.
Light body, good carbonation.
Uncommon and nice beer.\xa0214 charactersDentist666, Oct 25, 2016', '1/5\xa0\xa0rDev -68.1%look: 1 | smell: 1 | taste: 1 | feel: 1 | overall: 1So, is this really a beer? It seems that everybody wants to make the strangest beer and Don’t hesitate to put on the market everything possible (or not) This one wants to be a beer and a "modern" gin tonic with every kind of spices inside. Absolute mess. Pale colour., small head. Aroma of salt, lemon and a mix of spices that you can’t difference. Taste is just the same. NEver more in my life.\xa0399 charactersjanubio, Oct 10, 2016', "4.05/5\xa0\xa0rDev +29.4%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4.25Clear golden color with a bit of off-white foam. Aroma is really fruity with lemon, lime and also woody and herbal notes. Taste is quite salty up-front, also spicy, grassy, woody, herbal. Overall it's a really tasty gose with some extra complexity from the gin.\xa0391 charactersCiocanelu, Sep 12, 2016"]

name: Coco-A-Go-Gose
review:
["1.96/5\xa0\xa0rDev -43.8%look: 3 | smell: 2 | taste: 1.75 | feel: 2 | overall: 2Served On-Tap

A — Pours an odd dark brown shade into the glass, almost no head on it, and little to no lacing left behind.

S — Smells quite sour and perhaps spoiled, little bit of a salty component to it, some chocolate maybe, but its well hidden.

T — Tastes initially sweet and chocolaty, then goes quickly into a large lacto sourness, finishes a little salty, but its really just a bit of a mess. Seems like they tried to brew something else, then tried to salvage it when it didn't turn out.

M — Light in body, though a bit rich for being a sour.

O — OK overall, just really seems as though they tried to brew a chocolate stout, screwed it up completely, pitched lacto and salt and called it a chocolate gose.\xa0727 charactersMoose90, Aug 11, 2015", "3.68/5\xa0\xa0rDev +5.4%look: 4 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 4 | overall: 3.5The beer pours a muddled brown with a tight-knit off-white head that laces. The nose is rich with roasty cocoa, not much else. The taste has the same roastiness, but finishes tart with a little salted chocolate as well. There's minimal funk or citrus, but the bitterness builds in the finish as it warms. It's light bodied, well carbed, and drinkable, similar to if a gose was blended with a roasty porter. Best part of this beer is the subtle salt-cocoa play in the finish - pretty average, but unique.\xa0503 charactersThePorterSorter, Aug 07, 2015"]

name: Salarium (Dry Hopped)
review:
['3.98/5\xa0\xa0rDev +1.5%look: 4.25 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 4 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4This is being reviewed blind as to who brewed it and what it is. After first sip it is obviously a Gose
A: Hazy yellow. A effervescent white head forms two fingers that quickly subside and disappear. 
S: Seawater apple and pear
T: Salty and sour. pear, pineapple, citrus fruits, There is also some sweetness there 
MF: Very tart-almost puckering. There is a smooth backbone here. 
O: This is really terrific. It is a very sour gose that is balanced with a sweetness. I could drink this one quite often.\xa0516 charactersSammyJaxxxx, Oct 14, 2018', "3/5\xa0\xa0rDev -23.5%look: 3 | smell: 3 | taste: 3 | feel: 3 | overall: 3Smell: musty sea salt tart green apple lemon 

Taste: wow this is super salty it's hard to get past. Sweet and salty like the label says but mostly salty. Hints of tartness maybe but I'm digging for it.

Feel: light body medium carbonation 

Overall: it's just way to salty. I love transient but this just isn't very good\xa0321 charactersMasonz223, Mar 08, 2017", "3.96/5\xa0\xa0rDev +1%look: 4.5 | smell: 4 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4Purchased from the source in Bridgman, Michigan. Drank out of a Transient Artisan Ales tulip glass. Yay proper glassware!

Look: Poured with three and a half fingers of fluffy white head, thin wispy disjointed lacing, the color of the beer is cloudy straw, lots of fast moving small down-up carbonation.

Smell: Pineapple muffin, sweetened Greek yogurt, a good punch of Tropicana orange-mango juice, sweet wheat biscuit.

Taste: A bit of lacto tartness, definite salt on the finish, not a ton of tropical fruitiness from the hops like there was on the nose but there's a bit of a punch of grapefruit/orange rind, cracker malt, 

Feel: Light body, slick mouthfeel, dry finish, refreshing tickle of effervescence. Pretty much what I typically look for in a gose beer.\xa0766 charactersSpinaltapped, Feb 26, 2017", "4.07/5\xa0\xa0rDev +3.8%look: 3.75 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4500ml 
$8.99
Transient - Bridgman, Mi

Dry Hopped Salarium is the palest of golden, it verges on near colorlessness until backlit when it glows. The foam snap, crackles, and pops to attention. A couple fingers high. It's bubbly and fizzy before receding fairly quickly to nothing but a swirl. Could use a little more retention but this beer seems to lean more toward the sour than most so it's to be expected. With all that said, it looks good.

The nose is bright and vibrant taking on a lactic sour edge. Pineapple yogurt is the first thing that comes to mind. Deep pulls and I'm hit with that rustic wheat twang that's oh so inviting. The wheat base of this beer is like standing in a field when the breeze kicks up. A couple swirls brings forth orange peel, a hint of grapefruit and a touch of tropicals. This beer really opens up as it warms a bit.

The tropical fruitiness is more upfront in the flavor profile than the nose suggested. The middle brings more of that lactic pineapple yogurt tartness. The wheat tends to come through mostly on the finish. Freshly cracked and rustic with a nice twang. I get a touch of salt on the swallow but not much. It' bright and mildly acidic. The dry hopping adds a unique fruitiness to an already good beer.

Transient seems to do a very good job when it comes to dialing in the carbonation and weight of their beers. This particular concoction is on the lighter side of the spectrum with an aggressive, tongue tingly carbonation that brings frothiness to the body. Tartness lingers on the front of the tongue and inside of the cheeks while a soft saltiness lingers long after the swallow. The more I drink the drier the finish becomes. Very nice.

Dry Hopped Salarium is a fine beer from Transient. It's uniquely fruity with a solid wheat base and dialed in mouthfeel. Is it an improvement over original Salarium? Tough to say, it's a different animal all together, more tart and much more fruity. I would pick up this version again in the future.\xa01,994 charactersjoe1510, Nov 18, 2016"]

name: Epicurean Series 2019- Salted Rye Gose
review:
['4.25/5\xa0\xa0rDev +8.1%look: 4.25 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.25Burnt orange color with a rye taste and mild sea salt not a bad beer but no bells and whistles with this beer either more of a sipping beer to me goes down ok but not smooth\xa0173 charactersyuenglingfan101, Oct 19, 2019', "4.35/5\xa0\xa0rDev +10.7%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4.5 | overall: 4.5Clear burnt gold with a thin but fuzzy tan head quickly dying off to nothing.

That caraway rye flavor is fucking spot on and it's just perfectly, lightly tart with a faint salinity. Hints of lemon and green apple accent the background. It's just so much like a drinkably tart, beautifully toasted slice of rye bread in beer form it's absolutely delicious and I have no idea why it works so well, nor also why I wouldn't have thought it'd would going into it.

The round medium body has a light crispness and finishes semi-dry.\xa0527 charactersSabtos, Jul 01, 2019"]

name: Gose
review:
["4.45/5\xa0\xa0rDev +14.7%look: 4.5 | smell: 4.5 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4 | overall: 4.5Had this on-tap at the Princeton location. Most likely brought back. The bartender said the alcohol content was comparable to the Hefeweizen so I'd peg it at about 5.5%. Color was a bit more orange than the older reviews. Served with an orange which I put in the beer but did not squeeze. Made a nice pairing with their smoked turkey sandwich. Slight alcohol aftertaste but not too distracting from the overall experience. Definitely recommended while it's around.\xa0464 charactersphilerman, Aug 30, 2010", '4.2/5\xa0\xa0rDev +8.2%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4 | overall: 4My first gose beer. The specimen at hand was a dark hazy yellow with an inch of white head on top. Banana, clove and earthy spiciness round out the aroma. Slightly chewy due to the wheat, but still nimble on the palate. The flavors are similar to the nose, banana, clove, and some earthiness. There is a lingering acidity toward the end.

Definitely refreshing on a hot summer day. Similar to hefeweizen, but a little earthier. I very much enjoyed the pint.\xa0457 charactersBeardedBoffin, Jul 20, 2008', '3.88/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4Triumph Princeton- Gose

A- Dark, thick, dirty, unfiltered banana yellowish brown with a good size head. Solid chunky lacing.
S- Thick strong wheat, cloves, bananas, and vanilla.
T- Again thick gritty wheat, clove, banana, and vanilla. Similiar to a Hefe just not as bubblegum fruity.
M- Thick viscious grittiness lends into a sour tangy end.

Overall- My first Gose and I say it was pretty good. So close to a Hefe. Just thicker, heavier, and a little less spicy fruitiness.\xa0482 charactersNJpadreFan, Jul 03, 2008']

name: Guimaras Gose
review:
['3.85/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.5 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4A 330ml bottle with no visible bottled on or best before date. Poured into a d’Achouffe tulip glass.

Appearance: It poured a cloudy golden straw orange colour with a two finger white head that had decent retention but not much lacing.

Mouthfeel: Light to medium bodied with moderate carbonation.

Overall: I like it. It is refreshing, easy to drink and has lots of mango, which I enjoy.\xa0536 characterskitch, Nov 10, 2016']

name: Dodo
review:
["4/5\xa0\xa0rDev +8.4%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4Where the gose style traditionally has had a lot of leeway in its acidity- some regions along the Goslar river adapted a palate-stripping sourness similar to berlinerweiss, others were seemingly nothing more than a minerally hefeweizen. But Rhinegeists Dodo lands in the ream where both types meet.

Dodo's pour is bright and lemony straw, but also somewhat milky with its haze. As a delicate stark-white head springs to the surface, it soon dissolves to a necklace around the edge, succumbing to its own acidity. Its tangy, lemony aroma is backed with sour green fruits and hints of fresh baking bread. Sweet and sour in its initial taste, the beer's bready structure keeps the pilsner sweetness and wheaten body elevated... at first.

But the angel-food cakiness and confectioner's sweet begins to dissolve on the middle palate and the sourness rises. Lactic in its nature, the piquant tang of lemon, lime, crabapple, white grape and kiwi all weave into a refreshing, sprite taste. Unlike the more sour versions, the taste retains its wheat structure and keeps a semblance of balance before its minerally, salty, perfumy finish.

With a savory saline character to round out the flavors and to give the fruit flavors and bread structure a brighter, more robust character; the medium-light ale is balanced with a strong chardonnay tartness, a dry finish and an echo of citrusy perfume in aftertaste.\xa01,399 charactersBEERchitect, Oct 09, 2015"]
