A mojito inspired gose made with fresh lime and mint.119 charactersHopheadjeffery, May 06, 2017']

name: Ur-Gose
review:
['4.02/5\xa0\xa0rDev -1.7%look: 4 | smell: 4.5 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 4 | overall: 4.5Review: 0,5l bottle of Ritterguts Urgose Märzen, a Märzen Gose style: 5.5% ABV

Head is flat, none to speak of, but the colour looks great, a nice clear orange coloured beer, which looks tops.\xa0

The smell is interesting, get the salty aroma no problem,\xa0but also get the pine cone easily enough, amongst the usual range of odors........citrus, malts, coriander.\xa0

Like the smell, has an earthly feel to it.\xa0

As to be expected, in the taste I also get the salty flavours, and the spices, the malts and coriander. Very well balanced all things considering!

It is a high energy drink, I feel lifted and relaxed when drinking it. Actually felt it was a bit similar to a cold lucozade! Not bad I guess, can slowly sip it, the bitterness is light, and easy to manage.

It basically is a regular\xa0Märzen with the unique Gose style added. And that in itself is something to try.\xa0I liked it, it takes a while to warm your cockles, to overcome the initial surprise of all the sweet tastes, but then afterwards you can drink it slowly and relax into the Gose style.\xa0

Will definitely buy again, loving this new Gose style of beer on my taste buds!\xa01,146 charactersThisdrinkinglife, Jul 09, 2018', '4.26/5\xa0\xa0rDev +4.2%look: 4 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.5 | overall: 4.25Moderate pour yields a 6/4 inch white head over a bright amber body with little lacing. Nose of a proper Gose, but the flavors are different from all previous examples of the style due to its unique ingredients: 

"Our Ur-Gose is a revival of the old Märzen-Gose style, but with new twists: to the traditional barley, wheat and oat malts and coriander we add Swiss Stone Pine cones, fine Ceylon Cinnamon, and smoked salt from the thousand-year-old Halle saltworks near the brewery. Finally, extra doses of aromatic Hallertauer Perle and bittering Taurus hops round out this unique Märzen-Gose." 

As the beer warms the cinnamon comes out fully on the nose with some of the pine cone as well on the nose, taste, and finish. Wow! Mouthfeel is topnotch and overall, a real special Gose right here folks. Cheers!\xa0810 charactersbobv, Jul 02, 2018']

name: Beachmania
review:
['3.83/5\xa0\xa0rDev -0.5%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 4 | overall: 4A: Pours a hazy medium straw yellow in color with moderate amounts of active visible carbonation rising from the bottom of the glass and moderate pale golden yellow highlights. The beer has a finger tall fizzy foamy off-white head that 
quickly reduces to a medium sized patch of mottled very thin film and a very thin ring at the edges of the glass. Light amounts of lacing are observed.

S: Light to moderate aromas of slightly sour wheat malts and lemon citrus with light aromas of vanilla. The aromas of vanilla intensify slightly as the beer warms up.

T: Upfront there is a light to moderate flavor of slightly sour wheat malts with a light to moderate presence of lemon zest citrus. That is followed by just shy of moderate amounts of briny/salt. Finally there is a moderate flavor of vanilla which intensifies slightly as the beer warms up. Lingering hints of tartness.

M: Light to medium bodied with moderate amounts of carbonation. Light amounts of acidic prickliness.

O: Definitely interesting and makes me want to try some of this Atlantic Beach Pie that it is based on. The vanilla is a touch strong in comparison to the other flavors as the beer warms up but I quite enjoy this one.\xa01,198 charactersdbrauneis, Aug 31, 2016']

name: Raspberry Gose
review:
["3.54/5\xa0\xa0rDev -8.8%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.5On tap at The Scotch House Pub in Rochester, NY.

This one pours a dark pinkish color, with a small head, and not much lacing.

This smells slightly saline, with prickly raspberry puree, and a bit of lemon acidity.

This isn't horrible, but it's also tremendously basic. The raspberry feels authentic, but it doesn't have that juicy or jammy character I'd want out of it. The beer is mildly sour, with a 3 of 4/10 on that scale, I'd say. I get a touch of salt to remind that it's a gose.

This is light bodied, drinkable, and fairly crisp.

There's nothing particularly wrong with this beer, but it's also hard to get particularly excited about it.\xa0648 charactersGreesyFizeek, Oct 07, 2019", '4/5\xa0\xa0rDev +3.1%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4Pours a pink/reddish amber with a moderate head. Lots of juicy, ripe red raspberry aroma and flavor with a hint of wheat and salinity. Very nice fruited gose and quite refreshing.\xa0179 charactersLucular, Sep 03, 2019']

name: Plumbus
review:
['3.36/5\xa0\xa0rDev -10.9%look: 3 | smell: 3.25 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.25Foggy dark salmon with a headless, still surface.

A cucumber smell also exhibits Spree, plum and a hint of butter, while taste adds a lot to the table, including a mild, soft, milky-cheesy funk with tart lemon, plum and Sweet Tarts.

The moderate body has a soft, firm carbonation and finishes semi-dry.\xa0304 charactersSabtos, Apr 19, 2018', '4.19/5\xa0\xa0rDev +11.1%look: 4.25 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.25Served to me in a pint glass on-tap at the brewery, this beer draws a fairly cloudy, hazy copper color with a bit of an orange hue and a white head that’s about 2/3 of an inch thick when first drawn and served to me. Settles to a a thick white ring lining the inside of the glass with a big cluster swirl of foam on the beer’s surface and decent lacing. Aroma’s of biscuity, caramel malt sweetness along with some plum notes and just a slight vinegary funk hint. Has a breaded, biscuity, just slightly toasted, grainy malt taste with some plum notes that gives way to slightly vinegary salt notes. Not too salty or vinegary of course, just the right amount a beer like this ought to have. Has a mainly crisp, yet smooth, medium bodied mouthfeel with moderate carbonation. Has a slightly dry aftertaste. Easy to drink in the good way.

Eric\xa0852 charactersneenerzig, Mar 24, 2018']

name: Belle Of The Ball
review: ["3.45/5\xa0\xa0rDev -0.9%look: 4 | smell: 3.25 | taste: 3.25 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 3.5April 1st, 2015 - Slight and faint, this brew looks petite, but the regular pillars of carbonation suggest a subtler strength on the mouthfeel, as does the velvet head that manages to stay strong even in the cramped confines of a 3 oz. taster glass. Making a little room for the aromatic particles to congregate, I dip my nose into the thimble and catch slight smells of wheat, and a lemon citrus, combined to create the sensation of something like a shandy. The flavor is mellow and savory at the same time, with a bit of plum in the aftertaste. And as the bubbles displayed earlier, the palate isn't too thin like the other Breakwater brews I've had today. Instead, the delicate but lively carbonation matches very well with the tastes and the shade of salt added into the brew. This, I find, is a winner here at Breakwater Brewery.\xa0835 charactersGarrettB, Feb 12, 2018"]

name: Kai Gose To the Beach
review:
["4.1/5\xa0\xa0rDev +3.5%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4 | overall: 4Taking the citrusy taste of Gose to a more tropical place, the brewers at Virgina's Rocket Frog brewery gets together a rather traditional Northern German sour ale and goes to the beach with a generous addition of pink guava.

Kai Gose to the Beach pours a rather cloudy golden-straw hue before crowning with a white swath of sea foam. Leading with a tangy, tropical and exotic perfume, its guava influence is a tad stronger than its winey, citrusy, wheaty perfume underneath. Light on sweetness, the taste of saltwater taffy, sourdough and honeysuckle decorate the early palate.

And as the thirst quenching ale washes the middle palate with acidity, a lime, lemon, passionfruit, gooseberry, white grape and kiwi medley leap right out. The juiciness of guava provides a zesty, racy and fruity complement to the recipe before the ale zips right onto the late palate with a dry sourness of margarita and sangria.

Medium light in texture, the remnants of wheat and the roundness of salinity keep the textures and taste enlivened while trending crisp, clean and highly refreshing. Effortless on the finish the ale extends briefly with citrus with overtones of burlap and tonic.\xa01,175 charactersBEERchitect, Aug 20, 2019"]

name: Key Lime Pie Gose
review: ["4.45/5\xa0\xa0rDev +1.4%look: 3.75 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.75 | feel: 4 | overall: 4.5I had this on tap in Normal, and liked it so much I picked up a four-pack. Clear yellow gold with 1 1/2 finger head that quickly reduces to a thin ring which leaves a little lacing. Smells of light malt with sweet coriander and some vanilla, lime. The tartness is evident in the smell. Taste is similar but really melds together fantastically, the warmth of the coriander and vanilla an inviting accent to the tart lime. On tap, I thought it just moderately tart, but from the can I'd call it quite tart. A fantastic beer which, while not really evoking its namesake strongly, is even better than the name would suggest. \n\nDescription: We've added key lime, vanilla and lactose to our Leipzig-style gose to create a liquid version of the popular dessert. The result is a tart, creamy, refreshing treat for you tastebuds. Now, you can have your pie and drink it too. Cheers!\xa0873 characterswmscottsimpsonjr, May 11, 2019"]

name: Margarita Gose
review:
['3.81/5\xa0\xa0rDev +3.5%look: 3.5 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 4 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.75Poured from a can into a tulip glass glass. 

Ok, I see the purpose of this beer. It would be great to drink it with Mexican food, for example. It probably not something I would drink regularly.

Cloudy yellow, no head or lacing. Sweet fruit smell and taste. Refreshing and tasty but too much like a wine cooler for me, but glad I tried it.\xa0340 characterspuck1225, Oct 28, 2018']

name: The Hat Gose - Blueberry Lemonade
review: ['4.2/5\xa0\xa0rDev +4%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4 | overall: 416 ounce prowler into tulip glass, filled on 6/29/2019. Pours slightly hazy deep ruby red, light pink/purple color with a small fairly dense pink head with solid retention, that reduces to a minimal spotty lace cap that lingers. Minimal lacing on the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of big juicy/tart/tangy blueberries, fruit skin, lemon zest, lime, peach, plum, pear, melon, apricot, red/green apple, red grape/wine, sea salt, hay, straw, grass, wheat, cracker, white bread, light pepper/lacto funk, and yeast earthiness. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of blueberries, lemon zest, fruity/acidic yeast, and moderate pale/wheat malt notes; with big strength. Taste of huge juicy/tart/tangy blueberries, fruit skin, lemon zest, lime, peach, plum, pear, melon, apricot, red/green apple, red grape/wine, sea salt, hay, straw, grass, wheat, cracker, white bread, light pepper/lacto funk, and yeast earthiness. Light-moderate fruity/lactic tart/sourness, fruit tang, and light spiciness on the finish. Lingering notes of sour/tart/tangy blueberries, fruit skin, lemon zest, lime, peach, plum, pear, melon, apricot, red/green apple, red grape/wine, sea salt, hay, straw, grass, wheat, cracker, white bread, light pepper/lacto funk, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Fantastic complexity, robustness, and balance of blueberries, lemon zest, fruity/acidic yeast, and moderate pale/wheat malt flavors; with a great malt/tart/sourness and tangy fruit balance; with minimal puckering flavors after the finish. Fairly crisp finishing. Light-moderate increasing dryness from lingering tart/sourness and tangy fruit. Medium carbonation and light-medium body; with a very smooth and moderately grainy/acidic/tangy/tannic/saline balanced mouthfeel that is great. Zero warming alcohol as expected of 4.7%. Overall this is a fantastic fruited Gose! All around fantastic complexity, robustness, and balance of blueberries, lemon zest, fruity/acidic yeast, and moderate pale/wheat malt flavors; very smooth and fairly crisp/refreshing to drink with the modestly acidic/tangy/tannic/drying finish; not overly lactic/salty. Fantastic balance of super juicy/vibrant/jammy fruit and Lacto complexity; with a solid pale/wheat malt backbone against acidity. Minimal residual sweetness with crisp acidic/tangy drying. A highly enjoyable offering, and outstanding style example as expected.\xa02,425 characterssuperspak, Jun 29, 2019']

name: Harder It Comes Harder It Gose
review:
['3.67/5\xa0\xa0rDev -2.9%look: 4.25 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.5On tap at brewery:
Looks the part, with a very pale yellow/gold body with a fair amount of haze. Head wasn’t too strong, and medium collar left nothing behind.

Ode and taste have a decent representation from the wheat, something I think a lot of beers in the style miss. Coriander comes as an dull earthy note on the nose, but with a little more pop in the taste. Salinity is light, as is the sour aspect. Nothing noted in the nose, there’s a light lime-like sour in the taste.

This offering showcases different aspects of a Gose than the sour. I like that, but the components just didn’t all work as much as I’d thought they would. I think just a little more tartness could’ve done the trick to bring it all together.\xa0737 characterscjgiant, Aug 17, 2019']

name: Sour Cherry Gose
review:
["4.22/5\xa0\xa0rDev -0.9%look: 4 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.25Big thanks to rudzud for the bottle.

Pours a light fizzy head that fades little lacing, very murky super rosy maroon color.

Nose, def not the same bottle that rudzud had, yes there is cherry in there, lots of cherry skin, sour cherry mostly, but not a huge cherry, and there is a big gose or Berliner Weiss, lots of sour mash notes, and wild funk, a weird chemically sour acidic funk too though, raw bread dough, a touch of salt and some minerality and spices, that weird funky sourness almost solventy thing, unfortunately.

Taste is a looooooot better thankfully, none of that weird chemical acidic solventy thing, very tart gose, sour funky, earthy almost cheesy funk, a little salty with touches of spices, creamy wheat base and little lemony gose, nice funk level, some cherry not a ton, sour cherry and a little sweeter maybe Balaton, little candy cherry pie, sour cherry skin, fair acidity that ramps to a little flemmy finish, lingering tart cherry and lemony sour gose.

Mouth is med to lighter bod, decent fizzy carbonation, tart acidic flemmy.

Overall no idea what bottle rudzud got, but it wasn't anything near what I have, something really weird and off thing on the aroma, thankfully not very strong aroma as the good gose and some cherry there but something off, some cherry but nothing close to what rudzud had, taste was pretty nice, base gose was great and a bit of nice cherry, so no idea what the juxtaposition of the nose and taste were about.\xa01,467 charactersjlindros, Oct 02, 2017", '4.69/5\xa0\xa0rDev +10.1%look: 5 | smell: 4.75 | taste: 4.75 | feel: 4 | overall: 4.75Picked this up at the brewery. Dave told me the amount of sour cherry juice that was used in this...thought I submitted that amount as an update but I guess not...

A - Poured into my Duvel tulip a nice hazy pinkish hue with just maybe a little bit of gold to it. A very, very light ruby. Or well...cherry juicy color. The head though...two fat fingers of creamy pinkish white that leaves light side lacing and a very thick blanket. Absolutely stellar appearance for a Gose. Just stellar.

S - Aromas of tart sour cherries. Almost cherry pie filling like. Not the sweet stuff from the can but very bright and just lightly jammy. The cherries overpower the base beer pretty heavily. The lemon notes of the gose are gone, replaced completely by cherries. I don't really get much salt at all either. The doughy grains though are still there, although much more muted now due to the addition of cherry juice. That being said, this nose is absolutely incredible. What grain element is there, combined with the massive cherry aroma, tricks the brain into smelling a fresh baked cherry pie. It's really, really something. I can hear JLindros in my head saying though "where is the beer?! This doesn't smell like a beer" and I guess that's why I wouldn't give it a 5. That being said I would rather have this aroma, cherry forward, than one where the cherries are muted and play second fiddle. 

T - Taste is similar to the nose. More of that big tart cherry pie filling going on. Really get juicy, what I imagine are montmorency, cherry flavour. Once the cherry tartness fades though there is big gose notes. The base beer really comes out, nice creamy lactic funk. Very nice cereal grains and doughy notes. Very light flemmy notes with just a bit of salinity on the finish.

M - Mouthfeel is lightly carbonated, little creamy. Would like a bit more carb.

O - Overall, this gose was just incredible. Damn near perfect use of the cherries in this beer, I honestly don't see how this could be any more cherry without it getting into that weird medicinal realm that can happen with cherry beers. Base beer comes through perfectly on the taste. Killer appearance. Other than wanting some more carbonation this beer is the best non stout from Dave I've ever had. If this was from Westbrook or de Garde people would be losing their absolute minds and trying to trade some sort of barrel aged stout for it. Top notch Dave, top notch. If you ever venture into the world of canning your beers this one needs to be included.

Serving Type: Bottle\xa02,532 charactersrudzud, Sep 13, 2017']

name: Strawberry Gose
review:
["3.87/5\xa0\xa0rDev -4.9%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4Ale with sea salt, coriander, and strawberry puree. Poured from a can into a Woodburn tulip. The pour is dark gold in color with a very, very faint hint of red and sports an impressive head for a sour beer. I get some lemon, green apple, and wine-like notes on the nose, but overall it's very faint.

Light body with a firm feel and a tart, refreshing flavor. I don't get much strawberry on the nose, but there is a littler on the palate. There are also some fruity tart flavors as well as a hint of sweetness and subtle salinity. The beer is incredibly refreshing and not at all unpleasantly sour. I would happily offer this beer to an open-minded person who is unfamiliar with sours or who claims that they don't care for them.\xa0730 charactersdeadonhisfeet, Jun 06, 2019", "4.15/5\xa0\xa0rDev +2%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4 | overall: 4.25The 'ole traditional Northern German styled sour wheat ale thought it had enough flavor, complexity and uniqueness all on its own. But that classic style of beer never saw this coming... Strawberry. Along with the common spice of coriander and sea salt, this garden variety fruit adds a flavor to the beer that's anything but garden variety.

Pinkish gold and carrying a typical wheaten haze, Strawberry Gose teases the nose with a dip into its light ivory froth with a tease of citrus, a taunt of spice and an invigorating sour scent with red berries creating whimsy and charm. Light sweetness greets the tongue with notions of pulled candy, saltwater taffy and a kiss of pastry.

Sweetness and breadiness drifts away effortlessly as the middle palate is a full transition over to sourness. Brisk, lemony, lime-like, with green apple, white grape and gooseberries showering the tastebuds with acidity, the ale slowly lures in the strawberry character for a taste that hinges on cranberry and rhubarb as well. A rounded salinity brings a sea-like brine to the late palate while the bright and tangy prefume of citronella offers one last jolt of complexity.

Medium bodied for sour ale, the wheat isn't all lost. It makes a return on the after palate while the brunt of sourness drives home a highly refreshing, thirst quenching and effortless taste on the finish. Hints of burlap come in late and remind the senses of the beer's probiotic roots. It brings the taste of Liepzig to the threshold of the American South.\xa01,516 charactersBEERchitect, May 17, 2018"]

name: Locals Only! Key Lime Gose
review: ['4.13/5\xa0\xa0rDev +0.2%look: 4.5 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4.5Got in a trade with GreenBayBA. 12 ounce can into tulip glass, canned in 4/2019. Pours very hazy/cloudy pale golden/yellow color with a 2 finger fairly dense and fluffy off white head with fantastic retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Nice dense soapy lacing clings on the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation. Fantastic appearance. Aromas of big sour/tart/tangy key limes, citrus peel/zest, lemon, orange, grapefruit, peach, pear, melon, apricot, red/green apple, white grape/wine, sea salt, coriander, hay, straw, grass, wheat, graham cracker, white bread dough, and lightly toasted biscuit; with lighter notes peppercorn, lacto funk, and yeast earthiness. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of key limes, fruity/acidic yeast, coriander, sea salt, and moderate pale/wheat malt notes; with big strength. Taste of big sour/tart/tangy key limes, citrus peel/zest, lemon, orange, grapefruit, peach, pear, melon, apricot, red/green apple, white grape/wine, sea salt, coriander, hay, straw, grass, wheat, graham cracker, white bread dough, and lightly toasted biscuit; with lighter notes peppercorn, lacto funk, and yeast earthiness. Light-moderate fruity/lactic tart/sourness, citrus tang, and coriander spiciness on the finish. Lingering notes of sour/tart/tangy key limes, citrus peel/zest, lemon, orange, grapefruit, peach, pear, melon, apricot, red/green apple, white grape/wine, sea salt, coriander, hay, straw, grass, wheat, graham cracker, white bread dough, biscuit, peppercorn, lacto funk, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Awesome complexity, robustness, and balance of key limes, fruity/acidic yeast, coriander, sea salt, and moderate pale/wheat malt flavors; with an awesome malt, tart, sour, tangy, spicy balance; with no puckering/astringent flavors after the finish. Fairly crisp/clean finishing. Moderate increasing dryness from lingering tart/sourness, tangy fruit, spice, and carbonation. medium-high carbonation and light-medium body; with a very smooth and moderately bready/grainy/acidic/sticky/saline balanced mouthfeel that is great. Zero warming alcohol as expected of 4.5%. Overall this is an awesome gose. All around awesome complexity, robustness, and balance of key limes, fruity/acidic yeast, coriander, sea salt, and moderate pale/wheat malt flavors; very smooth and fairly crisp/clean/refreshing to drink, with the modestly acidic/tangy/spicy/drying finish; not overly lactic/salty. Awesome balance of juicy/vibrant key limes, Lacto complexity, salt, and spice; with a nice pale/wheat malt backbone against acidity for the ABV. Zero residual sweetness with crisp acidic/tangy dryness. A really enjoyable offering, and spot on style example.\xa02,732 characterssuperspak, May 24, 2019']

name: Raspberry Gose
review:
["4.29/5\xa0\xa0rDev +3.4%look: 4.25 | smell: 4.5 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4 | overall: 4.25My fiance said she hasn't had a better raspberry gose and while I won't go that far, it's so good I wouldn't fight her on it either! Very light, refreshing, and super crushable with great color and a solid head. Poured from a 12 ounce can into a stemmed, tapered glass.\xa0271 charactersSouthernSips, Oct 15, 2018", '4.65/5\xa0\xa0rDev +12%look: 4.75 | smell: 4 | taste: 5 | feel: 4.5 | overall: 4.75Look: pink rose color, fluffy strong head that fizzled out quickly

Smell: tarty raspberries

Feel: crisp, refreshing

Overall: quite surprised by the freshness of the raspberries!! I find this to be very drinkable. Sweeter than the typical gose.\xa0323 charactersHandMeAnother, Oct 05, 2018', '3.5/5\xa0\xa0rDev -15.7%look: 3.5 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.512oz can poured into 16oz tulip. Poured a slightly cloudy pink color with just a thin cap of light pink head that had low retention and no lacing.

Nice raspberry scent upfront,with an underlying tartness. Very similar on the tongue. The body was light and crisp,with a dry finish. Drinkability was very good,went quick and easy.I shoulda drank more of these while the weather was warm.
Overall, a pretty nice little brew. Worth trying if you see it.\xa0450 charactersbeertunes, Sep 16, 2018']

name: Sweet Tart - Passionfruit Gose
review:
['3.83/5\xa0\xa0rDev -3.8%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 4 | overall: 4473ml can - sort of a strange time of the year to be releasing something like this, innit?

This beer pours a hazy, medium golden yellow colour, with a teeming tower of puffy, finely foamy, and mildly bubbly off-white head, which leaves some cannonball splash aftermath lace around the glass as it steadily recedes.

It smells of gritty and grainy cereal malt, some muddled tropical fruitiness, a faint lacto funk, saline solution, and some ethereal earthy, musty, and dead leafy hop bitters. The taste is semi-sweet, grainy and crackery pale malt, a lesser spicy wheatiness, juicy passionfruit, fancy salt, faded yeasty notes, and more super understated earthy, herbal, and grassy green hoppiness.

The carbonation is fairly restrained in its innocuous-seeming frothiness, the body a so-so middleweight, and mostly smooth, with a small airy creaminess arising as things warm up a tad around here. It finishes off-dry, the frooty character predominating.

Overall - well, Matt and the gang brought the goods with this one. Definitely more sweet than tart, but, in the end, balanced. Full of flavour, and quite refreshing, but it is still weird drinking this right before I have to go out and lay down some sand on the sidewalk, before some kid takes a header.\xa01,263 charactersbiboergosum, Dec 11, 2018', '4.13/5\xa0\xa0rDev +3.8%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4Appearance - Pours a hazy straw gold with three fingers of foamy and bubbly white head.

Smell - wheaty and bready malts, sea salt, passion fruit, and spicy earthy yeast. 

Taste - wheat and bready malts upfront then quickly goes into a strong presence from the both the sea salt and the passion fruit. The spicy earthy yeast finishes the brew off.

Mouthfeel - Medium bodied with moderate to high carbonation. Finishes sticky with a pleasant tartness with the sea salt and passion fruit lingering.

Overall - An enjoyable gose from the folks at Phillips. They nailed the passion fruit and saltiness to a tee. A very easy drinker!\xa0630 charactersleaddog, Nov 24, 2018']

name: Downstream Jam
review:
["3.74/5\xa0\xa0rDev -6.3%look: 4.25 | smell: 4 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.75Downstream Jam brewed by Royal Docks Brewing Company, with an ABV of 5.00% This Leipzig Gose pours out of a 12oz can into a pint beer glass a nice deep reddish amber color with a nice white head. There is a nice amount of lacing to this brew, it sticks to the side of the glass well. Really digging the color of this brew. The smell is rich with sourness mixed with fruit . You also pick up on a nice amount of of grains and malts in the smell as well. Nice minor hits of raspberry in the smell are a nice touch to this brew. So far Downstream Jam is a nice inviting brew. Now for the taste, it is Bold with tart raspberry flavors mixed with mirror grains and malts. I will give this brew this it has a lot of sourness to it. But it like bitter sweet. Like real stong lemonade or something to that effect. But it is to be expected with this style of brew. The body is a solid medium. This is a nice flow of bitter sweetness in thi brew. The mouth feel is Tart , Sour, Bold, Clean Smooth and Refreshing. This brew would go nice on a warmer day or with lunch. Overall I'm going to give Downstream Jam a 3.75 out of 5. I would like to look this brew up again just to change it up from time to time.\xa01,197 charactersnicholas2121, Apr 27, 2019", "4.21/5\xa0\xa0rDev +5.5%look: 4 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4 | overall: 4.25Downstream Jam | Royal Docks Brewing Company. Poured from the can into a pint glass, the head's three fingers thick, with spottier lacing, and a translucent almost red body.

I smell lighter malts with plenty of the raspberries.

Tastes like a pleasantly tart version of the aroma. This still makes for a clean, refreshing finish.

Medium mouthfeel with mild carbonation.

Overall, I'll go ahead and rate Downstream Jam | Royal Docks Brewing Company with a 4.25.\xa0478 charactersCaveworm, Feb 23, 2019"]

name: Skipjack Oyster Gose
review:
['3.87/5\xa0\xa0rDev -0.8%look: 4 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 4 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.75-deep amber tap pour to a large tulip produced no visible carbonation. The aroma is light with lemon. The flavor is citrus and a bit of raisin. The astringincy is only moderate. There is a slightly salty note. This is a refreshing a well-flavored goose with a thinner finish.\xa0276 charactersBluecrow, Feb 20, 2018', "4.01/5\xa0\xa0rDev +2.8%look: 3.75 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4From the brewery: 
We teamed up with our good friends at 167 Raw - Charleston to design a gose brewed with whole oysters! The minerality and brininess of these oysters work perfectly into the tart, salty traditional character of this classic German style.
Brewed with whole oysters from 167 Raw. Earthy lemon aroma with a hint of ocean air. Light acidity and brininess. Bright lemon, dry, crisp finish.

Just got home with growler, poured 15 minutes later into pint glass. 
A: pours a crystal clear golden body with some fine bubble carbonation, one finger white foam head that quickly fades
S: soft salty air, hints of salty briney oysters, light mineral aroma, hints of lemon
M: light body with semi dry finish on the tongue 
T: tart up front, light fruity citrus, light mineral kind of mellows on the tongue, briney is just a touch and I've had heavier, the carbonation tingles on the tongue, I also feel like I get just a tad sweet tartness in the middle
O: great solid gose, worth having more\xa0997 charactersoutdoor7or24, Jun 18, 2017"]

It was easily my favorite of the 8 beers they had on tap.\xa0169 charactersLucular, Jul 26, 2015']

name: Pina Mangito
review: ["4.78/5\xa0\xa0rDev +10.6%look: 4.75 | smell: 4.75 | taste: 4.75 | feel: 5 | overall: 4.75This beer had no hype and I don't normally rate this generously, but this beer blew me away. Hazy, neon yellow turbid juicy look. Taste and feel was fleshy, like I was biting into a fruit. I wasn't even sure I was drinking a beer or eating a mango or pineapple. Then add in the gose salt and some pepper and there is so much flavor. More fleshy and fruity than the best new glarus or de Garde tarts. Hazy and juicy like NE juice bombs. Just a phenomenal beer. This beer melted my face.\xa0493 charactersSlothB77, Apr 03, 2016"]

name: Dub Plum
review: ['4.28/5\xa0\xa0rDev -4.7%look: 4.5 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4.5 | overall: 416 ounce can into tulip glass, canned on 8/20/2018. Pours very hazy deep ruby red/pink/purple color with a 1-2 finger fairly dense and fluffy pink head with fantastic retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers. Nice thick foamy lacing clings on the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation. Fantastic appearance. Aromas of big juicy/tart/tangy plums, fruit skin/pits, lemon, lime, orange, peach, pear, apricot, red/green apple, red grape/wine, coriander, salt, hay, straw, grass, wheat, biscuit dough, light pepper/lacto funk, and yeast earthiness. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of plums, fruity/acidic yeast, coriander, sea salt, and pale/wheat malt notes; with big strength. Taste of huge juicy/tart/tangy plums, fruit skin/pits, lemon, lime, orange, peach, pear, apricot, red/green apple, red grape/wine, coriander, salt, hay, straw, grass, wheat, biscuit dough, light pepper/lacto funk, and yeast earthiness. Light fruity/lactic tartness, fruit tang, and spiciness on the finish. Lingering notes of juicy/tart/tangy plums, fruit skin/pits, lemon, lime, orange, peach, pear, apricot, red/green apple, red grape/wine, coriander, sea salt, hay, straw, grass, wheat, biscuit dough, light pepper/lacto funk, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a while. Incredible complexity, robustness, and balance of plums, fruity/acidic yeast, coriander, salt, and pale/wheat malt flavors; with a nice malt/tartness, and tangy fruit balance; with no cloying/puckering flavors after the finish. Lightly increasing dryness from lingering tartness and tangy fruit. Medium-plus carbonation and body; with a very smooth, creamy/silky/bready, fairly acidic/tangy, and lightly saline mouthfeel that is fantastic. Zero warming alcohol for 5.6%. Overall this is an incredible double fruited gose. All around fantastic complexity, robustness, and balance of plums, fruity/acidic yeast, coriander, salt, and pale/wheat malt flavors; very smooth and refreshing to drink with the mellowly acidic/tangy/drying finish. Mildly lactic, and not overly salty. Enormous amounts of juicy/jammy plums, balanced Lacto complexity, and wheat/malts against acidity. Lightly sweet with lingering tart/tangy dryness. A highly enjoyable offering, and spot on style example. Sweeter than expected, but has tons of fruit to balance it out.\xa02,337 characterssuperspak, Apr 17, 2019']

name: Gose
review:
['4.1/5\xa0\xa0rDev +6.5%look: 3.5 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 4.25I had this beer on-tap in a pint glass at the Hillside in Seattle.

Appearance: medium yellow with a bit of haze and a thin layer of white foam.

Smell: lightly sweet and tart; well-rounded and enticing.

Taste: balanced, tart, sweet and damn refreshing. Even a dash of salt keeping it stylistically on point. Great!

Mouthfeel: medium-light body with a good carbonation and decent creaminess.

Overall: super to-style and refreshing. I dig it.\xa0449 charactersflagmantho, May 05, 2016']

name: Umi
review: ['3.86/5\xa0\xa0rDev -2.5%look: 4.5 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 4 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 4Got in a BIF from Coronaeus. 12 ounce can into tulip glass, canned on 2/26/2019. Pours fairly hazy medium golden yellow color with a 2 finger dense and fluffy white head with fantastic retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lasts. Thick foamy lacing clings on the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation. Fantastic appearance. Aromas of tart/tangy lemon, lime, citrus peel/rind, peach, pear, melon, apricot, red/green apple, white grape/wine, coriander, sea salt, hay, straw, grass, wheat, cracker, white bread dough, light peppercorn/lacto funk, and yeast earthiness. Nice and pleasant aromas with good balance and complexity of Japanese citrus, fruity/acidic yeast, coriander, salt, and moderate pale/wheat malt notes; with solid strength. Taste of big tart/tangy lemon, lime, citrus peel/rind, peach, pear, melon, apricot, red/green apple, white grape/wine, coriander, sea salt, hay, straw, grass, wheat, cracker, white bread dough, light peppercorn/lacto funk, and yeast earthiness. Light-moderate fruity/lactic tartness; citrus peel/rind bitterness; and coriander spiciness on the finish. Lingering notes of tart/tangy lemon, lime, citrus peel/rind, peach, pear, melon, apricot, red/green apple, white grape/wine, coriander, sea salt, hay, straw, grass, wheat, cracker, white bread dough, light peppercorn/lacto funk, and yeast earthiness for a good bit. Very nice complexity, robustness, and balance of Japanese citrus, fruity/acidic yeast, coriander, salt, and moderate pale/wheat malt flavors; with a nice malt, tartness, bitter, spiciness balance. Moderate increasing dryness from lingering tartness and bitter/spiciness. Medium-plus carbonation and light-medium body; with very smooth, moderately creamy/grainy, fairly crisp/acidic/sticky/resinous/rindy, and lightly saline balanced mouthfeel that is good. Slight lingering rind/spice astringency, but not overwhelming. Zero warming alcohol as expected of 4.3%. Overall this is a very nice gose. All around nice complexity, robustness, and balance of Japanese citrus, fruity/acidic yeast, coriander, salt, and moderate pale/wheat malt flavors; very smooth and fairly crisp/refreshing to drink with the modestly bitter/spicy/drying finish. Not overly lactic/salty. Very flavorful for the ABV. Very well balanced vibrant Japanese citrus, Lacto complexity, spice, and salt; with a nice pale/wheat malt backbone against acidity for the ABV. Minimal residual sweetness with crisp dryness. A very enjoyable offering, and well made style example; just wish it lacked the citrus/spice astringency.\xa02,564 characterssuperspak, May 05, 2019']

name: La Resistance Sour Ale
review:
["3.85/5\xa0\xa0rDev -0.5%look: 1.5 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4A&S: Easily one of the worst looking beers I have seen. Fizzy white head vaporizers instantly as it is poured. Translucent light yellow beer with barely a sign of carbonation. No legs. Really flat, lame looking beer. Contrary to the look, the aroma is pretty good. Sweet, grainy, and black cherries. 

T&M: Not bad. Not one of my favorite sours, but not bad. Can't taste the Himalayan sea salt, but I tasted tartness, slight acidity, and slightly fruity. Not a ton of carbonation, but honestly more than I expected. 


O: Not bad especially for the price. I would say it would be worth a try.\xa0592 charactersminterro, May 10, 2018", '3.75/5\xa0\xa0rDev -3.1%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.75Pours a slightly hazy, yet mostly clear, yellow straw color. Carbonation is visible with a minimal head that quickly dissipates. A thin ring of lace retains throughout.
The aroma emits a barnyard funk that is also redolent of hay and grass. It is also soon apparent that this will be a sour drink as a lemon like aroma begins to develop. Consistent with style, a briny and sea salt like smell also begins to develop. 
The taste is quite tart, almost acidic. Flavors of lemon, sour citrus fruit, dry cider, and vinegar. A doughy malt texture is evident in the mid palate. A touch of brine and salt are subtle and not overdone.
Light bodied with a moderate carbonate. Acidic and slightly intense. A bone dry finish and a puckering mouthfeel.
I thought it was fairly accurate for the style, albeit a little intense and perhaps slightly one dimensional. I recently had this breweries’ RBF, also a Gose, and preferred how its raspberry flavor took the edge off of things.\xa0971 charactersGajo74, Apr 15, 2018']

name: Blueberry Gose
review:
['3.99/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.75 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 432 ounce growler 
Served in a becker glass

This beer pours a hazy amber color with lavender tint from the blueberries. It is capped with two inches of white head that disappears and leaves no trace.

It has a tart blueberry aroma.

It starts out sweet with the taste of blueberries. Then the tartness comes along. The finish is mild saltiness. 

Smooth, medium mouthfeel

This was a refreshing gem found at primarily a wine facility. I really like the flavors going on here. It hits the spot on a hot summer day. Each sip leaves me wanting another.\xa0549 charactersbuschbeer, Jul 18, 2015']

name: Passion Fruit Gose
review:
['3.95/5\xa0\xa0rDev -4.6%look: 3.75 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 4 | overall: 4Gose brewed with coriander and sea salt with passionfruit added. Poured from a can into a Wicked Weed tulip. The pour is gold in color and slightly hazy with about a finger of fine white foam. Poor retention (due to the acidity). I definitely get the passionfruit on the nose along with apples, pears, kiwi, and a hint of lemon.

Medium light body with a firm feel and a tart, fruity flavor. Sharp flavors of lemon rind up front with a little passionfruit and kiwi. The fruit flavors fade at mid-palate and a soft salinity creeps in. It carries to the finish, where it is joined by some lemon, leaving a sharp tartness behind. Overall, very refreshing and a nice example of a fruited gose. I will definitely try some other offerings from Sour Note.\xa0748 charactersdeadonhisfeet, Jul 14, 2018', "4.16/5\xa0\xa0rDev +0.5%look: 4 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4 | overall: 4Some fruits are just better than others. And when it comes to sour ale, two fruits stand tall amidst the rest. Apricot and passionfruit may not seem like standout fruits on their own, but in sour ale they zing! The Sour Note team employs the power of passionfruit to seduce its imbibers with unapologetic effect.

Pouring a slight foggy goldenrod, Passion Fruit Gose brings a spritzy liveliness that rises and falls with a quick, loose froth. Racy aromatics fill the nose with tropical fruit, citrus, cider and white wine along with a light leathery must. Gentle sweetness layers on the tongue with a wafer thin maltiness that's suggestive of sourdough, saltwater taffy and hard candy.

Sweetness fades nearly as quick as its froth while the sourness begins to build upon the middle palate. Passionfruit flavors float above the natural fruitiness of lime, lemon, white grape, green apple, gooseberry and kiwi. Melon-lie flavors come along a juicy but acidic path with distinct sour, dry, juicy kiwi taste to round out the late palate.

The softness of perfumy coriander and the rounded flavor from sea salt keeps the ale tasting and feeling full yet bright while the unique acidity of peach bring a slight stone fruit character to the finish. Clean acids wash the thirst with ease as a quick after taste of peach and burlap highlight the beer's brightness and brininess all at once.\xa01,383 charactersBEERchitect, Jul 06, 2018"]

name: Vacation Island: Cucumber Margarita
review: ['4.46/5\xa0\xa0rDev +6.4%look: 4.25 | smell: 4.5 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.5Pours a foggy pale yellow with no head formation besides a little white fizz that fizzles out quickly. Aroma is a huge dose of cucumber, which comes off as refreshing and natural - not artificial. A hint of margarita is behind. There is an overall slight tartness to the aroma. Flavor profile is cucumber heavy. Margarita and lime are a little heavier in the flavor profile than the aroma. The lime has a distinct lactic sourness to it. Mouth feel is smooth with a slight fizz. It has a medium thickness. Overall, a stand-up refreshing sour. Well crafted and smoothed out.\n\nServed in a 12oz snifter from a 22oz bottle.\xa0618 charactersHarrison8, Jan 14, 2018']

name: Garage / Whiplash / Fuerst Wiacek - Missouri
review: ['3.85/5\xa0\xa0rDev +8.8%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 4 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.75Pours a clear, pale golden coloration with a tiny, fizzy head. Smells of light, wheaty malt and a strong citric acidity, with grapefruit being particularly noticeable. Taste follows the nose, being dominated by a medium citric acidity and a strong grapefruit presence, with just a hint of coriander and sea salt as well. Finishes with a medium acidity and some grapefruit lingering in the aftertaste. Smooth mouthfeel with a medium body and carbonation.\n\nThis is a perfectly nice, understated Gose that manages to feel towards the more traditional spectrum of the style despite the addition of grapefruits, which actually lend a rather nice, refreshing kick to this while not impacting the balance of flavor negatively here.\xa0724 charactersSnowcrash000, Jul 27, 2019', '3/5\xa0\xa0rDev -15.3%look: 3 | smell: 3 | taste: 3 | feel: 3 | overall: 3De Labirratorium. En copa Teku. Jugando a Thimbleweed Park. Algo de acidez y sal. No le encuentro el pomelo ni la naranja, si acaso el efecto del limon en la acidez. Simplemente bien, sin entusiasmar\xa0199 charactersjosanguapo, May 05, 2019']

name: Flamingo Juice
review:
['3.57/5\xa0\xa0rDev -12.1%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 4 | overall: 3.5Pours looking like mango juice with very little head.

Smell is tart, with notes of mango and mint and a hint of black pepper.

Taste is tart, with the same notes from the nose and some added passionfruit. The pepper lingers a bit after the finish.

Mouthfeel is medium, well carbonated.

Overall, a good sour, but a bit one dimensional.\xa0337 charactersJamFuel, May 15, 2019']

name: Au Contraire Mon Frère
review:
['4.05/5\xa0\xa0rDev -4.7%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4Fully opaque purple-red with a thin head that dies to a thin, pastel purple chain.

Smell is a little lighter and brighter than taste, with lime spritzed blackberry juice that pops but is a little airy.

Fresh seedy blackberry is up front on the palate, with tart accents of lime and hints of shortbread. The saltiness of the style is pretty much squashed by the fullness of the tart, sweet juicy berry as a moderate, fulfilling carbonation leads into a semi-dry finish. Hints of orange creep on, and in conjunction with the vanilla, this lends an occasional creamsicle element.

Missing Mountain is doing Answer things already! Thankfully this has a bit more of a beery bite and is much less sweet than some of those ostentatious juicers. Still, this is extremely fruit puree-forward.\xa0785 charactersSabtos, Sep 18, 2018']

name: Blueberry Grind
review: ["4.29/5\xa0\xa0rDev +7.3%look: 4 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.5Pours a glowing pink with a thin white head. Blueberry comes out swinging in the aroma, and is quickly backed-up by lemon zest, orange, and a lovely light-citrus coffee. It smells a touch sour, but just barely so. Flavor profile hits the aroma notes, but more in-depth. Blueberry opens up with lemon, and light fruity coffee coming in behind. Coffee is kept at a lovely level. It's there if you really lean into the aroma and flavor profile, but it's a light enough, African origin coffee that it melds in between the blueberry and lemon notes well. There is a light sourness to it, but nothing puckering. Mouth feel is a touch fizzy, but is otherwise splendidly smooth with a medium thickness. Overall, blueberry is an appropriate namesake for this beer. Blueberry notes are solid and come off as natural, with a pleasant array of notes behind it. \n\nDraft. Reviewed from notes.\xa0878 charactersHarrison8, Apr 21, 2018"]

name: Coffee Gose
review: ['4.24/5\xa0\xa0rDev +8.4%look: 4 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.25perhaps my favorite of the recent round of these beers to come around! its about as well done as such a thing could possibly be, and it represents one of my favorite of their beers to date! the coffee is awesome in this low alcohol tangy slammer. its strongly earthy with dark chocolate and minor smoke notes, and i think that levels out some of the clean bacterial acidity. in the taste, i am reminded of the way the italians sometimes take espresso, with the lemon zested right into the shot, that emulsified oily crema and the bright citrus are what i get from the lacto and the coffee together in here, its so good! bitterness from the coffee is also nice, but its proportionality in the beer is amazing. it must be blended in, cold brewed, post fermentation, its so clean and distinct on its own, and meshes so well with the delicate gose. not too sour, the salt really amplifies the wheat and the coffee together, and overall we have an incredibly unique and well executed beer right here, one of the best coffee sour beers i have ever had, and a deadset winner. these guys are positively killing it!\xa01,106 charactersStonedTrippin, Jul 14, 2017']

name: Margarita Gose - Tequila Barrel Aged
review: ['3.92/5\xa0\xa0rDev -0.5%look: 4 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 4 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 4Pours a hazy amber with a well retained half inch white head that left nice spotty lacing. Smells of lime, tequila and sea salt. Tastes of lime, lemon, lime peel, tequila, sea salt, honey and a hint of white bread. Light bodied, medium carbonation, mild to moderate tartness, slightly dry finish.\xa0297 charactersEMH73, Jun 22, 2019', '4.2/5\xa0\xa0rDev +6.6%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4 | overall: 416 ounce can into tulip glass, canned in 5/2019. Pours very hazy deep golden amber/light orange color with a small dense and creamy off white head with great retention, that reduces to a thin cap that lingers. Nice spotty soapy lacing clings on the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of big tart/sour lemons, limes, citrus peel/zest, orange, peach, pear, melon, apricot, red/green apple, white grape/wine, sea salt, tequila, oak, hay, straw, grass, honey, agave, wheat, white bread dough, light peppercorn/lacto funk, and yeast earthiness. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of lemon, lime, fruity/acidic yeast, salt, tequila barrels, and pale/wheat malt notes; with great strength. Taste of big tart/sour lemons, limes, citrus peel/zest, orange, peach, pear, melon, apricot, red/green apple, white grape/wine, sea salt, tequila, oak, hay, straw, grass, honey, agave, wheat, white bread dough, light peppercorn/lacto funk, and yeast earthiness. Light-moderate fruity/lactic tart/sourness, fruit tang; and light tequila/oak spiciness on the finish. Lingering notes of tart/sour lemons, limes, citrus peel/zest, orange, peach, pear, melon, apricot, red/green apple, white grape/wine, sea salt, tequila, oak, hay, straw, grass, honey, agave, wheat, white bread dough, light peppercorn/lacto funk, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a while. Fantastic complexity, robustness, and balance of lemon, lime, fruity/acidic yeast, salt, tequila barrels, and pale/wheat malt flavors; with an awesome malt/tart/sourness and tangy fruit balance; with minimal puckering flavors after the finish. Light-moderate increasing dryness from lingering tart/sourness and tangy fruit. Medium carbonation and medium-plus body; with a very smooth, creamy/silky/grainy, fairly acidic/tangy, and lightly tannic/saline mouthfeel that is great. Minimal warming alcohol for 6%. Overall this is a fantastic barrel aged fruited gose. All around fantastic complexity, robustness, and balance of lemon, lime, fruity/acidic yeast, salt, tequila barrels, and pale/wheat malt flavors; very smooth and easy to drink with the modestly acidic/tangy/drying finish; not overly lactic/salty. Amazing balance of juicy/vibrant lemon/limes, Lacto complexity, and tequila barrel presence/integration; with a great pale/wheat malt backbone against acidity. Minimal residual sweetness from lingering acidic dryness. A highly enjoyable offering, and amazing experimental style example. Spot on for the base style. Tastes just like a margarita as intended.\xa02,549 characterssuperspak, May 12, 2019']

name: Gose To The Limits
review:
["3.68/5\xa0\xa0rDev +1.7%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 4 | overall: 3.75I had this beer on-tap in a pint glass at the brewery taproom.

Appearance: light golden hue with a moderate haze and effervescence. Nice.

Smell: wheaty and lightly sweet with a dash of sour. I like it.

Taste: light and wheaty with just a tiny dash of sour. Not really sour enough to be a Gose, but otherwise a good beer.

Mouthfeel: medium body with a big carbonation and a good creaminess. Good.

Overall: this is a good and highly quaffable wheat beer, even if it's not sour enough to be a Gose.\xa0506 charactersflagmantho, May 08, 2016"]

name: Brews Brothers Faded (Habanero Peach Gose)
review:
["3.78/5\xa0\xa0rDev +1.3%look: 2 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 3 | overall: 4Look: Very cloudy straw color. Pours with a fine head which collapses to larger bubbles and then nothing within a minute. Forms large bubbles on the side of the glass. It is too cloudy to see bubbles rising.
Smell: Mix of many things including evergreen trees, ripe stone fruits, hot peppers, and mild yeast. Swirling the glass pops up some overripe fruit, stronger evergreen tree resins, and a stronger yeast.
Taste: Very fruity with a mild chile pepper burn. The burn builds towards the end. Rather tart, which makes the stone fruit flavors pop.
Feel: Turns into a creamy foam and then larger bubbles which are a bit hard to swallow without letting it mellow out in the mouth for a while (not such a bad thing if you like chile burn). The carbonation is quite active, so it starts to get flat near the end of the glass.
Overall: Highly recommended for the jaded beer drinker. This is a fresh blast of flavors that aren't usually found together. It probably wouldn't work with a chile cook-out since it would only add to the burn.\xa01,031 charactersaltstadt, Jun 04, 2019"]

name: Ice Box - Gose with Cherries and Lime
review:
['3.85/5\xa0\xa0rDev +2.7%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 4 | overall: 3.75Released at the SoPro Taproom in June 2019 on draft and in pint 4-pks., and subsequently on a limited basis in limited markets.

First had this Icebox upgrade at the 2019 Mississippi Craft Beer Festival, Fondren, Jackson, Mississippi, poured from pint can, no date on bottom, into taster glass, and have had on draft into clear plastic beer cup.

This is a very interesting effort. Both beautiful and ugly in appearance, as it’s a slightly hazy deep ruby red, marred by all kinds of (fruit? yeast?) floaties, and the light pink head disappears immediately. Aromas of cherry, cherry skin, lime and brine clash a bit, but on drinking the lime helps generate a crisp finish.\xa0673 charactersBigGold, Sep 02, 2019']

name: The Pink One
review: ['4.25/5\xa0\xa0rDev +3.7%look: 4.25 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.25one of the best gose types i can recall. certainly of the fruited variety, this thing is king. on tap at the new tivoli brewery, which is an awesome stop in and of itself, the best kept beer secret in denver really. they distribute all these awesome other breweries now, so always a good spot to try something new. this one is done with raspberries and something lemon, verbena maybe, and its amazing. tangy on two fronts, fruit and lacto, and its a wonderful fusion. sharp enough, but drinkable to infinity, which i feel like so few of these are. it seems to have a little more body and a little more oomph than most, and its a great combo. lemongrass and hops even on the finish, its more dynamic than it seems like it should be, and at this super low abv, its a beer i could have ten of. these guys deserve a ton of credit, and are probably one of the most underrated brewers in our state here. a top notch gose with a twist, refreshing and unique, do they package this one? if not it should be next on the list. love everything about it, and the carbonation is awesome too. yum!\xa01,082 charactersStonedTrippin, Dec 14, 2015']

name: Sunflower Fields Forever
review:
['4.35/5\xa0\xa0rDev +0.5%look: 4.25 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.25Pours a murky pinkish purple with a half inch pink head that settles to a ring and leaves spotty lacing, no visible carbonation. Smells of berries, sunflower seeds and salt. Tastes of blackberries, cranberries, sunflower seeds, floral notes and salt. Mild to moderate tartness, on the light side if medium bodied for the style, light carbonation, slightly puckering and dry finish.\xa0382 charactersEMH73, Oct 02, 2019', '4.3/5\xa0\xa0rDev -0.7%look: 5 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.25From a 16 oz. can into a Willi Becher style glass, this beer pours out like a fruit smoothie/berry color; pomegranate. Light sea foam pink crown. 

The nose brings a punch of berries along with a nice salinity. Floral stays faintly throughout the whole thing. Sunflower seeds. 

The taste brings the blackberries up front; dry and seedy before transitioning into the dry floral notes; like sunflower petals. 

Very nice salinity and tartness to it throughout. Thicker for the style, but still remains light enough to be refreshing. 

Overall, I enjoy it.\xa0554 charactersAyatollahGold, Aug 12, 2019']

name: Dry-Hopped Gose
review:
['4.34/5\xa0\xa0rDev +2.8%look: 4 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.25A: Lots of melon with moderately light pineapple, lemongrass hop aromas, followed by lemon, light sourness and slightly salty.

A: Deep gold color, hazy, with a thin dense white head with adequate retention.

T: Lots of melon and light pineapple lemongrass, lemon hop flavors, moderately light sourness with a slightly salty finish.

M: Medium-light bodied with moderate carbonation.

O: Super tasty; the beer has a great balance of components and the hops really complement the beer’s sourness and light saltiness. Very easy to drink.\xa0537 charactersPhil-Fresh, Nov 14, 2017']

name: Guava Mangose
review: ['4/5\xa0\xa0rDev -8.5%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4this is a great beer, a gose done with guava and mango. both of the fruits are really natural in it, i like how much i can appreciate the actual fruit, not some syrupy extract of them, they are flavorful here without being sweet and without corrupting the base beer at all, which stands as fluffy and wheaty and balanced, just tart enough, nicely salted, and with a great body and active carbonation on it, probably amazing on its own even without the fruit, but i like what the fruit contributes a lot here. the salt and lemony lacto seem to highlight the mango and guava perfectly, where citrus might be too acidic, and pineapple too sweet, these two together give it a tropical vibe without turning into less drinkable juice. great tartness here but not too sour, a little more mango than guava but both really fresh and authentic, and a drying briny salt thing at the end with plenty of wheat malt flavor and body. a really well made beer, clean and nicely fruited, very refreshing and drinkable, one of the better ones of these i have had in awhile...\xa01,056 charactersStonedTrippin, Oct 05, 2018']

name: Who Is Keyser Gose? Blueberry Lemon
review:
['4.33/5\xa0\xa0rDev +1.4%look: 4.25 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4 | overall: 4.25Went out on my lunch break at work today to a local deli joint (one which just so happens to make bomb sandwiches, I'll have you know), and stumbled upon this fun little beer being sold in single 16 oz can servings. Of course, when I checked out, I had to grab one, along with a four pack of yet another new Merrimack beer I've not yet had or even heard of. Talk about a solid place to grab a bite to eat! Just finished the other half of my lunch and cracked open this one, so let's get into it!

Pours an almost "cranberry juice"-like color with a quickly-fading head that leaves behind no lace whatsoever. That said, this is a quick sour so I pretty much expect very little due to the presence of lacto, which usually negatively affects head formation and retention. Great, deep color, however... some slight particulate matter floats throughout the beer but it mostly bears a consistent haze.

Nose is blueberry, blackberry, raspberry and the distinct tangy lemon peel note of a lacto-influenced, modernized gose-style ale. I almost get some yeasty funk, too, but it doesn't seem much like Brett so I don't think this has an issue in that regard. It's probably just the way the berries, citrus and base beer interact or something. Loving how rich and present the berry element is here, even with such a small beer. Just really solid.

Flavor is even more on-the-mark, with stemmy blueberry, jammy raspberry and tart cranberry-like notes all vying for attention as the bright lemon peel and semi-chewy wheat beer base steer the palate quite handily. Quick burst of sourness during the transition to the middle of the tongue. Dry and yeasty finish; lightly sweet with more black raspberry-like jam as each sip closes. Super refreshing, perfect body and very drinkable. A very successful fruited gose ale and, I believe, the first canned quick-sour from these talented up-and-coming brewers. I find Merrimack pretty underrated and I hope to be able to find more cans of this so I can stock up for the dog days ahead. Excellent effort!\xa02,034 charactersichorNet, Jul 18, 2017']

brewery: New Orleans Lager & Ale Brewing Company (NOLA)
name: Two For The Sages
review:
["3.13/5\xa0\xa0rDev -7.4%look: 3.25 | smell: 3.25 | taste: 3 | feel: 3 | overall: 3.25CAN:

Pink head. Dark murky red body.

Aroma is very tart, shrieking tart berries and mild sourness.

TASTE: Berry/currant. Not as tart as the aroma promised, but not sweet either. A hint of salt. Tang. Any malt backbone is neutral (probably pale malt and/or wheat malt), bending to the whims of the bacteria and berry. The berry doesn't taste entirely natural, instead skewing towards puree/syrup to its detriment. Why not brew with real berries exclusively?

TEXTURE: Smooth, wet, medium-bodied, thick, somewhat refreshing. Rarely are gosenbiere so thick...this is almost like a liquid air head, pliable with one's tongue. Surprisingly filling for a gose.

OVERALL: I don't know why they saw a need to can this in the 4x16fl oz format...definitely an anticonsumer margin maximizing maneuver. It's a drinkable gose but nothing special...I'd rather seek out Anderson Valley. Not worth the price. Fails to showcase blackberry or sage well, which seems like what they were after. A mundane but drinkable gose that won't dazzle discerning drinkers.


C+ / ABOVE AVERAGE\xa01,066 characterskojevergas, Sep 09, 2019"]

name: Tiki Vibez
review:
['4.03/5\xa0\xa0rDev +8.9%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4L: Poured from a tallboy can to a cylinder glass. Had a muddy orange color and a super cloudy consistency. There was a quarter inch of foamy / fizzy head that quickly dissipated. Not much lacing to speak of.

S: A very good aroma of citrus fruit, tropical fruit, lactose, wheat, and salt.

T: Tasted of a bit of wheat (present throughout; unobtrusive), a bit of lactose (quite fleeting), lots of citrus fruit (orange, in particular), a hint of salt (not too much), and a good shot of tropical fruit (guava). An incredibly tart, sweet, sour, and vibrant. It borders on being cloying, but never crosses the line. Pretty tasty.

F: A well-carbonated beer with a vibrant finish. Medium-bodied.

O: Not your classical gose, but definitely flavorful and unique. Worth a look.\xa0769 charactersavalon07, Jul 21, 2019']

name: Orange Chocolate Lab Gose
review:
['3.46/5\xa0\xa0rDev +2.4%look: 5 | smell: 4 | taste: 3 | feel: 3 | overall: 3.5The bottle has green wax covering the top. I don't see a bottle date.

Appearance: The beer is a black with some dark brown around the edges where light strikes it. It has a short creamy textured head with pock-marks over the surface. The head is a light tobacco stained tan. Good head retention and lacing.

Aroma: There is a bit of charcoal wood and sour cherry aroma to the beer. It has a touch of bakers chocolate that only shows up every now and then, but is mostly present on the first scent. It has a bit of a cordial cherry aroma.

Taste: There is a tartness to the beer which strikes the palate right at the same time that a bitter carbon flavor hits it as well. The flavors don't quite go together and that tartness morphs into a sour milk flavor. The aftertaste is really impressive though; it has this distinct chocolate cocoa flavor which tastes like a real piece of chocolate, and the sourness is cleaned right off the palate. There is also a bit of a lemon flavor that lingers on the palate long after the chocolate is gone.

Mouthfeel: The body feels light for the flavor profile. Carbonation is good. It is a clean beer and easy to drink.

Overall: This beer is a bit of an oddball because it clearly tastes like a Gose but it is also a very dark beer and it tastes like chocolate. From the label, this is made from "Dark wheat malt, chocolate malt, experimental hops, and orange rind." There didn't seem to be any orange flavor to the beer but they really seemed to nail it with the chocolate malt, as it delivers a lot of chocolate flavor. This beer feels very experimental and crazy, so I would recommend it to people who want something a little strange and aren't afraid to step out of their comfort zones. To traditional Gose enthusiasts or orange lovers, I would say it might be worth a try but don't expect a ton of character. The beer does take on an odd souring character to the middle but it is very fleeting and it is quickly replaced by chocolate flavor which makes up for it. I was interesting and worth trying.\xa02,041 charactersteromous, Jun 10, 2019']

name: Squeegee Master
review:
['4.02/5\xa0\xa0rDev -1.5%look: 4.25 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4Poured from the can into a tulip glass.

Very nice clear orange to lemon body, with some good amounts of carbonation. Pours out with a minor gush, but controls a big frothy white head out of the can, and a thick but small retention collar. Good chunk lacing and tall crown too, real nice looking gose.

Base aroma is pretty much straightforward. Good sensing chewy malt on the nose, a little bit of sourness and a touch of lime zest and briney character as well. What a basic gose should smell like.

Palate stays pretty simple. Chewy sensing flavors of wheat with a good bakery density. Parching and mineral light body, but with a hint of malt sweetness just barely accenting a good tartness and salty flavor. Aftertaste is real impressive. A good fresh bakery oven bread finish, mixing in with some of the nice briney salty quality as well. Flirts with a little bit orange and lemon flavors also.

Just a real solid gose, wish people would make them like this.\xa0971 charactersSmakawhat, Nov 10, 2019', "4.13/5\xa0\xa0rDev +1.2%look: 4.5 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4.5 | overall: 4.25Lively pour with a big white head, pale golden color, slightly hazy

Aroma is delicate, soft lemony fruit kind of aroma (from coriander?), slight hint of tartness in the nose.

Has a slightly tart lemon kind of flavor, and a definite presence of salt. Finishes fairly dry, tart and salty. 

Light mouthfeel and fairly high carbonation - definitely seems like the most highly carbonated canned beer I've had from this brewery. Mouthfeel seems perfect to me - scrubs the palate and prepares for the next sip.

Can't say I'm an expert on the style or a huge fan of the style, but this definitely hits the style highlights. Feel like this one came out in late summer or early fall - definitely is a beer for the heat of summer.\xa0728 charactersmpyle, Oct 13, 2019"]

name: Cucumber Gose
review:
["4.29/5\xa0\xa0rDev +0.7%look: 4.5 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4 | overall: 4.5Draft at the brewery
Big pillowy creamy dense head great retention, soapy lacing, very hazy almost opaque orange color

Nose brings plenty of gose out front, tart lemony doughy, lime, hint of salt, with light cucumber, juicy citrus, cucumber juice

Taste brings more of the same but bigger cucumber, again tart lemon lime juicy citrus, light doughy malt, touch biscuity, light salt in the background with nice cucumber juicy up front, dry like cucumber but not gritty, quite tart with nice lactic acid and even a little grapefruit like flavor but not over sour, a little flemmy on the finish and acidic, but dry bready cracker like typical gose, balanced to the gose side with light but noticeable cucumber

Mouth is med to lighter bod, medium to lighter carb, good bright acidity with a little flemmy finish

Overall quite nice, thankfully doesn't get overpowering cucumber but at the same time you can tell it's there, nice tartness and salt levels, although the finish might be a little flemmy for my taste it's within style\xa01,027 charactersjlindros, Jul 17, 2019", "4.23/5\xa0\xa0rDev -0.7%look: 4.5 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.5 | overall: 4.25Picked up a can of this at the brewery.

A - Poured into my Duvel tulip a nice hazy, murky almost brownish golden hue with a fat two finger white head that fades really slowly to leave great lacing and retention. If the color didn't have that almost grayish tint to it this would be a solid 5.

S - Aromas of big creamy wheat, lemons, excellent coriander, little bit of salinity. I'm struggling to get any cucumber aroma whatsoever though, which is a shame as the base gose is just spot on.

T - Taste is similar to the nose with loads of creamy wheat and bright lemon. The coriander is still there but finally I get some cucumber. Bright and crisp almost melon like cucumber flavour before becoming a little tart. The finish has a fair amount of salinity which is even more noticeable when you lick your lips after taking a sip. 

M - Mouthfeel is nicely carbonated, crisp, clean, refreshing. Spot on for the style. 

O - Overall this was a very enjoyable summer time Gose courtesy of Dave at Flying Dreams. His base beer is great as always I do just wish there was more cucumber on the nose and maybe a touch less salt on the finish. Other that that this is a very enjoyable beer. 

Serving Type: Can\xa01,202 charactersrudzud, Jul 05, 2019"]

name: Bea's Beach
review:
['4.3/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4.5 | smell: 4.5 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4 | overall: 4.25Draft at the brewery
Big creamy foamy head with medium retention, some whispy lacing, super hazy cloudy pear juice colour

Nose tart sour lacto funk, light salt note, big doughy creamy wheat, flash of vanilla and honey, all supporting the big lime zest, and lemon lime juice

Taste loads of lime juice up front, zesty lime and lemon lime, mild yoghurt like lacto funk with a Lyme lactic acid, slightly tart, hint of salt, big doughy creamy wheat, but not quite bread dough, light base with plenty of flavor, touch of vanilla and honey before the dry finish gives cracker and bread dough notes, light lime

Mouth is lighter bod, medium carb, a bit light overall but good for summer

Overall pretty solid, nice lime, hint of salt, good low lactic acid and lacto funk, creamy doughy wheat, wish the body was a bit more\xa0815 charactersjlindros, Aug 22, 2019', '4.3/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4.5 | smell: 4.5 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.5 | overall: 4Enjoyed on tap at the brewery today.

A - Poured a nice hazy super pale lemonade like hue with a thin white head that fades to leave a thick halo and light blanket. Really dig this color.

S - Big aromas of lacto and creamy wheat like aroma, very very bright lime aroma, little lemon, flash of salinity. Smells incredibly refreshing.

T - Taste is similar to the nose with loads of lacto and big creamy wheat. The lime is pleasant but not as assertive as on the nose. Finish is lingering lime tartness though the salt is on the lighter side.

M - Mouthfeel is nicely carbonated, bright, crisp, not overly acidic like this style can be.

O - Overall this was a rather enjoyable kettle sour or gose. The citrus is nice, as is the salt, I just wish there was more of it in certain areas.

Serving Type: on tap\xa0806 charactersrudzud, Aug 17, 2019']

name: Sweet Tooth
review:
['4.31/5\xa0\xa0rDev -0.2%look: 4.75 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.5 | overall: 4.25Received this beer from a recent BIF I partook in. I was intrigued that the beer has sour watermelon patch kids in it. I am stoked to try this beer. A gentle pour produced a two finger bright white head. The head dissipated and left lacing on the glass. The color is SRM 12 a medium amber with a golden hue. The clarity of the beer is clear with effervescence. 

The aromas in the beer are salt, toasted malt, wheat, sugar, and fruity notes.

The flavors in the beer are salt toasted malt, wheat, sugar, the sour stuff they use on the candy, fruit, and sugar.

The mouthfeel of the beer is tart and clean. 

The body of the beer is light, high carbonation, and a medium finish. 

Holy Moly, this beer is a Gose with Sour Watermelon Patch Kids. I am completely blown away. A tasty beer and a must try.\xa0804 characterscolts9016, Oct 16, 2018', '4.33/5\xa0\xa0rDev +0.2%look: 4.5 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4.5 | overall: 4.25plenty of wheat and mellow tartness/salinity ... some slightly sweet slightly sour watermellow candies and sweet tarts dancing aorund in there. some may see this as sort of artificial or gimicky but i dont judge at all and overall its pretty enjoyable/interesting!\xa0264 charactersHyptochrons, Oct 13, 2018']

name: No Drama
review: ['4.2/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4 | overall: 416 ounce can into tulip glass; no can dating, but is a recent release. Pours hazy nearly opaque dark brown/ruby red/purple color with a 1-2 finger fairly foamy and fluffy khaki head with solid retention, that reduces to a thin cap that lingers. Nice spotty soapy lacing clings on the glass, with a large amount of streaming carbonation retaining the cap. Aromas of big sour/tart/tangy red raspberries, fruit skin/seeds, lemon, lime, peach, plum, pear, apricot, red/green apple, currant, red grape/wine, coriander, sea salt, hay, straw, grass, cocoa, wheat, cracker, and toasted biscuit; with light peppercorn, lacto funk, and yeast/roasted earthiness. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of raspberries, cocoa, fruity/acidic yeast, coriander, sea salt, and pale/wheat malt notes; with great strength. Taste of huge sour/tart/tangy red raspberries, fruit skin/seeds, lemon, lime, peach, plum, pear, apricot, red/green apple, currant, red grape/wine, coriander, sea salt, hay, straw, grass, cocoa, wheat, cracker, and toasted biscuit; with light peppercorn, lacto funk, and yeast/roasted earthiness. Light-moderate fruity/lactic tart/sourness, fruit tang; light roasted bitterness and spiciness on the finish. Lingering notes of sour/tart/tangy red raspberries, fruit skin/seeds, lemon, lime, peach, plum, pear, apricot, red/green apple, currant, red grape/wine, coriander, sea salt, hay, straw, grass, cocoa, wheat, cracker, toasted biscuit, light peppercorn/lacto funk, and yeast/roasted earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Fantastic complexity, robustness, and balance of raspberries, cocoa, fruity/acidic yeast, coriander, sea salt, and pale/wheat malt flavors; with an awesome malt/tart/sourness and tangy fruit balance; with no puckering/astringent flavors after the finish. Light-moderate increasing dryness from lingering tart/sourness, tangy fruit, and carbonation. Medium-high carbonation and medium body; with a very smooth, moderately creamy/bready/grainy, acidic/tangy/tannic, fairly crisp, and lightly chalky/saline balanced mouthfeel that is great. Zero warming alcohol for 6%. Overall this is a fantastic fruited imperial gose. All around fantastic complexity, robustness, and balance of raspberries, cocoa, fruity/acidic yeast, coriander, sea salt, and pale/wheat malt flavors; very smooth, crisp, and earthy to drink with the modestly acidic/tangy/tannic/drying finish; not overly lactic/salty. Amazing balance of super juicy/jammy raspberries, Lacto complexity, cocoa, coriander, sea salt, and pale/wheat malts against acidity. Minimal residual sweetness from crisp dryness. A highly enjoyable offering, and impressive spot on style example. Not overwhelming on any aspect.\xa02,710 characterssuperspak, Apr 16, 2019']

name: Fruit Train
review:
['4.31/5\xa0\xa0rDev +6.9%look: 4 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4 | overall: 4.25Pours purple with some pink foam.

Smell is tart with notes of raspberries, passionfruit and currants.

Taste is tart and nicely acidic with just a tinge of sweetness. Notes of raspberries, currants, cherries and a subtle hit of passionfruit and salt. Great balance, and no fruit takes over and dominates.

Mouthfeel is thin to medium, with sparkling carbonation.

Overall, a great sour, complex but refreshing.\xa0411 charactersJamFuel, May 07, 2019']

name: Lemon Gose
review: ['3.58/5\xa0\xa0rDev -2.7%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.5also called limon gose from what i gather, which is of course the same thing, inconsequential really, but i have to assume its the same beer. i didnt really know these guys were doing sours, so thats pretty cool. this is fresh and summery, not quite as clean on the fermentation side as it could be, but bright and natural with the lemon in here, and i appreciate that aspect, almost has the taste and texture of lemonade, similar tartness, not overly acidic at all. yellow in color, moderate carbonation, fresh lemon in the nose, a little dirty lacto thing too, but its not there so much when i taste it, just kind of overly simple, not a lot of wheat going on, and not a lot of salt either, just kind of conservative it seems from a recipe standpoint, but its light enough to be real drinkable, especially for the style, and its good to see these guys pushing themselves into some different styles. i bet in future batches this well be tidied up a bit on the souring side, and we will have a real refreshing summer beer. for now, its better than okay but a few obvious tweaks away from something i would be eager to drink again...\xa01,132 charactersStonedTrippin, Oct 01, 2018']

name: Baltic Gose
review:
['3.11/5\xa0\xa0rDev -0.6%look: 4 | smell: 3 | taste: 3 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3L:
-pours a slight cloudy golden with a medium,foamy,white head
-medium carbonation visible
S:
-bready,honey,sugar sweetness,green apple,briney
T:
-white bread,honey,salty,grainy
-low sourness
F:
-medium carbonation
-light to medium body
O:
Drinkable, but not sour or salty enough for a Gose.
Somewhat disappointing because this Brewery has pretty solid sour Ales in their lineup.\xa0380 charactersdrmeto, Mar 26, 2019', "3.29/5\xa0\xa0rDev +5.1%look: 3.5 | smell: 3.25 | taste: 3.25 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.25Pours a pale golden coloration with a large, foamy, lasting head. Smells of grainy, wheaty malt and tart gooseberry, with a hint of sea salt. Taste follows the nose, with notes of grainy, wheaty malt, tart gooseberry, green apple and strong sea salt, with a certain, quite misplaced sweetness as well. Finishes kind of sweet turning a little more tart in the aftertaste, with lots of sea salt lingering on the tongue in an not entirely plesant way. Smooth mouthfeel with a light/medium body and Medium/lively carbonation.

This is just poorly balanced and doesn't have much in common with a classic Gose. Too sweet and excessively salty, while being quite lightly tart and lacking any kind of citric acidity kickback. Also has a light medicinal note to it that comes out more as the beer warms.\xa0794 charactersSnowcrash000, Dec 18, 2018"]

name: Lime Gose
review: ["3.56/5\xa0\xa0rDev +0.8%look: 4 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.5I've had 3 or 4 goses in the past, and this is the only one so far that I've liked! The reason is almost certainly because the saltiness is on the low side for the style (at least compared to what I've had), so if that's what you want in a gose, then you may not like this. The lime flavor works great as well, it adds just a little bit of juicy sweetness. It won't convert me wholeheartedly to the style, but it's a start!\xa0423 charactersUtahBeerPleb, Apr 16, 2018"]
