name: Headbanger Facerip
review:
['3.79/5\xa0\xa0rDev -13.9%look: 4 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 4 | overall: 3.75Pours a deep reddish color with a medium top of pink head that dissolves quickly. 
Aroma is of blue berries and sea salt. 
The taste starts of fruity and sour with strong blueberrie notes. The salty notes is mostly present in the finish. Mouthfeel is smooth and refreshing with a prickly carbonation and a light body. Quite an interesting take on a gose and it works. Nicely refreshing on a sunny day.\xa0402 charactersOlaB, Aug 03, 2019', '5/5\xa0\xa0rDev +13.6%look: 5 | smell: 5 | taste: 5 | feel: 5 | overall: 5Clear deep red with pink head. Little bit of lacing on the glass. 
Smells fruity, blueberries, sweet and tart. 
Taste is absolutely amazing. So refreshing and fruity. The blueberries give it a nice sweet caracter and the salt adds a lot of depth to the feel and taste. 
So freaking easy to drink. At 6.5% abv this is a dangerous beer. I’m going go drink a lot of these!
This beer ripped my face apart - and made me headbang with excitement! Amazing beer, insanely cool artwork, a true masterbrew!\xa0498 charactersHouborg1, Apr 22, 2019']

name: Salty Kiss
review:
['3.78/5\xa0\xa0rDev +1.1%look: 4 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 4 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.75L: It has a wonderful pink rose color with a slight haze. The head is thin and white in color.
S: This beer has a strong lemon smell with hints of hibiscus. I also smell something similar to a mixture of tropical fruit.
T: The Salty Kiss has a lot of lemon in the flavor with a semi-sweet hibiscus finish. The active culture produces a slightly salty finish. 
F: The beer is rather light and easy-drinking. Definitely a beer to be enjoyed on a warm day on the beach!
O: This beer has a wonderful taste and feel. It is easy to drink, isn’t overpoweringly sour, and goes down smooth. I would definitely reccomend this beer if you stop by the Oozlefinch taste room.\xa0664 charactersjustincarrasquillo, Dec 03, 2017']

name: Extra Plenty Ginger Gose
review:
['4.03/5\xa0\xa0rDev +9.8%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4L: Had this beer at Growlers to Go - Short Pump, poured from a can to a pint glass. Had a dirty, brownish-yellow color and a cloudy consistency. There was a quarter inch of foamy / fizzy head that quickly dissipated. Not much lacing here.

S: A light and sweet aroma of ginger, wheat, sea salt, and citrus fruit.

T: Tasted of a moderate amount of wheat (present throughout, but in a subtle way), a tinge of citrus fruit (a little squeeze of lemon), lots of ginger (the dominant ingredient), and a hint of sea salt. This is a light, sweet, and effervescent flavor. It basically mixes ginger ale with beer, and it works.

F: A well-carbonated beer with a vibrant finish. Light-bodied.

O: An easy to like beer. Worth a look.\xa0723 charactersavalon07, Aug 24, 2019']

name: It's Always Sunny
review:
['3.78/5\xa0\xa0rDev +7.4%look: 3.25 | smell: 3.25 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4Hazy fuzzy gold with a white collar.

Smell is cucumber, a little leafy green, like kale, and wild mint.

I taste a little milky Colby cheese, fresh wild mint, and cucumber, leaning tart and finishing dry.

Another refreshing sour by Arkane.\xa0241 charactersSabtos, Mar 27, 2017']

name: AndSoIt Gose Plum
review:
['3.75/5\xa0\xa0rDev +2.5%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.75Served on tap in a snifter glass

Appearance – The beer is served a hazy pink color with a one finger head of fizzy white foam. The head fades very fast to leave a light level of foamy lace on the sides of the glass.

Smell – The aroma of the brew is huge of a sour green apple smell as well as lots of plum and tart cherry. Along with these smells comes some notes of apple cider vinegar and a bit of grass and hay.

Taste – The taste begins with a tart green apple taste with a lot of apple cider vinegar. There is also a rather decent plum and dark fruit taste right at the start which get stronger and stronger as the taste moves forward. At the end some sour lemon and hay as well as a bit of grass come to the tongue, leaving one with a rather sour plum taste on the palate.

Mouthfeel – The body of the brew is on the average to slightly thinner side with a carbonation level that is a little on the higher side. For the sour flavors the thinner body was fantastic all while the carbonation level kept the tastes very lively. 

Overall – A rather decent sour with a nice tart and sour apple taste that is blended well with some darker fruit tastes.\xa01,169 charactersDarkmagus82, Apr 14, 2019']

name: Summer Gose
review: ['3.62/5\xa0\xa0rDev -8.1%look: 3.5 | smell: 4 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.5Unk ABV.\n\nPours golden with a solid quilt of light cream foam. Nose is juicy fruit, a bit too much so, but if toned down a hare, and complemented with just a hint of malt would result in a really fine nose. Nonetheless, I like the nose; I get a ton of tangerine, grapefruit (sweet), orange, pineapple and subtle hints of resin. On second thought, fucken A, good nose. Bitter, not nearly as much flavor as I’d anticipated from the nose. The bitterness is ushered past to reveal, well, body odor flavors. Some peach and weed reside therein. Medium bodied with assertive carb and an off-dry finish. This beer has sooo many qualities that could make it sincerely great. As of now, it’s a decent standby.\xa0705 charactersharrymel, Sep 14, 2012']

name: Juniper Gose
review: ['4.32/5\xa0\xa0rDev +10.8%look: 3.75 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.25i have loved a lot of the barbarian beers so far, but i may love this one the most to date! its a beautiful gose as a base, fluffy feeling, wheaty, tart but not acidic, and with enough of the salt to really give it a briny edge. it also has high carbonation, a clean lacto profile, and some body, all of which i love in the style, and it would be righteous on its own, but they do it up here with lavender, juniper, lime, and some kind of bark they use in tonic, which really does give it a gin and tonic profile, and the flavors here arent subtle at all, its intensely flavored, which i often hate, especially in the kettle sours, but it works so well here, really this blew me away. the lavender adds a neat springy floral element without being perfume, and the aromatics of the juniper are really compatible with it, highlighted by it. the juniper is strong, thankfully the strongest of these added ingredients, but its not the only bold flavor. i get like a lime leaf vibe from the lime, past zest, pungent and sexy, so good with the juniper, and the salt dries it all up fast in the finish. just a little pucker at the end, a spruce note, some lemon from the lacto, and enough wheat to keep it beery. better carbonation than it shows in the glass too, refreshing almost for how flavorful this is. overall amazing gose, they nailed this, and i hope they keep it coming! this is way too good to be a one and done...\xa01,418 charactersStonedTrippin, Jun 26, 2019']

name: Yuzu Gose
review:
["3.94/5\xa0\xa0rDev +2.6%look: 3 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4Look: Hazy straw color. Poured to a head of fine bubbles that dropped back to a thin skiff over less than half the glass in a minute. No lacing left on the glass. Very active fine bubbles rising from the bottom of the glass.
Smell: Light citrus with an overtone of funk. Swirling the glass boosted the funk, some fresh bread yeast, and citrus (lime) peel. There is also some toast.
Taste: Tart, but with some sweetness. The bread/toast scents show up as tasting like a multi-grain bread (not Wonderbread), making a citrus sandwich. The aftertaste is pure citrus.
Feel: Bursts into a creamy foam that slowly becomes coarse. Creates the fine foam even near the end of the glass when there aren't many bubbles left.
Overall: Very pleasant beer. The creaminess of the foam makes the beer feel thicker than it really is. Yuzu is not very common in these parts, so the citrus flavor is hard to place. It is closest to lime. This is like a heavy weight radler.\xa0953 charactersaltstadt, Jun 09, 2019"]

Serving type: on-tap\xa0631 charactersmetter98, Aug 25, 2019']

name: Down It Gose
review:
["3.61/5\xa0\xa0rDev -5%look: 3.5 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 4 | overall: 3.5Had at the Home restaurant in Branford on May 27 into a pint glass. Comes out yellow/straw, fairly clear, with a small head that fades down and doesn't leave lacing.

Very bright and pleasant aroma, some sweet citrus notes evoke fresh lime zest. There's an underlying malt sweetness as well. Flavorwise it is pretty light, touch of grainy malt and a bit of lime sweetness. A bit of tart after the swallow and I don't detect any strong saltiness.

Overall it's pretty refreshing on a hot day, but pretty useless otherwise. A very light Gose.\xa0540 charactersBranfordBound, May 31, 2016"]

name: Lime Gose
review:
["1.87/5\xa0\xa0rDev -31.3%look: 2.25 | smell: 2 | taste: 1.75 | feel: 2 | overall: 1.75L- Typical mid-gold colour of lager. Pours with minor carbonation that quickly clears to a small thin patch. Very slightly hazy.
S- Curious and distinct, woody aroma.
T- Unusual, clear lime, but then with a kind of woody marsh-mallow/nougat perfume note.
F- Feels quite dry, perhaps like a perfumed lager-top (ie with a shot of lime cordial).
O- Distinctive but not to my taste. I lived in Germany for 3 years, tried every beer style I could lay my hands on, but never encountered anything like this there.
Bought from Waitrose for £3/440ml can. BB: Jul/2020
Original listing below by Spike, he's just pipped me to a new listing before, this time while I spotted it and was buying it this lunchtime he was rating it. GoodOnYer, keeps me on my toes! :)\xa0753 charactersJonnoWillsteed, Jul 26, 2019", '3.57/5\xa0\xa0rDev +31.3%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 4 | overall: 3.5440ml can.
L: Clear, pale orange colour with several streams of bubbles and a thin smear of head. Plenty of lacing.
S: Rose’s lime cordial. 
T: Predominantly tastes of lime. Sourness is gentle.
F: Light body with a dry finish. Nicely tart. Subtle carbonation. Very smooth.
O: Super refreshing on a hot day. Lots of lime concentrate. Too much lime for me. Like a sour lager top.\xa0379 charactersSpike, Jul 26, 2019']

name: Key Lime Carousel Gose
review: ['4.51/5\xa0\xa0rDev +9.5%look: 4 | smell: 4.75 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.5if you like key limes, rather love them, this will be the best eight dollar bottle of beer you ever buy. i prefer this many times more than the blood orange version, which is also excellent. it helps that they start the process with an outstanding base gose, light and wheaty, fresh and tangy but not too sour, super clean on the bacterial side of things, no residual weirdness or funk, and just enough salt to really accentuate the fruit. i think its the perfect platform, and i hope they keep going with fruit like pineapple and kiwi, but i digress. the lime in the aroma here is so intense, so natural, more limey than a lime, and its key lime specific, they must have used a ton of fruit. if this is flavored with an extract or concentrate, i need to know what it is, because its far higher quality and truer flavor than we usually see from that method, no clue how they actually do it, but it has my mouth watering like crazy. the flavor is almost just as good, a little tamed by the wheat which i appreciate for the sake of this still being beer, and also for drinkability, but my gosh that lime flavor is intense all the way through. i really love the carbonation, the low alcohol, the dry finish, and the lime burps. so many fruited goses and berliners out there, almost none of them as impressive or intense as this one. a must try from one of the up and comers here in colorado!\xa01,388 charactersStonedTrippin, Dec 28, 2016']

name: Balance Bike - Watermelon Gose
review:
["3.56/5\xa0\xa0rDev -4.6%look: 3.75 | smell: 4 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 3.25 | overall: 3.25Can thanks to rudzud
Pours a nice frothy bubbly head about 1 finger with moderate retention, some lacing, hazy sediment filled pale color

Nose starts with a decent gose, raw doughy malt, bready cracker, little tartness, some green apple, hint of salt, and a touch of watermelon barely any

Taste more gose out front, lots of dough, cracker, malty raw bread dough, some yeasty notes and a little lactic tartness, green apple and a weird flavor I'm not a fan of but i can't put my finger on it, a little sour watermelon candy, a hint of salt on the back end but barely, no real spice, flemmy acidic lemonade on the finish, finally getting a bit more watermelon, like lemonade with a bit of green apple and watermelon

Mouth is light bod, a bit flemmy and acidic, a bit low on the carb, astringent on the finish

overall not bad but has some flaws. Seems to have fermented a bit too much in the can and got some sediment and a little acetaldehyde (green apple), the heavy lactic acid added a nice sourness but added to the astringency as well, watermelon unfortunately was not much, but I did get some decent gose notes\xa01,117 charactersjlindros, Jul 31, 2019", "3.9/5\xa0\xa0rDev +4.6%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 3.25 | overall: 3.75Picked up a 4 pack of this at the brewery. Apparently there is a plumbing issue and as such they cannot actually serve people in the taproom, however, Dave can still brew beer there. Weird; bathrooms finally kick? And occasionally release cans it seems. 5 cases released of this, or presumably 120 cans.

A - Poured into my Duvel tulip a nice just barely chill hazed gold with a thin one finger white head that faded very quickly to leave no lacing and thin wisps.

S - Aromas of slightly sweet watermelon juice. More of a watermelon hard candy or gummy candy than anything. I don't get any salinity on the nose, nor do I get any lemon or spice notes. Heavy swirls just intensifies the watermelon notes. The watermelon is very enjoyable but I don't really get any gose characteristics at all. Blindfolded this smells more like a 'fruit beer' ala 21st Amendment or the type of beer you might get that comes with a watermelon slice on the rim.

T - Taste is more of that sweeter watermelon juice and watermelon candies. There's the gose. Big lactic tartness, wheat like flavour. There's actually some real nice salinity going on as well especially on the finish. Just lingers; if this flavour was plum instead of watermelon I'd say this 100% tasted like Umeboshi. I don't get any herbal notes, no coriander and such which is typical for the style.

M - Mouthfeel is lightly carbonated, body is light, however the finish is very flemmy. I have to swallow a few times afterwards to try and clean out my throat after finishing a sip.

O - Overall this was still surprisingly well. There are plenty of stylistic flaws; quite clear, the flem educing mouthfeel from the acidity was a bit rough, and there really wasn't any herbal notes at all. What elements are good though are quite good. I absolutely love the level of watermelon here which is a difficult flavour to translate in a beer. The salinity is spot on which is something that brewers tend to go light on. This just lacks what makes a gose a gose as this drinks more like a salty, lactic, watermelon beer and while that's not a bad thing, certainly quite enjoyable in the summer, it's hard to go much higher on this beer due to the style flaws. If you could take the base gose that say Westbrook does and give that this level of watermelon it would be just insanely good.

Serving Type: Can\xa02,343 charactersrudzud, Jul 28, 2019"]

review:
['4.49/5\xa0\xa0rDev +1.6%look: 4.25 | smell: 4.5 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4.5 | overall: 4.5L: Had this beer on-tap at The Answer, poured into a snifter glass. Had a blood red color and a super thick, opaque consistency. There was a thin, off white, fairly long-lasting head. Not much lacing.

S: A big, fruity, tart aroma of raspberries, blueberries, sea salt, wheat, and some other light fruit.

T: Tasted of a tinge of wheat (not that much), some blueberries (a mild-tasting fruit most of the time), lots of raspberries, a hint of sea salt,a definite tartness, and light citrus fruit. An incredibly dynamic, very fruity flavor. More complex than I expected, with a lot of character.

O: An interesting and well made gose. Worth a look if you want something different.\xa0747 charactersavalon07, Mar 04, 2018']

review:
["3.83/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4.25 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 3.75L: Had this beer on-tap at Growlers to Go - Short Pump, poured into a pint glass. S: A fruity and sweet, if slightly muted, of berries, citrus fruit, dark fruit, malt, and stone fruit.

T: Tasted of a bit of citrus fruit (lemon and orange, in particular), some stone fruit (cherries, especially), a good shot of berries ( blackberries, a little dark fruit (plums), and a bit of malt (present throughout). This is one of those flavors that's a little on the thin side. All the ingredients are there, but seem muted. Still, it's not a bad mix.

F: A decent amount of carbonation with a lively finish. Medium-bodied.

O: A very much uneven beer, but it has some good qualities. Worth a look.\xa0846 charactersavalon07, Nov 15, 2019"]

name: Dream-A-Colada
review:
['3.81/5\xa0\xa0rDev -8.4%look: 3.5 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.25 | overall: 3.75Had on-draft at the brewery. Poured into a Mug Club mug

As per the brewery, "A kettle-soured gose brewed with pineapple juice, toasted coconut, milk sugar and vanilla"

L: Clear light golden pour. No head worth mentioning... carbonation bubbles coming up through the pour.

S: Tart and fruity... pineapple and coconut.

T.F: Tart up front... some pineapple sweetness to go along with a bit of funk and grain. A touch of salt. Light bodied... carbonation was off... and it felt semi-flat halfwa through. May have been a keg issue (in conjunction with the lack of head). Strong coconut at the finish.

O: A tart and refreshing gose with pineapple and coconut... so it delivered what was promised. The carbonation was off (as above... maybe a keg issue), but it was still super drinkable... went great with a summer meal.\xa0829 charactersEMV, Jul 25, 2019']

name: Braxton Labs Cranberry Gose
review:
['4/5\xa0\xa0rDev +1%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4Cranberry is such a fickle fruit. Even in the culinary world, we have to combine sugar, citrus, spices to make it look decent on a Thanksgiving dinner table. ...and no one touches it. So when the Braxton Labs experimental team turn to the red berry, they have their work cut out for them.

With a sharp tingle to the nose, the red berry, cider, wine and fruit character screams sour fruit. Upon the pour, Cranberry Gose carries a deep blush hue with a spritzy, fast popping froth that looks exactly like sparkling rosé wine. Supple sweetness bounces off the tongue with a hint of hard candy, faint wafer and and a hint of dough. 

Anything that resembles sweetness dissolves quickly off the tongue. All things red berry rushes in and floods the middle palate with notions of redcurrant, cranberry, strawberry, raspberry and cherry. Once the sweetness is stripped from the fruit, the red berry character is nearly indiscernible. Still, a thought of cranberry rises above the rest, skirting just above the underlying fermentation flavors of green apple, white grape, lime and gooseberry that carry into a light finish of berries and salinity.

The moderate tannic bite of cranberry seeds even carry over to the finish with a nearly peppery spice in the absence of any hop flavor, that along with the brisk acidity creates a crisp, clean and refreshing taste. Medium light in body, the beer is fuller, as expected, than berlinerweiss as its mild salt and citron spice provides a rounded finish of redness and piquant tartness.\xa01,524 charactersBEERchitect, Dec 15, 2018', '3.91/5\xa0\xa0rDev -1.3%look: 3.5 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4Cranberry is the choice color. Nose only hints at the tart berry that is to come. Very carbonated. Initial taste hits the jaws with tartness. Very good Gose.\xa0157 charactersKorbynlehr, Dec 15, 2018']

name: Lime Gose
review:
['3.97/5\xa0\xa0rDev +3.9%look: 3.75 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.75Double Nickel Brewing Co. "Lime Goes"
12 fl. oz. can, coded "08/11/16 10:16:11"
$1.99 @ Roger Wilco, Pennsauken, NJ

Notes via stream of consciousness: Typical appearance: very hazy gold-ish, almost brass-colored body without any head or lacing. The aroma displays some sweetish malt, some mineralish character, and just a suggestion of lime. It's pretty inviting whereas sometimes gosebiers can have a kind of odd note to them. On to the flavor... whoah! that's tart. No, I'd call it sour. And it's pretty salty too, I was expecting it to be a little lighter but it's really full-throttle. There's some lime to it, just a little, and it seems completely natural. Obviously there's no bitterness with such acidity, and it finishes quite dry. In the mouth it's medium-light in body, and it's oddly not that carbonated. I thought there'd be some to it, although I understand why you'd want to tone it down with such an acidic bite to it. Maybe that's why there was no head, well, that and the fact that it's a sour beer. So, OK, where do I stand? I appreciate that they went all out with it rather than just making a kind of watered-down version, and I like the level of lime but I do wish it had a little more carbonation to it, it almost seems flat to me, and that doesn't help it. Still, cold on a hot day I wouldn't turn this down. Worth trying for fans of the style. Not their best to date.
Review# 6,227\xa01,407 charactersNeroFiddled, Sep 10, 2018']

name: Meersalz - Passion Fruit
review:
['4.25/5\xa0\xa0rDev -0.5%look: 4.25 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.25Equally as noteworthy as their Raspberry Meersalz, who needs any fruit syrups syrups when you have access to copious amounts of passionfruit to give this German-styled Gose the depth, character and charm but without the sweetness that altered the original Leipzig sour and spice beer. And when you have the brewing prowess of Narrow Gauge the Gose style gets a major tropical upgrade.

Pouring a foggy canary yellow, the Passionfruit Meersalz builds a stark white mesh froth. A succulent and souring scent of tropical fruit tease the nose along with strong impressions of lemonade, white wine and the same gentle drift of citrus, burlap and sea air of other Meersalz varieties. But then the sweetness build impressions of saltwater taffy, pastry tartlet and sourdough on the early palate.

As the sour and wheaten ale splashes the middle palate, the radiant juiciness of passionfruit share hard candy proportions with a succulent sun-kissed sweetness. But then the bracing sourness counters with a crabapple, lime, lemon, gooseberry, white grape sourness. The rounded salinity and perfumy spice of coriander brings the sourness of ale and the copious passionfruit flavors together effortlessly for the late palate.

Medium light bodied for a sour ale, the near dry flavors carry a tremendous sense of culinary art as an offset to the brazen acidity that threaten to dominate the taste. But a medium quick finish leaves a trail of tropical fruit juices and damp burlap closely behind.\xa01,484 charactersBEERchitect, Oct 31, 2019']

name: Chips and Dip
review: ['4.31/5\xa0\xa0rDev +5.6%look: 4 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4 | overall: 4.25On Tap at Little House. Pours a slightly hazy brownish yellow with an inch of head. Virtually no lacing. Sweet and spicy aroma of lime, mango, and habanero. The taste is like a blend of salsa with lime and salt. It really succeeds in capturing the taste of chips and salsa. Mango, salt, lime and light habanero heat at the end. Medium to light body with very little carbonation. Salty while still being a bit sweet and spicy.\xa0425 charactersPicoPapa, Jul 13, 2019']

name: Manticore - Zombie
review:
["4.13/5\xa0\xa0rDev +1.2%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4On tap at Mortalis Brewing in Avon, NY.

This one pours a golden and slightly murky yellow color, with a small head, and not much lacing.

There's a lot in this, and all of it doesn't necessarily come through. It's still pretty delicious. It's mostly passionfruit and lime in here, with a lesser amount of orange creamsicle and pineapple. I don't really get the raisin or cinnamon, but it's still good stuff. There's no salinity to remind you it's a gose, but I don't really mind that.

This is light bodied, slightly creamy, and very drinkable, with a really smooth finish. It's only mildly sour.

This does a pretty good job at imitating the cocktail. This is Mortalis' MO and they do it well.\xa0695 charactersGreesyFizeek, Oct 27, 2019"]

name: Key Lime Goes?
review:
['4.15/5\xa0\xa0rDev -3%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4 | overall: 4.25The base sour style might have roots in northern Germany, but the Germans who originated the recipe never saw this version coming. Key lime, coconut and graham cracker layer over the salty wheat ale with dessert-like effects.

Key Lime Goes? pours with a zesty and expressive champagne-like appearance. Pale straw and frothily headed, the ale leads with the tartness of apple, citrus and tropical fragrances along with a savory graham cracker overlay and a hint of the sea. Saltwater taffy, meringue, praline, graham cracker and cream all come out to play on the early palate while releasing pastry sweetness and the yeastiness of sourdough.

As the ale rolls across the middle palate, its earthiness releases and the premiere tartness resonates loudly with lime but also a background symphony of white grape, crab apple, lemon and a hint of grapefruit. Deeper on the palate still, the roundness of graham cracker brings the savory taste of honey, nuttiness and dry, toasty cake that only graham crackers can bring. The roundness of salinity gives the ale a salty taste of margarita to offset a brisk aftertaste of damp burlap and cork.

Medium bodied for sour ale, the richness of salt and graham cracker eventually releases and the ale finishes crisp, clean and highly refreshing. The ale gives all the delight of key lime pie but at a fraction of the weight or fatigue. Built for seaside drinking sessions, Its acidity cuts through the thirst with ease and ensures a quick aftertaste of wheaten citrus.\xa01,505 charactersBEERchitect, Jan 22, 2018']

name: E09 Mojito Gose
review:
["3.68/5\xa0\xa0rDev +4%look: 3.25 | smell: 4.5 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 3 | overall: 3.5From the 16 oz. can that was canned July 14, 2018. Sampled on July 28, 2018.

Copper-amber pour with a quick head and modest clarity. A chill haze more than anything else.

That's some aroma! Perfume-like. Minty. Lime and citrus zest. Low profile bready malt character.

The body is light to medium and fairly smooth.

The mint and lime characters show up in the taste along with a pucker-up tart sour note and the Gose salt is quite noticeable. I couldn't drink the whole thing not because I didn't like it - but because I'm on a low sodium diet. I rarely drink a Gose anymore even though I know they are cropping up more and more.\xa0639 characterspuboflyons, Jul 28, 2018", '3.39/5\xa0\xa0rDev -4.2%look: 3.5 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.25 | feel: 3.25 | overall: 3.25Can from a Lazy Dog
Pours a mostly clear deep golden color with a small white head that dissipates almost immediately. Nose over the glass reveals a lemony lime salty minty margarita mojito kind of aroma. The taste is more puckering lemon than anything else.Salty lime and hints of crackery malt. Faintly carbonated puckering briny mouthfeel. Medium to thin body. The carbonation disappears almost instantly, if they could find a way to make this more bubbly longer it might be great but as is its meh.\xa0502 charactersjohnnnniee, Jul 21, 2018']

review:
["4.88/5\xa0\xa0rDev +9.9%look: 4.75 | smell: 4.75 | taste: 5 | feel: 4.5 | overall: 5Snifter at the brewery

A medium straw color with pure white head that fades fairly quick. Hazy/ opaque
Smells of wheat/ grain followed by herbal hops and an unfamiliar sour/ salty aroma
Has some grainyness followed by a medium low tartness and a bit of salt.
Very drinkable and thirst quenching

This is the best un-fruited gose I've had. Others have been way too saltly to enjoy, or tasted like sweat. This one is very tasty and drinkable.\xa0441 charactersPinto21, Nov 05, 2015"]

name: Salty Paul
review:
['4/5\xa0\xa0rDev +5.5%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4On-tap 11/25/2016 at Pour Farm Tavern in New Bedford, MA, served in a US tumbler pint glass.

A: The beer is a light cloudy yellow color, with a short white head that fades slowly and leaves a thin lace on the glass.

S: The aroma contains wheat, citrus, light malts and a faint touch of hops.

T: The taste starts out bready with flavors of wheat and a light malt character. Then some mild citrus tartness comes in. The hops presence is very mild as you would expect from this style but it provides a good balance. The after-taste is slightly bready and slightly tart.

M: Crisp and smooth, light-to-medium body, medium carbonation, finish is clean and dry.

O: Tasty, goes down easily, not too filling, very mild kick, good representation of style, this is a solid beer to drink for a while if you’re in the mood for the style.\xa0831 charactersTheManiacalOne, Nov 25, 2016']

name: Blueberry Gose
review:
['4.23/5\xa0\xa0rDev +2.4%look: 4.25 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.25Appearance : The beer poured a reddish-purple color with white bubble crowning the pour. 

Smell - The nose had blueberry pie notes with little sourness. 

Taste - The initial impression was bright sour blueberries with a salty sourness. The wheat gives the impression of pie crust. the sour lingered as the blueberries grew progressively more tart in the dry finish. 

Mouthfeel - The carbonation was appropriate for the style and brushed away the sweetness. 

Overall - This is an odd take on the style, but it is quite good.\xa0527 charactersJohnnyHopps, Feb 18, 2018']

Quite refreshing, certainty on a hot day.\xa0337 charactersTripel_Threat, Jun 20, 2019']

name: Gose
review:
["3.4/5\xa0\xa0rDev +2.1%look: 3 | smell: 3 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.75Served in straight pint glass. Poured a clean, clear medium-dark amber color with about 1/2 inch of light tan head that low retention and no lacing. This beer was much darker than any other example of the style I've tried, but I haven't had a lot of them.

The aroma was mostly gentle malts, with just a bit of yeast spice adding some balance. On the tongue, the beer had a good grain flavor, just a trace of salt, a touch of yeast and a clean, dry finish.

The body was good, nicely smooth and even. Drinkability was pretty good, the beer went quickly and smoothly. Overall, a nice little beer, it's good to see the brewery try a style that's not widely done in the PNW. Worth a shot if you see it.\xa0703 charactersbeertunes, Jan 20, 2013"]

Aroma is vanilla and light peach, pleasant enough but approaching milkshake/candy territory.
Taste is lightly tart with prominent peach and vanilla, the artificial lactose twang throws it off a little.
Medium bodied, tart but sweet, not all that refreshing. Not really sure how this is still a Gose with lactose and vanilla added. 
Worth trying a taster, but a full glass was too much.\xa0481 charactersemerge077, Jun 17, 2019']

name: Jose Gose!
review:
['4.25/5\xa0\xa0rDev -1.4%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4.5 | overall: 416 ounce can into tulip glass, canned on 8/13/2019. Pours fairly hazy/cloudy medium golden yellow color with a 1 finger dense and rocky white head with great retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Nice dense spotty soapy lacing clings on the glass, with a light amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of big sour/tart/tangy lemon, lime, tomato, orange, peach, pear, melon, red/green apple, white grape/wine, sea salt, habanero peppers, hay, straw, grass, wheat, cracker, white bread, light lacto funk, and yeast earthiness. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of tomato, lime, sea salt, peppers, fruity/acidic yeast, and pale/wheat malt notes; with big strength. Taste of big sour/tart/tangy lemon, lime, tomato, orange, peach, pear, melon, red/green apple, white grape/wine, sea salt, habanero peppers, hay, straw, grass, wheat, cracker, white bread, light lacto funk, and yeast earthiness. Light-moderate fruity/lactic tartness, and pepper spiciness on the finish. Lingering notes of tart/tangy lemon, lime, tomato, orange, peach, pear, melon, red/green apple, white grape/wine, sea salt, habanero peppers, hay, straw, grass, wheat, cracker, white bread, light lacto funk, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Fantastic complexity, robustness, and balance of tomato, lime, sea salt, peppers, fruity/acidic yeast, and pale/wheat malt flavors; with a fantastic malt/tart/tangy/spiciness balance; with no puckering/astringent flavors after the finish. Fairly crisp finishing. Light-moderate increasing dryness from lingering tart/tangy/spiciness. Medium carbonation and light-medium body; with a very smooth, moderately creamy/grainy, and acidic/tangy/sticky/saline balanced mouthfeel that is fantastic. Zero warming alcohol for 4.6%. Lightly increasing pepper heat after the finish through the glass, but not overwhelming. Overall this is a fantastic fruit/vegetable/spiced gose. All around fantastic complexity, robustness, and balance of tomato, lime, sea salt, peppers, fruity/acidic yeast, and pale/wheat malt flavors; very smooth and fairly crisp/refreshing to drink with the mellowly acidic/tangy/spicy/drying finish. Not overly lactic, spicy, or saline. Perfectly balanced juicy tomato, lime, salt, peppers, and Lacto complexity; with a great pale/wheat malt backbone against acidity. Minimal residual sweetness with crisp acidic/tangy/spicy dryness. A highly enjoyable offering, and outstanding spot on experimental style example. Not overwhelming on any aspect.\xa02,515 characterssuperspak, Oct 22, 2019', '4.37/5\xa0\xa0rDev +1.4%look: 4.25 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4.5 | overall: 4.5L: Ice tea coloration, nearly clear with a one finger tight bubbly head fading to a sparse cap and ring and little lacing.

S: Smells exactly like a blended tomato salsa. Fresh and salty!

T: Follows the nose with the right heat and a lingering saltiness. Lime also. A little of a warm sweaty aftertaste.

F: Light to medium weight with high carbonation. Refreshing.

O: Wow this is really neat - Gose may be my new beloved style.\xa0430 charactersOh_Dark_Star, Sep 22, 2019']

name: Lime Margarita Gose
review:
["3.79/5\xa0\xa0rDev +7.7%look: 3.5 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 4650ml bottle - made with salt, lime juice, and a 'splash of Tequila'. And at 4.5% ABV, I won't be wastin' away again, in, uh, what's that place called again?

This beer pours a hazy, medium golden yellow colour, with three fingers of puffy, chunky, and somewhat shiny bone-white head, which leaves a bit of crooked tree branch lace around the glass as it quickly dissipates.

It smells of acrid lemon/lime rind, white saltine crackers, gritty and grainy cereal malt, some earthy vegetal character that may or may not be Tequila, and faint leafy, herbal, and musky floral green hop bitters. The taste is semi-sweet, bready and grainy pale malt, lime cordial, a further muddled and candied tropical fruitiness, seawater, and more well-understated earthy, herbal, and grassy hoppiness.

The carbonation is quite active in its aggressive frothiness, the body a so-so middleweight, and mostly smooth, once you get acclimatized to the tart 'n sugary lime essences endemic here. It finishes off-dry, saltwater taffy soaked in lime juice the basic lingering impression.

Overall - this comes across as a lot more heavy and full-flavoured than I was anticipating (they seem to have found that lost shaker of salt) so, good! I can't deny that it bears a strong resemblance to a salt-rimmed lime margarita, just sans the alcohol kick - oh well, can't have everything, I suppose.\xa01,371 charactersbiboergosum, Mar 28, 2018"]

name: Tamarindo Gose
review:
['2.75/5\xa0\xa0rDev -18.4%look: 3.5 | smell: 2.75 | taste: 2.75 | feel: 2.75 | overall: 2.5A: Pours a pinkish/red color. At first a two finger white head forms and recedes in a second. No lace is left behind.
S: Up front, I get a quick whiff of buttery popcorn...diacetyl That quickly fades to some generic fruit sweetness. Which is pleasant at first. Though as this warms more buttery aromas come out.
T: Like the nose, a quick draw back from buttery flavors. I can only guess diacetyl. Fruity sweetness comes next, not really tart, not really "sour" and certainly not well defined. Buttery flavors grow as this warms...
M/O: A light body, thin, no snappy carbonation. Just kind of limp and nondescript. I finished the pint as fast as I could. Just not something I want to come back to.

At first I did not trust myself, but as this warmed I definitely got buttery diacetyl. Not a lot of fruit character, not a lot of tartness, or anything that I would consider "sour." I have heard a lot of good things with their Gose variations, this did not do it for me though. Maybe I am a little over sensitive, or my tastes just off, but was not happy with this.\xa01,082 characterschamp103, Jan 30, 2017']

name: Swimmin’ Trunks
review:
["4.75/5\xa0\xa0rDev +8.7%look: 4.75 | smell: 4.75 | taste: 4.75 | feel: 4.75 | overall: 4.75Brewed with lots of real limes. Limes jump out at you the moment you open the can. It's an exceptional beer in many ways. The main tasting note is of course lime, and underneath is a traditional pale ale, savory and refreshing. The flavor is top notch, it makes Bud Lime or Lime-A-Rita look like a joke. It's sporting a high ABV and a clean finish. Drinking all 4 cans is a possibility you should prepare for.\xa0409 charactersDrBeergood, Nov 09, 2019", "3.98/5\xa0\xa0rDev -8.9%look: 3.5 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 4Hazy orange-yellow with a thin ring.

Extremely tart and juicy lime and orange zest are amped up to 11 by the gose elements, like salted a margarita rim.

The crisp tingly medium-light body has a just dry finish.

At first this is delicious, but it then becomes a bit taxing on the palate. It's not sour like a traditional sour, it's literally from the excessive amount of citrus juice in here!\xa0394 charactersSabtos, Jun 10, 2019"]

name: Dream Cannon No. 6: Summer Sorbet
review:
['4.55/5\xa0\xa0rDev +2.7%look: 4.5 | smell: 4.5 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4.5 | overall: 4.75"Sour Ale Brewed with cherries, tangerines, orange juice and lactose."
Personally never had any of their gose style ales but it sounds like a winner. Poured into a pint glass. Well the cherries really added that fruity red color that I love which makes for a 1/2 inch of pink frothy foam. Smell is subtle but complex standard sour lemon and salty fanfare mixed with some fruity cherry and tangerine which I can clearly smell even though my smelling sucks. Taste is also nice not too sourly puckering but it does have a nice level of fruit juice flavors which balances with the tart base of the beer. In a way its perfectly balanced and not watery at all yet easy to crush. I love it...

Overall the body is light and with easy fruit to gose body this beer dare I say is the perfect summer brew. Picked it up at the Carson Street Deli for about 4 bucks so a bit pricey but to me one of the best fruit gose style beers I have had as of late. Try it!\xa0947 charactersDrDemento456, Jul 07, 2019']

name: Endless Ride - Blackberry and Mandarin Orange
review:
['4.03/5\xa0\xa0rDev +3.6%look: 4.25 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 45 oz in stemless glass at brewery.

Appearance: Wow, what color. Looks kind of like a V8. It’s a dark ruby with minimal head. Some lace. A really arresting, atypical color.

Aroma: Fruit! Blackberry and orange, as promised. Some funk too.

Taste: Nice funky character along with fruitiness. Blackberry definitely leads the way. Orange is a note. Kinda sour. Tart. Not much salt.

Mouthfeel: Very drinkable and juice-like. 

Overall: Really terrific fruit sour. Fun series, too.\xa0479 charactersillpass78, Jan 27, 2019']

name: Dry Hopped Gose
review:
["3.83/5\xa0\xa0rDev +2.4%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 4 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.75A: The beer is rather hazy yellow in color. It poured with delicate white lacing on the surface and a collar consisting of medium-sized bubbles around the edge of the glass.
S: Light to moderate aromas of lemon citrus are present in the nose.
T: The taste follows the smell and has flavors of lemon and lime citrus along with some sourness.
M: It feels light- to medium-bodied on the palate and has a moderate amount of carbonation.
O: This gose isn't nearly as sour compared to others in the style but has a nice amount of citrusy aromas and flavors.

Serving type: can\xa0571 charactersmetter98, Dec 02, 2018"]

name: Zwinger
review:
["4.5/5\xa0\xa0rDev +5.4%look: 4.25 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.75 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.5Received a can of this as an extra in a trade. Finally! A can from Arkansas!

A - Poured into my Duvel tulip a nice mostly clear dark straw with a two finger white head that faded relatively quickly to leave a thin, wispy head.

S - Aromas of lemons, salt, berries, little bit of tropical notes. Smells like the dry hop could be Galaxy. Quite pleasant and aromatic!

T - Taste is similar to the nose. Enormous lemon notes, almost sweet tart candy like, nice salt, decent tropical fruit note just like a blend of pineapple and mango. Tart, little salty fruit salad. Wow!

M - Mouthfeel is nicely carbonated for the style, not flemmy, body is nice.

O - Overall this caught me completely off guard. Really good vibrant base gose which the dry hopping really amps up with tropical notes. I'd love to have this up here in for the summer months!

Serving Type: Can\xa0859 charactersrudzud, Oct 04, 2018"]

name: Chocolate Cream Pie Gose π Edition
review:
["3.98/5\xa0\xa0rDev -0.7%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 4The effects of pastry favors have no bounds as to which beer style will see its influences next. And at the Westbrook brewhouse, this means gose: the Northern German sour ale with corriander and salt with the complementary flavors of chocolate cream pie for a yin-and-yang of emotions as well as taste.

Pale gold and draped in a fine mesh haze, Chocolate Cream Pie shows no chocolaty tone in sight but once its soapy froth settles the nose picks up on the gentle savory sweetness of chocolate, vanilla and cream over a tangy backdrop of citrus, cider and sourdough. Taffy sweet maltiness greets the tongue with a lightly plump taste with a soft breadiness in tow.

Its sweetness drifts away as the ale launches onto the middle palate where the citrusy tones reveal the taste of lime, lemon, green apple, gooseberry, guava and white grape. Just like in scent, the subtlety of chocolate is simple and understated while adding a fullness in taste that's backed by the sweetness of cream, vanilla and coconut for a beer that's as well suited for the dessert menu as it is the beer menu.

Medium light in body, the gently spiced Gose ale trends dry, crisp and refreshing despite its decadent tilt toward the savory. In a short and citrusy finish, a hint of chocolate lingers briefly on the after palate. I've never experienced something chocolatey also being refreshing. I learned something today.\xa01,393 charactersBEERchitect, Aug 20, 2019", "4.04/5\xa0\xa0rDev +0.7%look: 4.25 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4L: Had this on-tap at Westbrook's tasting room, poured into a taster. Had a bright, golden yellow color and a hazy consistency. There was a quarter inch of foamy, fairly long-lasting head. Pretty good lacing.

S: A very nice aroma of chocolate, a creamy quality, citrus fruit, and malt as well.

T: Tasted of a tinge of citrus fruit (a little lemon), some light malt notes (mostly in the finish), a fair amount of chocolate (kind of lingers around), and a creamy quality (present throughout). A light, sweet, and surprisingly subtle flavor. It's not quite as sour as some goses, but rather it has a nicely understated quality. Pretty tasty.

F: A well-carbonated beer with a lively finish. Light-bodied.

O: A solidly made gose. Worth a look.\xa0742 charactersavalon07, Aug 01, 2019"]

name: Gose Beer
review: ["3.66/5\xa0\xa0rDev +2.2%look: 4.25 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 4 | overall: 3.5I am in love with the sour beer craze and goze beers in general. I also love Deschutes so I was happy to show up for lunch and see that I was going to get to try a Deschutes gose. This one was silky, had no head and looked light. Nothing shocking there - the mouthfeel is also light and smooth - excellent stuff. My main issue with the beer is flavor. It's not all that sour, not all that crisp, not all that anything. It's certainly not bad either, just doesn't have much boldness or character that I have come to expect from Deschutes.\xa0537 characterschugamugofsud, Jun 12, 2013"]

name: Blackbelly
review: ['3.75/5\xa0\xa0rDev +3.3%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.75i have truthfully liked all of the beers i have had out of their denver location so far, this one included. its a neat gose with some special salt from what i understand, black or smoked or both, but the salt isnt over the top or even that obvious to me as different or special in here, it just tastes like a well made gose. i do get some faint alderwood type smoke in the nose, really compatible with the fuller wheat base here, but its super subtle, a nuance at the most, earthy though and sort of an autumnal vibe to a style that usually screams summer to me. good clean tang on it, fairly sour once i taste it, but not stomach turning either, and still refreshing when ice cold. hops are minimal in flavor but there is a nice bitterness that comes in at the end, a lightly acrid (in a good way) thing from the smoke and minerals too, clever and good. not as light bodied as a lot of them, but i dont mind that here. everyone is making gose these days, not sure of a style with a faster or more widespread resurgence than this over the past couple of years, and more and more they are starting to all taste the same. its nice to have something a little different here, i thought this was great.\xa01,197 charactersStonedTrippin, May 07, 2018']

name: Salt N' Peppacorn Gose
review:
['3.43/5\xa0\xa0rDev -2.3%look: 4 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 3.25 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.5A thanks to the man who added this beer, woodychandler, for this beer. Poured from a 12 oz. can. Has a bright golden color with a 1/2 inch head. Smell has plenty of salt, some lemons. Taste is of salt and lemons, I feel like a shot of tequila should be involved, dry at the finish. Feels medium bodied in the mouth and overall is a decent beer.\xa0344 characterstone77, Jun 05, 2018', '3.59/5\xa0\xa0rDev +2.3%look: 3.5 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 3.25 | overall: 3.75I picked up a mixed 12-pack of CANs at Shady McGrady's in Harrisburg during a recent visit. This CAN was among them & came from their production facility in Export, PA for inclusion in The CANQuest (tm).

From the CAN: "Malt beverage with sea salt and peppercorn added".

I agitated it in the CAN prior to the Crack! & when I did Crack! it open, I got a little bit of foaming through the vent. An inverted Glug produced an unbidden finger of fizzy, foamy, bone-white head that quickly faded to wisps. Color was an-oh-so-faintly hazy Golden-Amber (SRM = > 5, < 7). Nose was very salty with a lemony tartness & just a hint of peppery spiciness. Mouthfeel was kind of thin & watery. The taste, while salty, was not as sharp & challenging as some that I have tried. It definitely tasted of wheat with a light lemony tartness, but I was not really getting the peppercorns. Drinking through it, I just kept getting wave after wave of lemon and salt, salt & lemon, but not much else. It was a refreshingly dry drink that went down very quickly, but I was left feeling unfulfilled.\xa01,073 characterswoodychandler, Feb 23, 2018']

name: Ice Box - Gose with Coconut, Vanilla and Lemon
review:
['4.12/5\xa0\xa0rDev +1.5%look: 4 | smell: 4.5 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4Released at the SoPro Taproom in June 2019 on draft and in pint 4-pks., and subsequently on a limited basis in limited markets.

First had this Icebox upgrade at the 2019 Mississippi Craft Beer Festival, Fondren, Jackson, Mississippi, poured from pint can, bottom stamped (apparently) canned on “05/21/19 COCOBOX,” into taster glass, and have had on draft into nonic pint.

The ABV boost, added coconut and smoothing and sweetening vanilla and lactose, with the existing big lemon and zest bite, make for a bigger, more complex and, oddly, more quaffable beer than the original Icebox.\xa0589 charactersBigGold, Aug 06, 2019']

name: Nice and Brite Gosè
review:
['4.17/5\xa0\xa0rDev -4.8%look: 3.5 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.5 | overall: 4.25Poured into a Samuel Adams perfect pint glass. No best by/brew date. Poured from a can.

Appearance: light ‘lager’ look. Small head, With minimal retention. Slightly hazy at the top of the glass, other wise very clear. No lacing.

Smell: slight lemon/citrus. Strongest scent is of the elderflower, giving a berry and slight floral scent. With hints of wheat. 

Taste: not overly sour, taste is of heavy lemon flavor, and taste is akin to watered down lemon aid. No real taste of the berry flavor. 

Feel: not a heavy beer at all, very light and drinkable.

Overall: would be a perfect summer beer for drinking while at the beach, lake, or just outside in general. Has a refreshing feeling of lemon aid, not very sour; so if you like sours for their sourness this might not be for you. For me, it’s the perfect amount of sourness. Can drink a few of these easily.\xa0868 charactersJefeLopez, Oct 27, 2019']

name: Sunrise Gose
review:
["3.74/5\xa0\xa0rDev -3.4%look: 3.5 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.75355ml can - not the cranberry version, as far as I can tell.

This beer pours a slightly hazy, medium golden yellow colour, with three fingers of puffy, loosely foamy, and ultimately fizzy off-white head, which leaves absolutely nothing in the way of lace anywhere near the glass as it quickly evaporates.

It smells of gritty and grainy cereal malt, generic citrus rind, saltine crackers, a hint of tart yeastiness, and some plain earthy, musty, and floral noble hop bitters. The taste is grainy and bready pale malt, sour apples, indistinct citrus peel, wan coriander and salt spice, some mild lacto, and more understated leafy, herbal, and musky floral green hoppiness.

The carbonation is fairly active in its palate-pinging frothiness, the body an adequate middleweight, and generally smooth, as the tartness here isn't all that threatening. It finishes off-dry, the grain, citrus, and faded spice arranging themselves as such.

Overall - this comes across as a well-made example of the style, nice and crisp and refreshing. And with the very session-friendly ABV, one could put back a sixer of these no problem over the course of an afternoon whilst grilling up something meaty on the ol' BBQ, methinks.\xa01,212 charactersbiboergosum, May 15, 2018"]

name: A Mango & Key Lime Get Salty
review: ['4/5\xa0\xa0rDev -5.2%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4"The second in our series of margarita-inspired sour beers. Brewed with heaps of malted wheat, just a touch of lactose and the Himalaya\'s finest pink sea salt. Soured in the kettle with our mythical house lactobacillus culture for a refreshing lemony sourness. Conditioned on mountains of mango and lime puree for pronounced fruitiness and zesty tartness. One sip and you\'ll feel like you\'re on a beach in Cancun... Plan your dream vacation now."\n\n10 oz draft. Probably a 7.5 of 10 on the sour scale. Decent amount of fruit but less than I expected. Nice wheatiness and salinity. An interesting beer but I wish there was more mango.\xa0632 charactersLucular, Sep 05, 2019']

name: Farmhouse Berry Gose
review:
['4.09/5\xa0\xa0rDev -5.5%look: 3.75 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4 | overall: 412 ounce can - $2.99 at Total Wine & More in Kennesaw, Georgia.

Appearance: Pours a lightly hazed, light reddish-pink tinged body with a collapsing, whitish head.

Smell: Spritzy, berry infused aroma with a tangy undertone of lactic sourness stink.

Taste: Very light flavor of wheat with a dose of berry juices cut by curt hints of berryskins. Soft tartness, modest sweetness with a blended berry taste. Its salinity and lactic qualities remain comparatively light. Maintains its lightly tart, sweet berry flavor through the finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-light body. Medium carbonation.

Overall: A competent gose that features ample berry taste without feeling the need to overdo it, so you're still aware you're drinking a beer (welcome) instead of some "adult" smoothie (absolutely unwelcome).\xa0795 charactersChainGangGuy, May 11, 2019']

name: Distant Dreams
review: ['3.99/5\xa0\xa0rDev -0.2%look: 3.75 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4a pleasant gose here, not too sour, even my dad liked it, refreshing, and done with pink sea salt, kiwi, and lime. i think the lime is the dominant element, but the salt and tartness are nice too, this almost drinks like a margarita, nice for the summer, and the low alcohol is on point, i wish for more beer like this in the world. its got some deeper color to it, an orange tint, and a nice head from the tap. aroma here is puckery citrus and lactic tang, lots of fresh lime, more zesty and essential oily than fleshy and acidic, and there is a cool floral note here. its hard to smell kiwi, more of like a honeydew melon thing for me, and the bigger wheat malt base is also evident here. clean enough in the fermentation and the souring, nice job with that. the flavor is lime driven for sure, but i do get some neat tropical character from the kiwi and a little bit of sweetness fighting to hang on. i love how low the acidity is, more drinkable than most of these because of that, and i like the high carbonation and round body as well, this feels great for the style, and the salt plays an obvious role in that too. i like the inclusion of the kiwi, something a little different here, but i do wish it was just a little more forward in the flavor mix. other than that, this is summery and drinkable and delicious, juicy and refreshing, yum.\xa01,346 charactersStonedTrippin, Aug 13, 2019']

name: Redemption Gose
review:
['3.88/5\xa0\xa0rDev +0.3%look: 3 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4Serving: Can
Canned: Apr-5-2019 (Consumed Jun-9)


It pours pretty murky with very short-lived head. Meh. The aroma hits you with strong floral funk, sage, coriander. The flavor follows with light tartness, a rich full-but-light-on-its-feet malt character, lime; there is a lovely little tingle and a touch of saltiness at the finish. It is very easy to drink and refreshing, active carbonation. This is a very nice beer. It is not the most attractive but is very nicely balanced and refreshing while still being a little substantive. Very enjoyable and great for a hot day.

3...3.75...4...4...4\xa0596 charactersTheDoctor, Jun 10, 2019']

name: Never More³
review:
["4.25/5\xa0\xa0rDev -0.2%look: 4.25 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.25L: Had this beer on-tap at Growlers to Go - Short Pump, poured into a pint glass. Had a purplish color and a thick, viscous, almost smoothie-like consistency. There was a quarter inch of foamy, off-white, fairly long-lasting head. Excellent lacing.

S: A sweet and enticing aroma of several types of berries, malt,, wheat, salt, and citrus fruit.

T: Tasted of a bit of malt (mostly in the finish, overpowered by fruit), a pinch of salt (barely present), a whole ton of berries (blackberries and raspberries), and a hint of citrus fruit (lemon, perhaps?). An extremely fruity and sweet flavor. The berries dominate everything, but that's okay. Tasty stuff.

F: A fair amount of carbonation with a smooth and creamy finish. Medium-bodied.

O: A slightly unusual, but likable gose. Drinkable.\xa0790 charactersavalon07, Aug 31, 2019"]

name: New Wave Gose z Jagodą (Blueberry)
review: ["3.19/5\xa0\xa0rDev +0.6%look: 3.5 | smell: 3.25 | taste: 3 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.25Pours a cloudy, deep, dark purple coloration with a tiny, fizzy, quickly dissipating head. Smells of light biscuity malt and sweet blueberries, not much else going on here. Taste is dominated by sweet blueberry and lactose notes, with some light biscuity malt coming through as well, but really not a lot of tartness/acidity noticeable. Finishes sweet'ish, with some blueberry lingering in the aftertaste. Smooth mouthfeel with a light/medium body and carbonation.\n\nI've really enjoyed everything I've had by AleBrowar so far, but this just doesn't cut it at all for a Gose. Way too sweet, with almost no tartness or acidity present. It's almost like they brewed this with lactose exclusively, without any lactobazillus. Taste more like a blueberry soda than anything else really.\xa0780 charactersSnowcrash000, Jun 29, 2019", "3.15/5\xa0\xa0rDev -0.6%look: 3.5 | smell: 2.75 | taste: 3.25 | feel: 3.25 | overall: 3.25Bottle shared @ KJUBZT tasting June 2019. Pours a hazy reddish colour with a pinkish white head. Aroma's of lactic acid, some weird things, hard to describe, fruit, really weird. Retronasal it's mostly lactic acid and fruit. Flavour is moderate sweet and fruity, light sour, light salty. Light bodied. Long buttermilky finish.\xa0326 charactersArjen, Jun 16, 2019"]

name: Freigeist/ Ritterguts - Coolship Urgose 1375
review: ["3.83/5\xa0\xa0rDev -0.8%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.75Had on tap. So with the 1940's yeast, this beer is older than me, or at least one major component, pretty cool. I'll just say up front this was a weird beer. From the burnt orange body to the flowery and woody feel, gose is not the style I would have ever guessed if blind tasted. The gose yeast and slight pucker is there... somewhere in the finish. Otherwise the coolship treatment has provided a ton of wood, citrus zest, a lightheartedness to the sour and acid. The cinnamon hits hard in the smell but very faintly in the near finish in the taste.\xa0557 charactersREVZEB, Oct 31, 2019"]

name: Black Currant Gose
review:
['4.24/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 5 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.25Picked up at the brewery. Shared with JLindros.

A - Poured into a Kate the Great tulip a nice hazy dark purple red hue with a one finger fuchsia head that fades to leave light wisps and nice lacing.

S - Aromas of big lemons and creamy wheat. Nice tartness, light coriander. The black currant notes are really really subtle.

T - Taste is similar to the nose with excellent lemons and creamy wheat. Good tartness, some very light red berry notes. The currants are pleasant but subtle.

M - Mouthfeel is lightly carbonated, body is decent.

O - Overall this was a rather solid beer, the base was excellent.

Serving Type: bottle\xa0629 charactersrudzud, Apr 20, 2018', "4.24/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 5 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.25THanks to rudzud
Huge purple pinkish fluffy creamy 1 finger head that retains for a while, sticky lacing too, super dark black currant / boisenberry purple red color, super dark. 

Nose starts with creamy wheat lactic acid little funky and creamy, tart black currant but not a lot, berry, little sour like, plenty of lemon and tart lemonade, currant is too light though

Taste again loads of creamy wheat and lacto creamy funk, almost like there is cream in there, lactic acid, quite tart, lemony, sour berry with a bit of black currant, more than the nose but still wish there was a bit more, fluffy creamy wheat, little acidic and slight sweet drier flemmy acidic finish, touch of bitter fruit seed and skin tannins, and a little berry lingering with the tart lemon, little salty on the back end especially

Mouth is med bod, little rich but very creamy and fluffy, decent fluffy carb, fair tart flemmy with nice acidity

Overall pretty nice base beer, gose is good, black currant is a bit on the light side, good tartness, great creamy wheat and lacto, nice acidity, just lacking currant although I can't fault them too much as that can go overboard really quickly.\xa01,168 charactersjlindros, Apr 20, 2018"]

This is a winner on all fronts.\xa0266 charactersDVMin98, May 26, 2019']

name: Elderflower Gose
review:
['3.78/5\xa0\xa0rDev -0.5%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 4 | overall: 3.75Appearance - Pours a hazy gold with two fingers of bubbly white head. 

Smell - spicy earthy hops, lemon, coriander, sea salt, bready malts, hint of fruity esters, floral aromas, and earthy yeast. 

Taste - spicy earthy hops upfront then quickly goes into the lemon, coriander, and sea salt. The floral aromas, hint of fruity esters follow suit. The bready malts and earthy yeast finish off the brew.

Mouthfeel - Medium bodied with moderate to high carbonation. Finishes tart and sticky with the malts and floral elements lingering.

Overall - A crushable gose from the folks at Yukon. The floral aspect of the elderflower is done well but I wish there was a touch more salt to make it more of a stand out. Nonetheless, an enjoyable brew.\xa0739 charactersleaddog, Oct 20, 2019', "3.81/5\xa0\xa0rDev +0.3%look: 3.75 | smell: 4 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.75473ml can - a kettle-soured ale with coriander. The last white wine I made had dried elderflowers in it, curious to see how it works here.

This beer pours a slightly hazy, pale golden straw colour, with four fingers of puffy, finely foamy, and somewhat creamy bone-white head, which leaves a bit of low-lying streaky lace around the glass as it quickly blows off.

It smells of gritty and grainy cereal malt, a strong musky floral character, muddled domestic citrus rind, some coriander and black pepper spiciness, and faint estery yeasty notes. The taste is grainy and crackery pale malt, more dirty florals, still indistinct generic citrus peel, semi-sweet coriander, and some ethereal herbal, musty, and dead grassy hoppiness.

The carbonation is average in its palate-satiating frothiness, the body a decent medium weight, and mostly smooth, with just a touch of floral acridity maybe not making nice with the neighbourhood kids at this particular juncture. It finishes off-dry, the malt and elderflower locked in a lingering pas-de-deux.

Overall - this is a pleasantly rendered version of the style, with the guest flower ingredient doing well enough to not overstep its bounds. I'm not getting much in the way of the purported saltiness, but that's ok, I can still enjoy the rest of this without it.\xa01,311 charactersbiboergosum, Jul 12, 2018"]

name: Starlighter
review:
['3.98/5\xa0\xa0rDev +0.8%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 4When I read the word "Dark" my first instinct was to expect burnt toast brown to black, but this guy is more of a red to chestnut brown with a drop of pomegranate juice. Not quite perfectly clear, but good enough that I can see my fingers through the glass. Above once held a thin lightly tanned foam, but as expected with the style, it vacated immediately and never leaves even a suggestion that it ever existed.

On the note of pomegranate, this has a sour dark fruitiness to the aroma. Kind of a mixed berry thing with a briney base and a touch of toasted cereal grains for good measure.

The flavor isn't far off from that. A touch more grainy than expected, especially in the linger, but this is mostly salt and berries. Kind of reminds me of grape juice too. The Welch's concentrate kind, like when were kids.

Pretty thin, even watery, but the salinity tricks the mind as it nearly perceives carbonation, where this is actually kind of flat. Nice balance of sweet and salty, tart and grainy.

Dark Gose is a style that should be explored more. This is good. Was good I mean, as I drank this thing dry before I even got to finish this review.\xa01,157 charactersLingenbrau, Sep 22, 2019']

name: Gose The Distance
review: ['4/5\xa0\xa0rDev +1.3%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4a really interesting take on a gose here, with white grape and hibiscus added, two things we dont see together often enough. the base gose is light in malt body and flavor, so the modest salt and mineral complexion really shines through, and there is a distinctive citrus note to the lacto souring aspect, which is cleaner here than it is in their raspberry berliner, but not quite all the way refined yet, still real close. they were smart to keep the hibiscus subtle here, its lightly fragrant, floral, and citrusy, but stays away from the heavy sprayed perfume thing, a very nice accent flavor, and sort of cut off at the right time by the bacterial acidity on the back end. it really does have a rose wine quality to the flavor, the white grape has a nice tangy sweetness, and there is the tart skin aspect too, with a bright freshness and natural character, accentuated by the hibiscus really well. the salt adds the needed minerality, it seems essential for uniting the flavors and it does its job really well. a good back and forth between the grape and the sour, really nice flavor trajectory, and dry but mouthwatering as it finishes with a uick spurt of carbonation. overall a smart and appropriately delicate but highly unique gose. these guys are absolutely killing it here in the early going, all their beer is great right now, and this was one of the best! not to be missed!\xa01,388 charactersStonedTrippin, Dec 12, 2017']

name: Pettit Gose
review: ['3.78/5\xa0\xa0rDev +4.4%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 4 | overall: 3.75a simple, clean, and well made gose here, more drinkable than most out there because the acidity is really low, its just tart enough to be dry and a little puckery but not acidic enough to sit in the belly funny, hurt my teeth, or warm up with a caustic sort of intensity. i think they did a really nice job with this overall. the souring is tidy and precise, the wheat malt can still be tasted, and the saltiness is obvious without being too much, the balance between all the elements is excellent, and we found this refreshing, even a gose for a pint glass, which is a rarity for me. there is a soft lemon note here from the lacto, and an almost noble sort of hop profile at the end, some minerals and earthiness from the salt without it taking over, and really nice carbonation to keep it summery and uplifting as i drink it. for how popular this style has become in recent years, there are still a ton of bad ones out there, and its nice to find such a solid locally made example of it. they should can this one, if they dont already, even consider making it year round. they have something here!\xa01,100 charactersStonedTrippin, Jul 13, 2019']

name: Here It Gose Again
7 Bells Passionfruit Gose
review:
['3.11/5\xa0\xa0rDev -6%look: 4 | smell: 3 | taste: 3 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3Oooo, this sounds like it might be an interesting segue of a brew from Green Beacon - 7 Bells Passionfruit Gose. First up - my experience with Gose’s are limited but ever expanding. I’ve found they generally taste a bit like Eno - that delightful salty/lemon antacid drink. Yep, Gose’s and Eno are strange bedfellows, but Eno is refreshing ergo Gose’s are too. This one has passionfruit too, so it should be a nice salty tropical summery brew then. Plus at 4.2% ABV it means you can drink even more at the BBQ your GF dragged you along to and still drive... eventually... yay! This can suggests 7 Bells is a part of Green Beacons ever-expanding core range (it’s not a printed label and is brightly coloured like their core range cans) however I reckon it’s a seasonal ;) 

Poured from a 375ml can into a Duvel tulip.

A: CLAAAASIC Gose look: cloudy pale straw body with an excitable white sea foam head that thins down to a snowy blanket on top. Well, well, Green Beacon have nailed that Gose look... then the head completely died. Still looks good. 8/10.

S: Passionfruit upfront, but it’s got a weird tropical Berocca (fizzy good, make feel nice tablets) character. Then it’s got yeast, not quite as bad as Edge Pomegranate Sour, but it’s a noticeable dusty tome (LOL!). Hints of sea salt, but interestingly no lemon - nearly every Gose I’ve tried has had lemon in the flavour profile. Hmmm, a bit too musty but not bad GB. 6/10.

T: Huh, passionfruit Eno... interesting... not as refreshing IMO as the original lemon Eno (sorry GB). Yeast is a bit on the prominent side, dusting its way throughout the flavour profile, salt also comes in a bit sharp, finishes slightly tart and mildly bitter. Other than that it’s a bit on the plain side. Ticks the Gose boxes though. 6/10.

M: Mid to light bodied with a light but spritzy carbonation and a lively tongue-feel (yeah that’s right - I said “tongue-feel”, I’m mixing that shit up yo). 7/10.

D: It’s definitely not the train-wreck that Pomegranate Sour was, but it’s probably the least refreshing beer I’ve had from Green Beacon, though pretty much all their beers hit “the spot” so it’s not a Greek tragedy that 7 Bells is a bit “meh”. TBH I’m not sure Green Beacon even needed to invent this new beer - not when they’ve got solid corkers like Uppercut IIPA, Whaler Blood Orange IPA, and Scrimshaw IPA sitting in the wings as limited release beers - FFS Green Beacon, pick any of those 3 beers to brew year-round and I will be able to die a happy man!!! Not that we’re not already spoiled for choice these days [shud-up me!]. 6/10.

Food match: Seafood for sure: Oysters with lemon juice, and Kilpatrick (no really).\xa02,719 charactersdoktorhops, Jan 25, 2018']

name: Gose German Style Ale
review:
['4.1/5\xa0\xa0rDev +2.8%look: 3.75 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 4Pours a hazy, gold color. 1/4 inch head of a white color. Decent retention and good lacing. Smells of pale malt, wheat, salt, hint of bacterial funk, citrus, and a hint of hops. Fits the style of a Gose. Mouth feel is sharp and crisp, with an average carbonation level. Tastes of pale malt, wheat, salt, hint of bacterial funk, hint of citrus, and a hint of hops. Overall, decent appearance, good aroma, body, and blend.\xa0427 charactersTone, Aug 18, 2016', "3.87/5\xa0\xa0rDev -3%look: 4.25 | smell: 4 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 4 | overall: 3.75From the freshness dated bomber (6/15/16) into a Samuel Smith's perfect pint glass results in a slightly hazed orange body capped by a surprisingly substantial frothy head that recedes into a cap of foam, some lacing is there too, a nice looking beer .
Aroma is subdued, but I get astringent wheat beer and a slight lemony tang
Taste is very clean wheat beer, some citrus tang. Salt is very light as is the coriander. Too light for my tastes as I do enjoy a bit more salt in a Gose, otherwise I'd seek out a wheat beer.
Nice thirst quenching wetness and very easy to put down quickly, I wonder why nobody puts these low ABV beers in a 40oz package?
Overall a nice summer beer, but slightly misses my expectations on the style\xa0728 charactersmudbug, Jul 24, 2016"]

name: Lotus-Eaters
review:
['4.16/5\xa0\xa0rDev -1.9%look: 3.75 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.25I tired this on tap at Bluejacket, enjoyed chilled in a tulip.

The color is golden, clear with thin ring of beads for head with good clarity. The smell is wonderful sour/spiced scent with lightly fruity and woody with citrus aroma and gentle berry aroma. The feel is very good with slight fruity/tangy quality and mineral saltiness with low sweetness and dry finish with slight tangy fruity quality lingering. 

The taste is great juicy and salty with a tangy fruit flavor with light acidic aspect and subtle salt with light malt and semi tropical quality with citrus tang and lactic sour quality lemony flavor as it finishes with some residual sour qualities. This is very enjoyable perhaps one of the best of the style I love the mix of fruit and sour wheat -great flavor with a nod to tradition\xa0798 charactersSlatetank, Feb 09, 2016']

name: Carolina Creamsicle
review:
["4.03/5\xa0\xa0rDev +3.9%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4L: Had this beer on-tap at Gene's Haufbrau, poured into a pint glass. Had a brownish-amber color and a hazy consistency. there was a thin, foamy head that quickly dissipated. Solid lacing.

S: A strong aroma of citrus fruit, vanilla, malt, and lactose.

T: Tasted of a decent shot of vanilla (more than expected), a tinge of malt (not a huge component), lots of citrus fruit (orange, of course), and some lactose (not overly obnoxious). An extremely sweet, oddly enjoyable flavor. For the most part it does taste like a creamsicle, though it does need to settle down first; the orange is quite bracing at first. Pretty tasty.

F: A well-carbonated beer with a lively finish. Light- to medium-bodied.

O: A light and likable beer. Worth a try.\xa0742 charactersavalon07, May 04, 2019"]

review: ['3.74/5\xa0\xa0rDev +3.3%look: 3.5 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.75Sammy, Aug 28, 2017', '3.5/5\xa0\xa0rDev -3.3%look: 3.5 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.5Pmicdee, Jul 14, 2017']

name: Gose
review:
['1.95/5\xa0\xa0rDev -25%look: 2 | smell: 2 | taste: 2 | feel: 1.5 | overall: 2bottle at Catraio, Porto.
i think this bottle was unfermented and totally fucked up.
No head, almost no carbonation, juice-like taste and feel. bad bad bad they should not sell this stuff, threw it in the toilet and asked for something else.\xa0241 charactersDispyDnb, Sep 18, 2016', "3.25/5\xa0\xa0rDev +25%look: 3.25 | smell: 3.25 | taste: 3.25 | feel: 3.25 | overall: 3.2533cl brown glass bottle purchased and served at Catraio in Porto for 3.50 euro in May 2016.

Lots: 0516. Best before December 2016. 4.20% ABV. Gose.

A: White cap of 8cm width. Lasts ~7 minutes, leaving no lacing as it recedes. Body is a slightly hazy yellow-copper of average vibrance. No yeast or lees are visible within.

Appears well-carbonated. Looks nice for a gose, generally speaking, but I note no unique or special characteristics.

Sm: Mild twangy sourness (maybe a 3/10 in terms if intensity), lemon, twang, wheat, coriander. Doesn't smell salty.

Aromatic intensity is average. Suggests a clean refreshing gose.

T&Mf: Has a refreshing wheat backbone with subtle notes of coriander and salt. Some faint lemon. That's it, really. Balanced albeit shallow and simple.

Refreshing, light-bodied, smooth, wet, approachable, and overcarbonated.

O: It's a pretty basic gose, touching on each convention of the style but offering nothing more. Drinkable and pleasant, but far from excellent.

High C+ (3.25) / ABOVE AVERAGE\xa01,029 characterskojevergas, Jun 11, 2016"]

review:

Overall, a really nice sour, that does what the name says. Really nice mouthfeel on this one.\xa0393 charactersJamFuel, Dec 08, 2018']

name: Reinheitsgewhathappened!?
review:
["4.02/5\xa0\xa0rDev +3.9%look: 3.75 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 4Tangy, tantalizing and traditional, the sour ale fetish of Little Fish Brewing Company relies upon the history of the northern German sour and salty style and links it with the classic combination of rhubarb and strawberry for a brand new taste.

Strhubarb Reinheitsgewhathappened throws caution to the purity wind when pouring a golden hue and with a hazy appearance. Above its cottony white froth, a musty fruit aroma floods the nose with the tang of cranberry, rhubarb, apple, strawberry, other red berries, currants and lime. Built upon a light pastry sweetness, the taste of sweetened pie crust joins the flavor fray. 

And as the scant sweetness fades further and further into the recesses of taste, the beer's sourness wins out, carrying first the taste of tangy red berry, bing cherry, rose wine, citrus and cider. All trending more dry than sweet, the taste soon transfers to a sharply acidic taste of lactic sourness with a brisk afterpalate of the sea to follow.

Medium bodied for sour but rather suitable for gose, the beer's wheaten aftertaste is joined by the pillowy softness of starch, protien and a creamy substrate of carbonation. Moderate sourness leads to a moderate dryness and a light saltine roundness and a bright orange perfume that plays out underneath the fruit additions. A quick aftertaste of cellar must ensures a rustic counterpart to radiant fruit.\xa01,381 charactersBEERchitect, May 15, 2017"]

name: Key Lime Gose

It fits as a perfect post-workout beer.\n\nLime notes are bright on the aroma and the taste. Salty texture. Light sour notes on the finish which combine perfectly with the lime notes. Highly enjoyable beer. Very well made.\xa0313 charactersZAP, Nov 24, 2015']

It is fairly well balanced overall, with a lot of wheat flavor, but it does lean a little to the sour side. Especially at the end. Seems like a pretty traditional version, and a pretty good one\xa0284 charactersWesMantooth, Oct 21, 2016', '4.33/5\xa0\xa0rDev +0.9%look: 4.25 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4 | overall: 4.254 Oz pour on tap

A: Light white color with a touch of haze with decent carbonation, looks like chardonnay almost.

S: Light coriander, wheat, salty

T: You can really taste the wheat and the saltiness and then the coriander comes in and its a touch sour on the back end.

M: A little denser and not as lip smacking refreshing as some Gose beers are. The tartness may lend to the heavier mouthfeel. 

O: This is a solid Gose its got nice bits of saltiness sourness and wheat flavors. Its light enough to drink all day as well.\xa0526 charactersSomethingClever, Oct 15, 2016']
