The aroma is subdued - tart fruity wheat malt.

The flavor is subdued and pretty watery - sweet wheat malt and tart acidic sour fruit with a subtle salt finish. The mouthfeel is medium bodied with low carbonation.

name: Guava Tears
review:
['3.94/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.75 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 3.75Moss Mill Brewing Co. "Guava Tears"
$2/4 oz. at the brewery on 14 April 2018

Notes: Cloudy pale straw gold body beneath a short head of bright white. The aroma is mineralish/salty and citrusy/acidic. The flavor follows and I'm not sure the guava comes through clearly but there is some fruit to it. It's not too tart, not too salty, and not too mineralish. Moderately bitter with a dry but lightly acidic finish. Light-medium in body and crisp. Refreshing.\xa0457 charactersNeroFiddled, May 08, 2018']

name: Grapefruit Gose
review: ['3.75/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.75a nice beer for summer, with a simple but very clean lacto profile, acidic enough without being real intense, and without any of the cheesy or stinky weirdness that comes with a lot of these now that everybody and their grandmother is kettle souring. this has a bright mineral element to it with the salt, brine and lemon together, super refreshing over the light wheat malt base. the grapefruit is really natural just like it appears in their no coast ipa, pulpy and fleshy and zesty and juicy all at the same time, like they use the whole fruit. i like the added acidity from the grapefruit, it makes this even more refreshing, and its pretty pungent, i taste it well in front of any grain. the bitterness is nice too and this is very summery and drinkable overall. very basic example of the style, but they have done a nice job with it and the grapefruit is really authentic. nice brew overall, not too sour to have a couple of them. i liked pretty much all the beers here at peace tree, these guys are doing some fantastic stuff!\xa01,033 charactersStonedTrippin, Apr 27, 2018']

name: Don't Gose Chasin' Waterfalls
review:
['3.82/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 3.75L: Had this beer on-tap at Brewmasters - Wilson, poured into a snifter glass. Had a golden yellow / amber color and a mostly clear consistency. There was a 3/4", foamy, fairly long-lasting head. Sparse lacing.

S: A good, but not great aroma of malt, citrus fruit, a floral quality, and salt.

T: Tasted of a good amount of citrus fruit (lemon, in particular), a decent shot of malt (a big component here), a tinge of salt (mostly in the finish), and some of the floral quality. This is a lightweight, sweet, but a little uneven flavor. It seems like it could use a little more of a citrusy backbone to work properly. Not bad, though.

F: A well-carbonated beer with a slightly slick finish. Light-bodied.

O: This is an uneven beer, but it has likable qualities. Worth a try.\xa0776 charactersavalon07, Apr 06, 2019']

name: Haterade - Orange
review: ["3.82/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4.5 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 4 | overall: 3.75Berliner Weisse brewed with electrolytes. Poured from a can into a Bell's tulip. The pour is hazy and orange with a big, majestic three-finger head the color of peach ice cream. The nose is much funkier than I was expecting. A fair amount of barnyard mustiness along with a hint of orange.\u200b\n\nLight body with a fizzy feel and a tart, refreshing flavor. Sharp lemon-like sour notes up front balanced by a sweet orange pop-like flavor. Some of that mustiness on the nose comes through on the finish, but it's buried underneath sour lemon and sweet orange. Overall, not quite sure what to make of this beer. It definitely tastes unusual. I don't get fresh fruit flavor, it's more of an artificial fruit flavor. Not bad, certainly refreshing, but not sure it's something I would want to drink a lot of.\u200b\xa0802 charactersdeadonhisfeet, Sep 09, 2019"]

name: A Petit Déjeuner
review: ['4.32/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.5 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4.5 | overall: 4.5Opaque orange juice with a soft white blanket dying to a thin ring.\n\nThis delivered on the passion fruit promise excellently, coming across both as really juicy and also seedy and lightly funky like passion fruit can be, with minimal salty, cheesy Gose stuff going on that you sometimes get. The crisply tingly medium-full round body finishes semi-wet, as the aroma does exhibit more typical Gose-like attributes with lightly salty biscuit and other sea-like smells.\xa0466 charactersSabtos, Jan 28, 2019']

review:
["4.12/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4.25 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4 | overall: 4Poured from a 12oz can into a snifter.

L: Deep pink flavor with light pink head that quickly dissipates.
S: Sweet red berries. Mild aroma, but very pleasant.
T: Berry fruit forward, but I not distinctly raspberry. Bit of breadiness. Could use a bit more salt and I don't get any coriander if there is any in the recipe.
F: Medium carbonation. A little bit sweet sticky finish and not as much of a sharp, crisp finish from a traditional Gose.

A very nice fruited Gose that is refreshing and very easy to drink. Lovely summer beer.\xa0531 charactersWA_Brian, Aug 11, 2019"]

name: BioNoc' Meingose
review:
['4.39/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.5Birrificio Artigianale BioNoc' "Meingose"
alla spina @ Serpente Pub, Roma, Italy on 30 NOV 2015

Notes: This beer grew out of a collaboration with Brewhouse Rock in Quero, Italy. This version was brewed and bottled at BioNoc' using Pediococcus (and possibly lactobacillus) and Himalayan pink salt.

Appearance: Slightly hazy straw gold body beneath a bright white head. Head retention and lacing are limited, but that's somewhat expected for the style.

Aroma: Fruity and sour combined.

Flavor: Salt upfront, quickly fruity, then sour. The malt comes through towards the swallow. Very nicely balanced, not too sour or salty; and with a good transition of the flavors across the palate - something that you don't necessarily find in gosebiers.

Mouthfeel: Light-medium to medium-light in body and bristling with a fine-bubbled, gently effervescent carbonation.

Overall: Quite pleasant! An excellent rendition of the gosebier style. Both refreshing and satisfying.\xa0964 charactersNeroFiddled, Feb 17, 2016']

review: ['3.58/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.5Golden/orange color with a small white head, aroma of watermelon and salty cucumbers, taste of unriped fruits and salty cucumbers, no bitterness, no sweetness, just sourness...\xa0176 charactersmishi_d, Oct 06, 2019']

name: Passionfruit Gose
review: ['3.99/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.75 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4an awesome summery brew right here, maybe a touch stronger than many in its field and perhaps a little too sour to drink a ton of, which is something i like in gose, but a really good execution in a lot of ways. the fruit is natural and robust, honestly tart and right on par with the acidity here, which is remarkable clean here, lactic and familiar and even one dimensional, but they compliment each other excellently well, and i appreciate this a lot for that, some balance, even if its a little intense. lemon and grapefruit nuance to this too, an appreciable wheat malt character in both flavor and body, and a light but tight and drying salt complexion, more a feel than a flavor in this one. it could use a little more carbonation but the mouthfeel still seems right for what it is. cleaner than many, very little leftover sweetness from the fruit, tropical and summery and good. its my first beer from these guys, and it seems quite professionally done. quenching and just right this time of year!\xa01,005 charactersStonedTrippin, May 17, 2018']

name: Little Wolf / Stellenbosch - Sorghum Gose
review:
["3.81/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 4 | overall: 3.75Very cloudy pale yellow body with a good finger of fuzzy white head that sticks around better than I'd expected. Once it starts to dissipate though, it disappears almost immediately leaving just some discrete wet bubbles raising to the top.

Nose has an interesting blend of tart gose notes and an almost floral/nectar note that I attribute to the use of fynbos. Really interesting. Hints of lager-type malts.

Taste doesn't have quite the same enticing layers. Much more muddled and subdued. Light earthiness and more grains than tart or salinity. There is a little bit of each of the latter in there though, Focus is more on the earthy grains though, which is enjoyable enough on its own, but seems a little out of place in the style. Finish draws closer to the tart but it's not a bright tartness, much more dull/earthy but still a little tart. Might be some banana-esque in there as well, but it could be an artifact of hearing Umqombothi described using banana-descriptors, since this features sorghum, and sorghum is used in Umqombothi, and I don't really know what sorghum tastes like otherwise, ha.

Drinkable and enjoyable. Bright effervescent carbonation, and the finish is much more dry than I'd expected. 

An interesting take on the style, and enjoyable, even if it strays somewhat. Definitely glad to have grabbed a can and hauled it back across the globe!\xa01,371 characterskemoarps, Mar 31, 2019"]

review:
['3.94/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.5 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 4 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 4.25On-tap at Alvarado Street Brewery, Monterey, CA

A: The beer is clear very light yellow in color and has a light amount of visible carbonation. It poured with a patch of white bubbles on the surface and a collar around the edge of the glass.
S: Light aromas of sourness and lactic acid are present in the nose.
T: The taste is similar to the smell and starts off with some sour flavors of lemons and quickly transitions to some yogurt-like flavors from the lactobacillus.
M: It feels light-bodied and a little creamy on the palate with faint bits of tartness.
O: This beer is very easy to drink and has some refreshing properties. I could easily drink this all day long.

Serving type: on-tap\xa0694 charactersmetter98, May 27, 2016']

name: Raspberry Gose
review: ['3.74/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.5 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.75a simple but tasty gose here, another beer type i didnt really expect to find here, but was glad i did. this is light on the sourness, which helps be be drinkable as a pint beer, and the fruit is natural and tangy as well, without any of the jammy sweetness that sometimes turns me off in the style, it remains light and refreshing, and for being so straightforward, its quite good. less color than anticipated from the fruit, and not a whole lot of head retention here, but the aroma and flavor is really appealing, with a natural ripe berry front end and some citrusy pucker later on, the fruit and the lacto go really well together, and its very clean, no sweaty sock, no cheese, no weird fermentation characteristics at all, so well done on that. its not quite as interesting as the best ones in the game, and i think a lot of that is because i dont really appreciate much salt in this, maybe in the texture a little bit, but really not in the flavor, which i kind of miss, i think it would highlight the raspberry in a cool way. i do like that i can taste the grain in this, and that there is a little complimentary lime thing in the finish that makes it pop pretty well. overall a fine beer, a little tame for the style, but solid. i was impressed with the selection at their northside location, tons of cool beers i had not seen before!\xa01,343 charactersStonedTrippin, Oct 11, 2019']

review: ['3.81/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.75 | smell: 4 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.75This gose is very much on the tart side and has a ton of fruit. It is much more thick and viscous than 99% of goses. There is a slight off flavor (wet cardboard maybe?) that detracts from the overall result.\xa0207 charactersLucular, Dec 19, 2018']

name: By the Flaming Hammer of Gallagher
review:
['3.85/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 4 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.7516 fl. oz. can
Served in a becker glass

This beer pours pale yellow with some haze. It is topped with a fleeting off white head that leaves no lacing.

Whew, the coriander is strong with this one. It kind of masks the other aromas. I do get some watermelon and salt after it warms a bit.

Now the flavor is another story. The coriander and watermelon meld to create a refreshing flavor. The saltiness adds a dryness to the finish leaving me wanting another sip. Right when I forget about the jalapeno, it rears up to add just a slight hint of heat. 

Thin bodied with a slightly dry finish.

This is damn refreshing brew. I thought they overdid it with the coriander, but the taste hits the spot on a pleasant summer evening.\xa0726 charactersbuschbeer, Jun 08, 2019']

name: Classic Gose
review:
['4.18/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.25On tap at the brewery 

Mostly clear dull gold with a big, bright white soapy head that’s a bit fizzy. M

Smells sour against a strong grainy background. 

Just a little bit of salinity up front and then the sourness quickly transitions into a strong wheat flavor and has a lingering grain taste. A bit of apple or pear like fruit too. 

Body is fairly well carbonated but has a pretty soft feel. 

If you are looking for a super sour, or overly fruited Gose (American style) this isn’t it. This is a subtle, traditional Leipzig version more like Sixpoint Jammer. And an excellent one.\xa0589 charactersWesMantooth, Oct 06, 2018']

name: Cooling Sensation
review:
["4.03/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4L: Had this on-tap Growlers to Go - Short Pump, poured into a pint glass. Had a brownish / yellow color and a very cloudy consistency. There was a thin, foamy head that quickly dissipated. Not a whole lot of lacing.

S: An interesting aroma of strawberries, cucumbers, salt, wheat, citrus fruit, and mint.

T: Tasted of a bit of salt (just a little pinch), some light mint notes (present throughout), lots of cucumbers (a surprising amount), some citrus fruit (lemon, in particular), a hint of wheat, and some strawberries. Not your typical gose flavor. but in a good way. It's a light, refreshing, and likable flavor. 

F: A good amount of carbonation with a smooth finish. Light-bodied.

O: A well done gose - good for the summer months. Drinkable.\xa0750 charactersavalon07, Jul 05, 2019"]

review:
["3.68/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.5 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.75Hazy pale yellow with a persistent fluffy white blanket settling to a curled collar.

This is floral more than anything else, pairing with a touch of very mild, stream water mineral sort of funk, as well as lemon. But overall I'm very much getting an actual blossom vibe, which is fitting.

Very lightly tart and very frothy, the medium-light body finishes semi-wet and tingly.\xa0377 charactersSabtos, May 10, 2019"]

name: Royale With Guava
review: ['3.83/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 4 | overall: 4a very clean and successful gose, not too sour to drink a bunch of, and really nicely balanced by the guava in here, which is tropical and ripe and for once in its beer life not coopted by pineapples and passion fruits and such, but standing nicely on its own. the beer is very pale in color, like champagne from the tap, with a nice white head on it and pretty carbonation rising up. its minimal from the grain side, light white wheat and pils malt seems to be all, its like it gets most of its body from the salt, which isnt briney or drying but full and mineral forward and rich to me, adding a really cool earthy element and size to this. the guava is nice and juicy and works super well with the sourness. its nice and tidy, a profession sort of lacto souring, tangy and perfect with the salt, not overly acidic and no weird off flavors with it. bright and summery beer, lively in feel and full of flavor, a cool take on the style, and something really drinkable. i was impressed with all the beers we had in here from a quality standpoint!\xa01,045 charactersStonedTrippin, Jun 16, 2018']

More than usual. It creates an interesting flavor profile. The blackberry base gives it some tart sweetness.\xa0207 charactersFee, Oct 12, 2019']

name: Strawberry Gose
review:
['3.71/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.5 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.75As the warm weather comes to a close, the Country Boys say "never say die" to summer with a crisp and cleanly soured ale with an overlay of strawberry for extra charm, comfort and that warm feeling that only summer can give.

Peachy golden upon the pour, the cloudy beer expels an initial creamy froth with penetrating spritzy acidity that relegates the beer somewhat still quickly after. With a decidedly fruity scent, the strawberry finesse rests upon a sour and citrusy base with apple, lemon and lime. Its taste is faintly sweet to start, casting hints of doughy sweetness through fresh pilsner grain and whole wheat bread.

The malts and sweetness dissolves quickly over the tongue and leaves the full brunt of taste to rest squarely upon the sourness, fruitiness and supportive earth. While strawberry character remains in charge, there's suggestions of raspberry, sour cherry, green apple, dry white wine and citrusy sourness that smack the tastebuds around with their sheer lactic sourness. With little in the way of coriander perfume, the finish is playfully salty yet careful not to interfere with the delicate aura of strawberry.

Light in body, the beer's relative stillness renders is needing greater life, personality and sprite. But the acidity enlivens the taste regardless and closes the session clean, crisp and greatly refreshing. With an undercurrent of wheat dough and sour fruit, the taste lingers slightly in aftertaste.\xa01,443 charactersBEERchitect, Nov 06, 2015']

name: Pocket Sandwich
review:
['4.01/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.5 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 4Color isn’t bad, but its kind of brown because of the peanut butter... there are more visually aesthetically pleasing beers.
Smell is world class, I haven’t smelled many beverages this fragrant let alone so accurately peanut butter and jelly.
Taste isn’t as peanut buttery as you would expect until it warms up some, but it’s still quite flavorful and full in general for the style. It maintains most of the fresh taste you would expect from the smell.
Feels very bubbly, not much in the way texture. Mildly velvety and smooth at first with those sharp acidic bubbles you’d expect from a gose on the swallow.
Overall great beer, give this a try. If you specifically like goses this is a must.\xa0702 charactersdydrate, May 11, 2019']

name: Pink Guava Imperial Mangito
review:
['4.25/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4.25 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.25L: Had this beer on-tap at The Answer Brewpub, poured into a taster glass. Had an orange color and a thick, viscous consistency, There was a thin, foamy head that quickly dissipated. Very good lacing.

S: An interesting aroma of tropical fruit, citrus fruit, malt, and chili peppers.

T: Tasted of a small amount of malt (very fleeting), lots of citrus fruit (lime and lemon, especially), a good shot of habanero chili peppers (particularly in the finish), and a lot of tropical fruit (the advertised guava and mangoes). An offbeat and lively flavor. For some reason the heat from the chili peppers works well with the sourness of the beer. Delicious.

F: A below average amount of carbonation with a smooth, yet hot finish. Medium-bodied.

O: A strangely enjoyable sour beer. Drinkable.\xa0787 charactersavalon07, Jul 13, 2019']

name: Kveik 8 - Pina Colada
review: ['4.2/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.75 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4 | overall: 4.25part of their kveik series. a really tasty gose or berliner type sour golden ale here done like a pina colada with coconut and pineapple, possibly also some citrus as well, as i get a strong hint of that, although it could be some fruity tang from the lacto that sours this. really pretty well done beer, skeptical as i have been of this sort of thing, its hard to argue that this isnt summery, refreshing, and delicious. a few aspects really set it apart from the crowd. the first is that its not too sour, summer cocktail flavors like this needs to be drinkable in some volume, and this is never too acidic to have a bunch of, super smart there. secondly, the coconut and the pineapple are both natural and really obvious without overtaking the beer, they marry well together obviously pop at the right time, but dont get sugary or dominant at all. third, the base beer is excellent, salty like, or mineral forward enough to highlight the added ingredients and wheaty enough to still taste and feel like beer, probably excellent on its own. nuances here of fresh lime zest, toasted coriander seed, and meyer lemon, almost like a frozen pina colada melted down into the beer. if this is fermented with the newly famous kveik yeast as the name suggests, than someone has finally figured out the right context for it, nice with the bacterial acidity and more saison-esque than i have known it to be in the past, a less invasive complexion for sure. good carbonation too just sets it off, and overall a really impressive beer here. if there is lactose in this, it adds, not detracts from the beer, just a bit of sweet creaminess at the end like coconut cream would be in the drink. a beer to be celebrated!\xa01,704 charactersStonedTrippin, Jun 18, 2019']

review: ['3.78/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 4 | overall: 4Had as part of flight. Hazy straw color with little head. Aroma is light and subtle, some sweetness and sour comes through, like sour candy. Taste starts off salty and tangy, just another run of the mill gose. But then the mango kicks in on the finish, thick, full, juicy and sweet. Captivating finish.\xa0302 charactersTripel_Threat, Aug 20, 2016']

name: Baby Snake
review: ['3.58/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.5not my favorite of their work, thats for sure, but also one of the only ones i have ever had on tap. its done in collaboration with ritterguts, which makes sense, being a gose and all. it looks like a cider from the tap, almost no head at all, decent clarity, and a radiant yellow color. it smells fruity, white wine, good champagne to be more specific, green apple, and green pear, juicy and citrusy too, with a clean lactic sourness that makes my mouth water a little bit. the flavor is weird, its not beery enough for me, i hardly taste any grain or salt, and the bacterial sourness is so clean that it doesnt taste like much, just produces this moderate acidity. its real fruity, but to me more like a cider or something than a beer, i cant get any grain at all. pear for sure in the flavor, its both sweet in the middle and dry later on, with a lemony note, a white wine tannic thing, and some minerals that help it finish. i wish for a little more wheat or pils malt or something in here to make it beery, and maybe a little more yeast character too, its so clean that its kind of here and gone before i can really get into it all the way. there has to be some fruit in here, but its kind of nondescript for me. overall something really different, incredibly light, but without the sort of soul i have come to expect from the beer these guys make. good but not great, quite unconventional in this style.\xa01,409 charactersStonedTrippin, Nov 16, 2018']

name: Drink NoVa Gose
review:
['3.55/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4.25 | smell: 3 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.5On tap at brewery:
A bit of a lore amber body, mildly surprisingly. The head is a nice cap until I start drinking, when it starts to thin, perhaps because it leaves its bubbles on the glass wall.

Really light nose of lightly toasted wheat with an allusion to tart and a couple flakes of salt. Clarity is pretty high.

Similar taste, more of an amber ale than a wheat. The salinity and tartness are watered down, the former less so than the latter. The sour sorta builds up if you drink quickly.

There’s nothing bad here, but there’s a light hand that has this seeming a tad bland. It took me half the glass to appreciate it more, and I raised my scores from average. I think just a little more sour - not much - would bring this together more for me.\xa0762 characterscjgiant, Jun 26, 2019']

name: MF Gose: Sandia
review:
["4.25/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4.25 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.25Poured into a tall tulip/stemmed lager glass (depending who you talk to).
The appearance was a ruddy burnt orange/malty copper color with a small white foamy head swiftly sliding off. Barely any lace.
The aroma started off with true to style gose qualities of salt, soured wheat, and tart fruity/lemon lactic acidic qualities. Subtle watermelon works its way in for a stellar balance.
The flavor meshes all of those prior mentioned aromas together - tart, sour and sweet features. Mild aftertaste of sweet authentic watermelon with a touch of salt and sour-ed wheat.
The mouthfeel felt really nice! I'd say about medium bodied with a decent sessionability about despite a slightly higher than normal ABV. Subtle stickiness but mostly pretty good. Finishes salty crisp with some watermelon sweetness, nothing in the way.
Overall, would love to bang again during warmer weather.\xa0876 charactersLone_Freighter, Nov 14, 2019"]

name: I Just Blue Myself
review:
["3.81/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.75 | smell: 4 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.75Seeing the brewhouse in blue stained glasses, Rock House is anything but blue rolling out a supple, sour and succinct ale that's slathered with generous blueberry additions for a fruit forward taste that'll have area wide sour sippers something to drool over. It's a beer that just might require a moist towelette. 

In true adolescent form, I Just Blue Myself plays on words as it plays on the eye with a purple and light crimson hue. Light haze adorns the glass as a dainty swirl of foam rises to the rim. Tart aromas pull from the robust fruit for a bold yet bright scent of wine, cider, citrus and berry. A light candied and cobbler taste is wheaten sweet with saltwater taffy and sourdough.

The blueberries splash against the middle palate with a juiciness that's remiss of grape juice with the essence of plum, raspberry and blackberry stewing under the surface. The beer is supported well by a medley of lime, grapefruit, green apple, green grape and gooseberry from the base taste. A hint of burlap and balsa step in to give a gentle earhen complexity to the intensifying sourness late on the palate.

Medium light and not quite up the g sourness of true Liepzig gose, a hint of brine brings roundness to the acidity and fruit and fosters a bolder taste and texture than what is likely actual. A medium short aftertaste of berry skins and light tannins provide a juicy but dry finish with a drift of sea air.\xa01,417 charactersBEERchitect, Dec 04, 2018"]

name: The Floor is Guava
review:
['3.78/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4.25 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.75On tap at brewery:
Hazy pink grapefruit juice with a moderately beaten egg white froth that gathers at the edge in a medium collar. Temporary lacing shows and disappears before one’s eyes.

Light guava note accentuates the sour side, with a slight fruity lean. Lighter wheat, but not much salinity.

Taste brings a little more pop than the nose, both with the wheat base, a moderate to mildly subdued tart fruit (yes, guava) note, and a little saltiness that sneaks in the back. There’s a very slight note of Greek yogurt in back, as well.

Pretty balanced, nice and lightly tart Gose that doesn’t hide or overpower with the fruit addition.\xa0649 characterscjgiant, Jun 26, 2019']

name: Beetbox
review:
['4.24/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4.5 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.533cl bottle, 9m to bb.

Deep ruby red, lighter than beetroot, but a very intense red. Foam matches in colour. The visual intensity is not matched by the aroma, which is quite standard gose type. There are rounded notes to it, telling of the flavouring ingredients of beetroot and quince (besides the style-obligatory salt). Head sticks for a while but eventually disappears.

Taste is balanced and smooth, and the rounded notes from the aroma now reveal themselves more clearly and identifiably after the middle stage of taste. Yet, everything is so harmonious that you do not think in terms of ingredients. A soft yet refreshing substyle of gose emerges. Well done\xa0665 charactersKooVee, Oct 26, 2019']

name: Bez Porzeczka
review:
['2.5/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3 | smell: 3 | taste: 2 | feel: 3 | overall: 2.533cl bottle, based on old notes and leftover bottle a year past bb date that I discovered in my cellar.

Reddish brown, large-grained foam that subsides but sticks moderately.

Nose is blackcurrant, a bit of mineral acidity.

Taste was quiet a mess when young.. the mineral gose backbone was clashing with the blackcurrant and something undefinable which was probably the beetroot, while elderflow tried to add its own voice from the side. Now, way past its prime the blackcurrant has almost gone, and what remains is a very minerally base. Maybe this was in balance somewhere in the middle but I doubt it. The 2,3% strength felt in the original to be a blessing because there was too much going on already.

They themselves describe this as an experiment to celebrate an anniversary. I wanted to record my own notion that fruity and herbal notes apparently do not mix trivially with a salty gose base. As is not really surprising. A brave attempt nonetheless.

The\xa0966 charactersKooVee, Feb 17, 2019']

review:
["3.35/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.5 | smell: 2.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.25 | overall: 3.25Decent gose. Extremely tart with some light sweetness. Has a nice sea salt character. The aroma was a bit off putting and didn't match the flavor at all. 

Feel was a bit on the light side with high carbonation. Puckering, kind of like sucking on a sour warhead. 

Overall not bad, would like to try this one again to give a more in depth review.\xa0346 charactersScaryEd, Oct 12, 2016"]

name: Roll In Ze' Cafe Limone
review: ['4.12/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.75 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 4a fantastic variant of their gose, featuring coffee and lemon, a strange combination of flavors for a beer like this, but a really successful one! it doesnt look like much, no real color to it from the coffee, and not a lot of head from the tap. aroma is striking, anything but subtle, its zesty fresh lemon and lots of it, along with a rich roasted coffee that has some milk chocolate aromatic to it, and then the sourness, which is a mid range lacto effort. the flavor is as pungent and the nose, tons of coffee and lemon, very espresso-like on the coffee, concentrated and dark with a ripe fruitiness about it. amazingly fresh lemon feeds into the acidity, and there is still some malted wheat underneath, an awesome mix of flavors and textures, and it finishes dry. it is a little flat, more carbonation would be a great add, but the flavors here are fantastic, both really bold, but incredible together. i wasnt sure this would work in a gose, but it really does. the cleaner lactic aspect helps, as does the salt, which is subtle but unifying in here. i thought this beer was both inventive and well executed, and verboten continues to stay well ahead of the small brewery curve in terms of quality!\xa01,205 charactersStonedTrippin, Dec 08, 2017']

As it warms, I even get notes of key lime pie with graham cracker crust.\xa0393 charactersSabtos, May 13, 2019']

name: The Crowd Gose Wild with Guava
review: ['3.69/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.75a neat little series here it looks like, gose with fruit, a fun one for the summer here with guava in it, which i feel like i have been seeing on its own, separate from other fruit, more and more lately which i dig. it has a sort of soft tropical pulpy juicy fleshy sweetness to it, is distinct and also candy-like to me, nice with the salt and the sour in here, both of which are fairly tame. not at all too sour to drink, and the souring here is pretty clean, a little bit of that sweaty thing to it, but not enough to slow this down, even as a pint beer. the fruit is forward in the mix, but its not too much, since this is fermented down to close to dry and there is a little lemony acidity to balance it out through the finish. nice carbonation, which is essentially mandatory in a beer like this, and a pillowy wheaty vibe to the feel, plush and inviting. hints of passion fruit and lime at the end too, and the minerals of the salt that make this quenching and sort of addicting. i liked this quite a bit, and see the potential for all kinds of other fruits to make this a seasonal series that works anytime of year, apples in the fall would be cool for the next one! not perfectly refined, but a cool beer from a brewery i didnt know messed around with sours.\xa01,267 charactersStonedTrippin, Aug 24, 2019']

name: Fall Gose
review: ["4.25/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4 | overall: 4.25On tap at the brewery. Pours a slightly hazy golden color with very little head. Some lacing. The aroma is tart with green apples, cinnamon, allspice, wheat and lemon. The taste is sour apple pie with a slice of lemon. Extremely unique flavor for sure. Cinnamon, all spice and orange peel. Lemon and green apple finish. Honestly, I'm blown away by the blend of flavors here. It works shockingly well. Lightly carbonated. Go find this beer while it is still available.\xa0467 charactersPicoPapa, Sep 14, 2017"]

name: Tide Flats
review: ['3.62/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4 | smell: 3.25 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 4.25It’s brewed with oyster brine and coriander. Quite attractive golden brew with fine-grained foam in the New Belgium snifter. Aroma can best be described as "what the..."? Sort of like wet cardboard but more interesting. It starts out with a touch of malty sweetness followed by the acidic fruity sensation and celery aftertaste. \n\nI wouldn\'t say this actually tastes like oysters, but there\'s something from the ocean, though I would have guessed seaweed. While it\'s tart, it doesn\'t veer into the vinegar territory, so it\'s actually pretty drinkable. But totally strange nonetheless. From the 500 ml bottle purchased at Garden Path Fermentation.\xa0648 charactersmactrail, Sep 08, 2018']

name: Cherry Lime Rickey
review:
["3.99/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.75 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4Poured from the can into a wheat ale glass.

Pale dark orange and red body color, with a very good sized frothy off white tall head. Head reaches a solid three fingers, and has some surprising staying power for a gose. 

Briney like aromas hit the nose nicely, with touches of small salt quality. Very faint hint of fruited cherry, with more of a citrus and zesty quality that's quite large on the lime. Hints quite a bit of oily like zest as well.

Palate continues some of the trend. Solid base gose style, with a good malt backbone and a hint of chewy texture. Brings some good salty to briney like qualities, but with some unusual character. Hints quite a bit of oily zest but a little indistinguishable. There's some odd spicy quality to this almost a little cinnamon to nutmeg like, perhaps gingerbread.

Solid gose, but doesn't really have this cherry quality coming through as much as I anticipated.\xa0915 charactersSmakawhat, Aug 16, 2019"]

name: Chrysalis
review:
['4/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4Appearance: Pour a clear pale lavender color with a three finger head; reasonably good retention with a few spots of lace

Smell: Tart lime tones with a floral element

Taste: Tart and floral tones forward with growing tartness, through the middle; modest amounts of salt and herbal tones in the finish

Mouthfeel: Light body with moderate carbonation

Overall: Tart and refreshing; brewed with butterfly pea flowers which provide an herbal element

Thanks, cdubnbird, for the opportunity\xa0493 charactersbrentk56, Apr 11, 2019']

name: MF Gose: Mango Limon
review:
["4.04/5\xa0\xa0rDev +7.2%look: 3.75 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4 | overall: 3.75Thanks Steve!
This was poured into a stange.
The appearance was a semi-bright copper/yellow color with a stifled transparency about it. I didn't really see any carbonation rising but I did see and hear a quickly dissolving white bubbly head. No lace.
The aroma had some mango flesh with lime and lemon juicy pulpy character. Gose characters seem there but staying somewhat in the backseat.
The flavor brought forth the lemon and lime tones in front of the mango and the gose characters. Mild tart lemon and lime aftertaste.
The mouthfeel was about medium bodied with a fair sessionability about it. Good carbonation and plenty of sticky citrusy fruity tartness. Finishes somewhat lemony and lime-like with some salt.
Overall, it's actually quite good for me but perhaps may be at the cusp of almost over-doing it. Somehow, I would want to have this again preferably for me.\xa0873 charactersLone_Freighter, Nov 16, 2019"]

name: Zombie
review:
['4/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4L: Had this beer on-tap at Growlers to Go - Short Pump, poured into a pint glass. Had an orange / brown color and a cloudy consistency. There was a quarter inch of foamy, somewhat long-lasting head. Sparse lacing.

S: A solid aroma of citrus fruit, wheat, tropical fruit, apricot, and salt.

T: Tasted of a bit of wheat (mostly in the finish; kind of fleeting), a bit of apricot (just a touch), a lot of citrus fruit (blood orange), a pinch of salt, and some tropical fruit (pineapple). A light, sweet, and effervescent flavor. At first it seems a little thin, but it settles down and quickly improves. Tasty.

F: A well-carbonated beer with a sharp finish. Medium-bodied.

O: A likable, lightweight gose. Worth a try.\xa0718 charactersavalon07, Oct 29, 2019']

review:
["3.12/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.25 | smell: 3 | taste: 3 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.25Full on pink color. Light haze. Nearly no head (rim bubbles only). Zero lace. 

The smell is candy-like sweet, similar to candy corn. No cranberry, no gose. 

The flavor is also very sweet but less like candy corn. There's also a touch of sourness which provides some balance. A bit of a novelty -- good for those who have a sweet tooth.\xa0337 characterssmcolw, Apr 27, 2019"]

name: Granny's Candies
review: ['4/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 416 ounce crowler into tulip glass, filled on 6/30/2019. Pours lightly hazy pale golden straw color with a 1 finger fairly dense and fluffy white head with solid retention, that reduces to a thin spotty lace cap that lingers. Minimal spotty lacing clings on the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of big juicy/tart/tangy lemon, lime, orange, grapefruit, raspberry, peach, pear, melon, red/green apple, white grape/wine, hay, straw, grass, wheat, cracker, white bread, light peppercorn/salt/lacto funk, and yeast earthiness. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of gummy candy, fruity/acidic yeast, and moderate pale/wheat malt notes; with big strength. Taste of big juicy/tart/tangy lemon, lime, orange, grapefruit, raspberry, peach, pear, melon, red/green apple, white grape/wine, hay, straw, grass, wheat, cracker, white bread, light peppercorn/salt/lacto funk, and yeast earthiness. Light-moderate fruity/lactic tang/tartness, and light spiciness on the finish. Lingering notes of tart/tangy lemon, lime, orange, grapefruit, raspberry, peach, pear, melon, red/green apple, white grape/wine, hay, straw, grass, wheat, cracker, white bread, light peppercorn/salt/lacto funk, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Great complexity, robustness, and balance of gummy candy, fruity/acidic yeast, and moderate pale/wheat malt flavors; with a great malt/tart/tangy balance, and zero puckering flavors after the finish. Fairly crisp/clean finishing. Moderate increasing dryness from lingering tang/tartness, and carbonation. Medium-plus carbonation and light-medium body; with a very smooth, moderately grainy/acidic/tangy, and lightly saline balanced mouthfeel that is great. Zero warming alcohol as expected of 4.2%. Overall this is an excellent flavored gose. All around great complexity, robustness, and balance of gummy candy, fruity/acidic yeast, and moderate pale/wheat malt flavors; very smooth, crisp, clean, and refreshing to drink with the modestly acidic/tangy/drying finish; not overly lactic/salty. Very flavorful and not watery for the ABV. Feels like sour patch kids were used. Great balance of juicy candy and Lacto complexity; with a nice solid pale/wheat malt backbone against acidity. Zero residual sweetness with crisp acidic/tangy candy drying. A very enjoyable offering, and well made style example as expected. No complaints.\xa02,393 characterssuperspak, Jun 30, 2019']

name: Little Man Tate: Cherries, Raspberries & Cranberries
review:
['4.17/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4.25 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4 | overall: 4.25A: Pours a clear but almost opaque dark reddish purple in color with moderate amounts of fine active visible carbonation rising quickly along the edges of the glass and moderate deep garnet red + ruby red + burnt orange + copper colored highlights. The beer has a two finger tall dense fizzy foamy pinkish white head that reduces to a large patch of very thin film covering a little more than 75% of the surface of the beer and a thin ring at the edges of the glass. Minimal amounts of lacing are observed.

S: Just shy of moderate aromas of slightly sour wheat malts with a moderate amount of lacto + tart lemon citrus underneath slightly stronger than moderate aromas of tart and slightly sweet berries (raspberries, cranberries, and cherries). Hints of brininess. 

T: Upfront there are slightly lighter than moderate flavors of slightly sour wheat malts with minimal amounts of grainy sweetness. That is followed by moderate flavors of lacto + tart lemon citrus. Finally there are slightly stronger than moderate flavors of tart yet still slightly sweet cranberries, raspberries, and cherries. Slightly heavier than light amounts of lingering tartness in the finish and hints of brininess.

M: Just shy of medium bodied with moderate amounts of carbonation. Light to moderate amounts of acidic prickliness.

O: Easy to drink with well hidden alcohol and just enough tartness (without being overly sour). Enjoyable with really nice flavors/aromas of the fruits over a very nice base gose. I could easily have a couple of these.\xa01,530 charactersdbrauneis, Mar 26, 2019']

review: ['3.85/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 4 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.75Pours a clear, straw coloration with a small, fizzy, quickly receding head. Taste follows the nose, with mildly sour notes of green apple, white grape and apricot and just a hint of spice coming through as well, pepper being most prominent, but a little coriander as well. Finishes quite crisp and dry, with a very light sourness and saltiness. I feel like this is a very nice "beginner gose", to get aquainted with the style. All the expected components are there, the sourness, the spiciness, the saltiness and very well balanced, but also very mild. Very crisp and refreshing, but perhaps too mild for some.\xa0684 charactersSnowcrash000, Mar 15, 2018']

name: Horse of a Different Color - No. 003 - Lime Gose Ale
review:
['4.23/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.5 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 4.25The CANQuest (tm) is back for New Tying Up Loose Ends Beer Sunday, Redux (Week 760)! I am going to see "Hustlers" this afternoon so I wanted to get an early start. I have to cop to cheating … sorta. This one was not a part of the backlog, but knowing that today was on the horizon, I snagged it at the FGBS on Friday night with an eye to today. It still hearkens back to Week 759.

From the CAN: "Another matter entirely. Unique brews that run the gamut of the beer style palette from batch to batch."

I have alluded to it before, but while not being much of a Tart/Sour guy, I have a real affinity for Goses. It is the inclusion of (usually Sea) salt that really sends me as a retired sailor. Lime? Mmm. 

Having Crack!ed open the vent, the room suddenly filled with the scent of salt & lime! Phew. I mouth beCAN to water as I performed a heavy-handed aggro C-Line Glug into the awaiting glass. I got just under two rolling fingers of foamy, soapy, rocky, bone-white head with low retention for my efforts, quickly dissipating away to wisps. Color was an oh-so-slightly-hazy Yellow-Gold (SRM = 4 - 5). Leaning in for a sniff, the nose was REALLY salty, held in check by the lime citrusiness. Mmm. Mouthfeel was thin & watery, but on par for the style. The taste was REALLY tart & puckering, like liquefied alum! Once the initial tartness subsided, the lime & salt REALLY asserted themselves! Phew. Tart, salty, lime citrusy, this one had it all! Of course, I was having a tough time prising my lips open, but that was a horse of a different color. It CAN only be described as dry, tart & highly refreshing. Finish was super-dry, leading me to reach for my asthma inhaler. Phew.\xa01,681 characterswoodychandler, Sep 15, 2019']

name: Sangria Gose
review:
['3.47/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.5 | smell: 3.25 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.51st review of this beer on BA. Mammoth didn't divulge their offerings at the Strange Brew festival ahead of time, so you just kind of showed up and saw what they had. This one didn't sound disgusting so I gave it a try, and was surprised it was one of the better beers of the festival held on May 18, 2019.

Pours a shade of color that is more akin to sangria than your traditional gose. Light red and purple color, looks a little bit like a cranberry vodka, thin almost nonexistant head of about 1/10" in a lighter shade of that purple/pink/red regime. Had that red wine barrel nose to it, earth, dark grape, dark oak nose. Not much for salinity there, still hasn't shown itself to me much of a traditional gose by any means. 

Taste was where it excelled, there was a brackish in the slightest form of a red wine meets gose vibe going on, a little bit of dark cherry and blackberry note to it. The mouth feel was very dry. Lots of oak and tannin dryness. Was a good beer, glad to have checked it out, shit I'd even vote they package this one up. They haven't had many new recipes the last 20 years, might be time.\xa01,125 charactersrodbeermunch, Jun 10, 2019']

name: Dragon Drink
review:
["4.04/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4.25 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4L: Had this on-tap at Westbrook's tasting room, poured into a taster. Had a bright red color and super cloudy consistency. Looked like cherry Kool-Aid. There was a thin, foamy, off white, somewhat long-lasting head. Not much lacing here.

S: A sweet and fruity aroma of citrus fruit, tropical fruit, coconut, and malt.

T: Tasted of a bit of coconut (a little fleeting), light malt notes (mostly in the finish), a ton of tropical fruit (dragonfruit, mango, pineapple), and a little citrus fruit (lemon). A super fruity, slightly sour flavor. It's a little odd at first, but it grows on you after awhile. Light and effervescent.

F: A good amount of carbonation with a vibrant finish. Light-bodied.

O: An interesting and well done take on the gose. Worth a try.\xa0761 charactersavalon07, Aug 01, 2019"]

name: What Gose Round - Dry Hopped
review:
["4.25/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4.25 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.25Murky opaque pale yellow orange, compact layer of surface foam that leaves behind some lacing. 
Dry hop is most noticeable in the aroma, the citrus and green botanicals compliment the tart juicy gose. 
Tart and fruity with a citrusy edge, smooth and slightly pulpy feel, very light hop flavor present.
Tart lacto, zero bitterness, a touch of salinity was noticeable at a well-balanced level.
Overall this was a great variation on the standard gose, which is always a go-to for me.

Interestingly they offered blood orange and lingonberry syrups as an addition at the bar. 
Maybe they'll brew some fruited versions in the future...\xa0630 charactersemerge077, Dec 31, 2017"]

name: Gose
review: ['3.58/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.5according to the lady behind the bar they are still working on this one, and it has changed a bit from batch to batch. the current iteration is extremely mild on the sourness, and while it is clean and seemingly well done from a technical standpoint, there isnt enough of it to really make this beer as distinctive and refreshing as gose normally is, not enough acidity to cut all the wheat in here, and it seems a little bland and heavy for the style. the wheat malt is fresh, but its also fairly sturdy, and more sourness would really help lighten it up. nice lemony freshness to the lacto too, so more of it would be welcomed, none of the normal young brewery trying a sour sweaty or cheesy off flavors, very tidy with it. the other side of this though, is that it probably is a little more approachable and has wider appeal than a lot of sours, even most gose types, and this could serve as a great introduction to them for those not yet on board. this is not a far jump from american pale wheat ale, especially one served with a citrus wedge, and i could see it making some converts. a bit plain for me, but well made.\xa01,123 charactersStonedTrippin, Aug 13, 2017']

name: Pineapple Parade

name: Mango and Passionfruit Gose
review: ['3.66/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.5 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.5very light take on the style, which part of me like and part of me dislikes, both about equally actually. the like part is that its not overdone on the fruit, so it still tastes like beer. its natural enough, and the tried and true combination of mango and passion fruit does its thing pretty well here. its summery and drinkable and fun. the dislike part is that the base beer would be almost irrelevant without the fruit, light as it is, which is to say that its thin, bland, and unexciting it appears. not much body or character from the wheat at all, a crisp sort of briny mineral thing is really all, a fast lactic twang too, but its there and gone, giving way to the fruit long before the finish. i could see this turning some newcomers on to conventionally sour beer where it has been intimidating before, this is mighty approachable, but it lacks the texture and complexity that the best beers in the style have. good carbonation helps though, and the fruit is tasty. overall good not great on this one. seems like everyone is making a fruited gose right now...\xa01,069 charactersStonedTrippin, Oct 09, 2018']

name: Sultry Maiden
review:
["3.71/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.75 | smell: 4 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.75Lightly hazed, nearly crimson in color, lush, off-white head. Looking good, but definitely different from other goses I’ve seen.

In the nose: fruity. funky. odd. floral. something’s been added to this? hibiscus? pomegranate? You never know, these days. (Maybe I'm imagining it?)

In the mouth: tart, then sweet. Fruity, yes, but not fruit-infused, I don’t think. Salty. Smooth. Refreshing. Tasty. Something akin to chocolate malt is coming through. Am I imagining this, amidst the coriander and sea salt?

Tartness returns again with each new sip, goes down easy. It’s not as intensely puckering as some may want, but it’s got the tart and it’s individual. Special. Approachable. And I can dig it. Nice try.\xa0720 charactersfeloniousmonk, Oct 26, 2017"]

name: It's Pronounced Gose
review: ['3.79/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 4 | overall: 3.75a simple and well made gose, a little raw to me, but drinkable and good, oddly delicate, even for the style, but a beer that checks all the boxes, although perhaps somewhat less inspired and compelling than i have gotten used to with these guys. i also am quite sure i have seen several other breweries make beer by this same name, i guess the gose puns are inevitable and probably have to start doubling or tripling up at some point. in any event, its tasty beer, brewed with pink salt, full of minerals and it shows along with the wheat, giving this a crispness almost like it has been lagered which i really like, a high iron property or something, its cool, drying, and acts as the point of distinction in an otherwise rather samey beer. a little sweatiness to the lacto, but the sourness is light and this element seems sort of secondary. some lemon notes also highlighted by the salt, and more pils malt than wheat when i taste it fully. overall this is summer and tasty, a little refinement away from being awesome, but id drink a few of these in a sitting if given the chance...\xa01,086 charactersStonedTrippin, Oct 07, 2018']

name: Freshie Moka Coffee Gose
review:
['3.78/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 4 | feel: 3 | overall: 4Yo, yo, yo... wassup my main G’s? Been a while, yes - I took some time out after review #900 to rest my liv-actually I was just about to lie, I’ve still been drinking beer, just needed a break from writing reviews, you think this stuff just comes natural to me? Well, anyway, here’s another Nomad Gose, this one caught my eye because - coffee in my Gose? That sounds intriguing. I bit into Nomad’s pitch hook, line, sinker. As the label states “In Napoli they add a pinch of salt to their morning espresso”... never knew that, I might have to give it a go sometime. So I’m a sucker for coffee, I love it, and when two things I love come together... well that’s why I love coffee beers so much - it’s the best of both worlds (sometimes!).

Poured from a 330ml can into a Duvel tulip.

A: Easily the darkest Gose I’ve encountered - with a deep black/brown body and a splotchy mocha-coloured blanket on top. The head bubbles look reasonably dense, so the mouthfeel should be decent, cool as brah. 8/10.

S: Roast cold drip coffee mingles with coffee bean, and a nutty/earthy note, hint of salt as well. Some beers don’t even smell like beer to me anymore, and this is one of them - the coffee notes dominate the olfactory senses and we end up with an aroma that could only be described as “coffee soda”... that’s what it reminds me of: Those Asian cans of coffee - Mr. Brown I think it’s called. 7/10.

T: Cold drip coffee front/back/all over with a granular earthy/nutty character, a touch of malt sweetness (like the teaspoon of coconut blossom sugar I add to my morning coffee) with, yep you guessed it - sea salt. The sea salt gives this brew a palate drying effect which works well. Finish finds that fine line between bitter and sweet (and salty). Surprisingly delightful brew this! 8/10.

M: Mid to light - a touch watery - with a very dense (and unfortunately flat) carbonation. Here’s the weakest link of this brew: Lack of body and carbonation, it’s not a game-killer though. 6/10.

D: I liked this. It was slightly sweet, slightly bitter, slightly salty, and coffee all over - if you’re adverse to those things then steer clear, if not this is a tasty brew that I can imagine having as a breakfast beer. As far as Goses go(ses) this is probably one of the best - though it’s the least to style - one that I’ve had. Hopefully Nomad will make more so I can get my coffee/beer fix heading in to summer (which is apparently now in Queensland dammit). 8/10.

Food match: Not sure why but this brew made me want a cannolo... I need help.\xa02,579 charactersdoktorhops, Sep 21, 2017']

name: Who Cares Editions Snake Charmer Smoked Gose
review: ["4.1/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.5 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 4.25Experimental, smoked gose. It pours slightly hazy yellow with short lasting small white head. Very spicy and interesting smell; it contains coriander, smoke and citrusy aroma. Taste is very complex, but slightly sharp. Moderately lemon like tartness comes with lots of salt and this saltiness lasts into the finish, but smoky woodiness and peppery spices support balance. Low-medium bodied and carbonation is low for a gose. It's not very easy to drink, bur I really like its complexity and refreshment. Very innovative!\xa0520 charactersemincems, Aug 27, 2018"]

name: Ledergosen
review: ['4.15/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4.5 | overall: 4.512 ounce can into tulip glass, canned in 9/2019. Pours lightly hazy/cloudy golden amber color with a 1 finger fairly dense and fluffy off white head with good retention, that reduces to a thin spotty lace cap that lingers. Light spotty soapy lacing clings on the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of big juicy/tart/tangy black cherries, fruit skin/pits, lemon, lime, orange, peach, pear, apricot, melon, red/green apple, red grape/wine, sea salt, coriander, hay, straw, grass, wheat, cracker, white bread, light peppercorn/lacto funk, and yeast earthiness. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of cherries, fruity/acidic yeast, coriander, sea salt, and moderate pale/wheat malt notes; with big strength. Taste of big juicy/tart/tangy black cherries, fruit skin/pits, lemon, lime, orange, peach, pear, apricot, melon, red/green apple, red grape/wine, sea salt, coriander, hay, straw, grass, wheat, cracker, white bread, light peppercorn/lacto funk, and yeast earthiness. Light-moderate fruity/lactic tartness, fruit tang, and light coriander spiciness on the finish. Lingering notes of tart/tangy black cherries, fruit skin/pits, lemon, lime, orange, peach, pear, apricot, melon, red/green apple, red grape/wine, sea salt, coriander, hay, straw, grass, wheat, cracker, white bread, light peppercorn/lacto funk, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Awesome complexity, robustness, and balance of cherries, fruity/acidic yeast, coriander, sea salt, and moderate pale/wheat malt flavors; with a fantastic malt/tartness and tangy fruit balance; with no puckering/astringent flavors after the finish. Fairly crisp/clean finishing. Light-moderate increasing dryness from lingering tang/tartness and carbonation. Medium-plus carbonation and light body; with a very smooth, moderately bready/grainy/acidic/tangy/tannic, and lightly sticky/saline balanced mouthfeel that is fantastic. Zero warming alcohol as expected of 4.2%. Overall this is an outstanding fruited gose. All around awesome complexity, robustness, and balance of cherries, fruity/acidic yeast, coriander, sea salt, and moderate pale/wheat malt flavors; very smooth, crisp, clean, and refreshing to drink with the mellowly acidic/tangy/tannic/drying finish. Very flavorful and not watery for the ABV. Not overly lactic/salty. Awesome balance of juicy/jammy cherries and Lacto complexity; with a great clean pale/wheat malt backbone against acidity. Minimal residual sweetness with crisp acidic/tangy dryness. A highly enjoyable offering, and outstanding spot on style example.\xa02,585 characterssuperspak, Sep 28, 2019']

name: Rum Barrel Aged Tropical Gose
review:
["3.86/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.75 | smell: 4 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 4There's no way that a sour German ale could link up well with rum barrels. Right? Never underestimate the brewing prowess that comes when Blue Stallion Brewing teams up with Wilderness Trail Distilling. On thing's for sure, that Leipzig styled gose never saw this coming.

Picking up a lot of caramelized color from the barrel, the Rum Barrel Aged Tropical Gose pours a chestnut bush color with a fairly light haze. As a short lived froth builds on the beer, the nose leads with a gentle sweetness and spiciness of rum with a twinge of citrus and tropical succulence and sourness. And that shy caramelization shows up early on the palate with a toasty, nutty taste of cashew, candy and sourdough.

As the flavors unfold on the middle palate, the caramel gives way to the natural fruit flavors of cider, wine, lime, lemon and passionfruit. As the nutty cocktail-like taste steers from the normal taste of gose, the barrel brings a surprising flavor of candied apples with a light simmer of classic rum alcohol and peppery spice.

The sour ale picks up a slight heft as it takes on new lift which jeopardizes its refreshment and effortlessness on the palate, but its added complexity is charming as it fares much better than once believed.\xa01,237 charactersBEERchitect, Jan 15, 2019"]

name: Washed Overboard
review: ['4.09/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.75 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4 | overall: 4an awfully delicious beer from one of the most underrated breweries in colorado. i have not had many sours from these guys, but this one is on point for a hot summery day, a margarita inspired gose, brewed with lime and lime leaf and sea salt, i think they absolutely nailed it! it smells really fragrant, the lime leaf is strong and fresh and obvious, but before it becomes too much, there is some more acidic juicy lime character and piquant tartness from the souring that come in, smells amazing, and makes my mouth water like crazy to sip it. ive never really thought of something smelling refreshing, but this somehow does! the flavor is great too, a more balanced lime character from start to finish, and not so much of it that i cant taste the grain. i get a cool zested element as well as some vegetal bitterness for a flash, like the waxy peel of a cucumber or something, summery as well, and a nice counterpoint, wherever it comes from. the salt is full of minerals and not real subtle, a cool brine aspect to it, and nice with all the wheaty body in here, this still drinks like a beer, not a soda or a cocktail, which is hard to do at this flavor intensity. its also something i want to drink several of, which is almost never the case with these fruited kettle sours, so nicely done there as well! the tart has some linger, and the beer isnt quite dry, but i dont mind it hanging around a little bit. really flavorful and delicious beer overall, has clear margarita elements, and has some awesome can art as well. pick some up and treat yourself this summer!\xa01,571 charactersStonedTrippin, Aug 09, 2019']

name: Blueberry Balsamic Gose
review:
["3.69/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.75On tap at Fifth Frame Brewing Co in Rochester, NY.

This one pours a dark purplish color, with a small head, and a bit of lacing.

Luckily, this smells mostly like blueberry, with a touch of balsamic funkiness on the back end. There's a touch of salinity on the nose, and some lemon as well.

I had heard from some people that this beer was truly horrific. Luckily, it's not that bad. I'm not fully sold on balsamic in beer, so luckily that flavor is pretty light here. There's a lot of sour blueberry, and some lemon zest maybe, and a touch of saltiness on the back end.

This is light bodied, crisp and clean and fairly juicy, with a good level of drinkability.

This is definitely unique, and that's to be commended. I enjoyed it, but don't really ever need it again.\xa0770 charactersGreesyFizeek, Jan 02, 2019"]

name: Gherkin
review: ['3.75/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.75a dill pickle inspired gose, so weird we had to try! i think they did a really good job with this, and most of their flavored beers were solid in here to be honest, this is creative and not over the top, making it better than just a novelty drink. the basic gose is simple and light, only minimally sour, and built to support the added ingredients. the tartness is clean, the wheat is obvious, and the salt seems just right, with the fresh dill in here it really does have a pickle brine aroma and flavor to it, and the acidity is no more than a tangy pickle, really pretty right on for what it is. its hard to tell whether or not this is good, and its probably entirely subjective, like how much do you love pickles, but the beer is well made either way, and i was pretty impressed with this. the dill is really fragrant and natural to me, while there is a light citrus note as well. i think it would be cool to add in another dimension or two, like some caraway, hot pepper, or even garlic to this to give it a bit more of real pickle nuance, but the beer as it stands is undoubtedly a success, and the saltiness is really cool with the pickle flavor, it completes the theme nicely. light and springy too, well worth trying!\xa01,226 charactersStonedTrippin, Apr 29, 2019']

name: Beltane - Universal Mind
review: ['3.77/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4.5 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.75Tasted in a Rastal Teku from a one pint can on February 8, 2019. A collaboration beer with Windmill Brewing Company in Dyer, IN. Kettle soured Gose style ale. Gentle acidity pairs with sea salt, blueberries, lemon zest and rosemary for a truly unique flavor. Has a beautiful clear purple hue.\xa0292 charactersHopheadjeffery, Feb 11, 2019']

name: Brombeere
review: ['4.25/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4.25 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.25this is truly about as good as it gets in the fruited gose style, incredibly fruit forward, but also full bodied for its strength, dry, and drinkable, a really fine specimen. the color is insane on this, past pink but short of purple, with some haze and some fluffy white head atop it, looks right on for the style, and i love it having some body and character form the wheat, not enough of these do anymore. there are a few things about this that make it awesome, the sourness being the first among them, its mild but clean, tart but not acidic in a way that slows drinkability, and i feel like its real playful with the fruit, a perfect match, nothing about this makes me want to only have one. the salt is also right on, seems so perfectly suited to the blackberry, adding minerals in the finish, body throughout, and a decided dryness to finish, surprising for a beer so profoundly fruity earlier on. wheaty and fresh, spunky and new, fruity but not jammy, good complexity in a simple beer too. these guys covered all the bases, and this was among their best. good fun, i love drinking beer like this, a surprise, an underground hero, the best of their sours!\xa01,163 charactersStonedTrippin, Mar 03, 2019']

name: Oaxaca Shaka
review: ['3.74/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.5 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.75a gose with lime and coriander here, both quite pronounced. it pours quite hazy and a little dull looking, but smells really fresh and good, with a fresh zested vibe to the lime and some minerals from the salt really accentuating it. i like all the wheat flavor and body this has, and while it might not be as drinkable and minimal and refreshing as i often like in the style, i also like the malt not being lobotomized, the extra body and flavor isnt heavy or sweet, and its a nice base for all the flavor. the coriander is natural and good, comes on strongest in the finish, and the whole thing really isnt very sour. its nice because its clean, no weird sloppy lacto souring, but it also doesnt quite get to the acidity level i feel like the style sort of demands. acidulated malt in the mix giving a little pucker, but thats all. a little longer to finish than most with all the lime, but the flavors are summer and appropriate. less carbonation than it should have kind of drags it down a little bit, but overall i like this pretty well. these beers continue to be hit and miss from western collective, but this one is promising.\xa01,134 charactersStonedTrippin, Jul 17, 2019']

name: A-Salt and Blackberry
review:
['4.19/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4.25 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.25From a crowler can filled 12/06/18

Appearance - Pours opaque and deep violet with a bright pink, finger width head. Fair retetion before dying to a thin, broken layer of suds and a thin ring around the edge of the glass. Some broken webbing that hangs near the surface; lines and spotting further up the glass make up the lacing.

Smell - Aroma hits on blackberry sweetness, lemon or lime tartness and some salinity. 

Taste - Follows the nose. Blackberry flavors upfront and throughout, with some lime-like tartness and a nice salty kick to round out a simple but tasty flavor profile. 

Mouthfeel - Light-to-medium in body with fair, tingly carbonation. Slick, easy drinker with a crisp, refreshing finish. 

Overall - Damn good gose that works on all levels. Well done.\xa0773 charactersTheSixthRing, Dec 10, 2018']

name: Anything Gose
review:
['3.76/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.5 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 4 | overall: 3.75Type: 16-oz. can
Glass: Westvleteren 12 Trappist
From: Chad
Price: N/A 
Purchased: N/A; Received Nov. 17, 2017
Consumed: Dec. 31, 2017
Reviewed as: Gose 
Misc.: No canned on date

Thanks, Chad!

Got this as part of a nice haul from Chad on his latest work trip to San Diego. He has raved about Lead Dog, but I think this would be my first time having one from them. I had to add this to Beer Advocate, so my guess it was a very new beer. On the can it read, “This delicious Gose is touched by a hint of sea salt which lends to a refreshing and crisp tartness that may be enjoyed by sour lovers. And even those who still have their training wheels on. We age this Gose with sweet and tart cherries to deliver a red color and slightly sweet finish.” Was looking forward to it.

Poured a medium amber clear color with one finger of fizzy off-white head. Lots of fast-moving bubbles coming up from the bottom of the glass. Average watery lacing. Good retention. (Sight - 3.50)

Smelled tart cherries up front, followed immediately by sea salt. Also cranberry, coriander peel, citrus zest, cereal and grass. (Smell - 3.75)

Tasted a little better than the nose. Not as much a salt as I would’ve thought, which I didn’t mind. Got cherry, cranberry, coriander zest, cereal, grain, hints of cinnamon and earthy salt grass. (Taste - 3.75)

Light body. Thin-to-oily texture. Average carbonation. Abrupt finish. (Feel - 4.00)

Still new to the style, but this was at least very good overall. I was back and forth on a few of the categories. (Overall - 3.75)

3.76 | 85 | B+\xa01,570 charactersBucannonXC5, Jan 02, 2018']

review:
["3.32/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 3.25 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.25Pale foggy white-yellow with a thin fluffy blanket.

Taste is tart watermelon Jolly Rancher with a light salty accent and some white grain via a soft, light body and a semi-sticky dry finish.

While the taste is very candy-esque, the smell is more in line with the Gose style, with a natural wheat and salty ocean aroma.

Before I said this is a killer Summer crusher that should be in more hands ASAP. But now (Summer 2019) I think there's too much of an essential oil/perfume vibe.\xa0483 charactersSabtos, Jul 16, 2018"]

name: Tropical Gose
review:
["4.24/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.25The temperatures may be falling but the imagination at Blue Stallion is just heating up. Teaming with local Ethereal brewers, the popular German-style gose meets a tropical fruit addition to add complexity to the natural citrus, apple and melon character of the base beer. 

Bright straw and with a light translucent glow, the beer shares a mild pinkish hue from the colorful dragonfruit. A zesty and sprite froth swells and quickly collapses upon itself for a still but peppy appearance. Tangy aromas of cider, white wine, citrus and tropical fruits capture an essence of hawaiian punch with the soft must of the sea. Sweet and sour on the palate, a hint of sour patch kids ride on the heels of wheat and pilsner bready sweet flavor.

The sweetness dissolves on the middle palate and the bright fruitiness takes center stage. Lime, lemon, crabapple, sour green grape, gooseberry and kiwi flavors meld seamlessly with the exotic and slight robust tropical fare of passionfruit and dragonfruit. Low on hops, its the brazen sourness of the lactic fermentation that chases a clean and acidic finish as a return of sea and brine return.

Giving the light bodied beer a little more robust and bright flavor, the mild salt additions add a fullness to the beer's flavor without sacrificing cleanliness or crispness. Perfumy coriander allows for a finish of orange peel bitterness and earthy burlap after palate.\xa01,404 charactersBEERchitect, Jan 10, 2017"]

name: Fifty Fifty
review:
['3.47/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.5I don't see a bottle or import date listed.

Appearance: The body is opaque and dark puple-red with a brown tint to it. It is mostly opaque. The head is short and off-white with a slight pinkish hue. It fades out to a fluffy ring. No retention.

Aroma: There is a soft cream of wheat aroma with a light scent of raspberries.

Taste: The beer has a light tart raspberry flavor.

Mouthfeel: The beer is a bit tart with a light saltiness that forms around the lips while drinking. It is light bodied and smooth. Very drinkable.

Overall: The label says this is a "Sour Ale Brewed With Raspberries, Licorice and Salt." While there was an obvious raspberry flavor there wasn't even a hint of licorice. The beer is nice but it doesn't seem to be quite what the brewer has intended for it to be. I would still drink it again and recommend it to those who love raspberries.\xa0865 charactersteromous, Nov 17, 2019']

name: Strawberry Gose
review:
["3.53/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.5 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.5650ml bottle - the second in their Forage Series, inspired by wild Alberta strawberries. Yum!

This beer pours a clear, pale bronzed amber colour, with three fingers of puffy, finely foamy, and somewhat fizzy pink-tinged white head, which leaves pretty much nothing in the way of lace anywhere near the glass as it quickly dissipates.

It smells of gritty and grainy cereal malt, saltine crackers, some musty yeastiness, faint indistinct berry fruity notes, and ethereal earthy, leafy, and floral noble hop bitters. The taste is bready and grainy pale malt, saline solution, some mealy dark fruitiness, fading estery yeast, and more well-understated earthy, musty, and floral green hoppiness.

The carbonation is adequate in its palate-pinging frothiness, the body a basic medium weight, and mostly smooth, as only the mild salty essence may be a small cause for concern here. It finishes trending dry, the malt maintaining a crackery lingering stance.

Overall - yeah, this is certainly more 'gose', than 'strawberry' in its bearing. It's not bad, but I was imagining that burst of insane fruity goodness that you get when eating one of those tiny strawberries you find growing on the sides of mountain hiking paths in the late summer. Ah well.\xa01,250 charactersbiboergosum, Jun 29, 2018"]

name: Biplane
review:
['4.22/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4.5 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 4.75Pours almost clear and very pale with a five-inch, fine, white meringue. The long lasting head eventually condenses to a one-inch foam with big bubbles after leaving patchy lace. Slow, lazy, tiny bubbles meander within a Stiegl stange.

Funky brine plays well with light lemon hops. This Gose is earthy with white pepper and coriander.

The flavor is dry with tart lemon, salty and fresh. It is equally light bitter and light sweet. A quick mild finish follows the nose while warmth introduces grapes.

The body is surprisingly full with a smooth soft texture. Modest fine carbonation helps elevate this very dry palate with no alcohol presence.

This is an excellent beer for relaxing and quite a surprise. It is refreshing, interesting and very welcome.\xa0755 charactersSLeffler27, Aug 05, 2017']

name: Tampa Timeshare
review:
["4.19/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4 | feel: 4.75 | overall: 4.25(Grapefruit-Basil version).

Appearance: Pours a rather faint, nigh hueless appearance, just a wisp of pale straw yellow. Head, about an inch, white in color.

Smell: Grapefruit, its usage can really trounce things with unabashed sharp, citric bitterness. Basil, its usage can really trounce things with what seems akin to something of a juice cleanse diet. I'll admit, I was hesitant. Okay, so I grimaced reading the label. However, the aromatics are nicely blended and play well together. Underneath, a delicate tartness, a noted salinity and a touch of sour wheatiness.

Taste: Sourish, lactic wheat, albeit thin on the wheat with a quick, brief, low-level sweetness. Early on, the salt content, while never overwrought, is quickly discernible. Mildly juicy, citrusy from the grapefruit and has that unmistakable herbal zip from the basil -- both without going overboard and having me trudge off to the nearest sink. The salt has both an accumulative and sort of cleansing effect, aided by a little final spritz of carbonation at the finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-thin body. Medium-plus carbonation.

Overall: A pleasant surprise.\xa01,130 charactersChainGangGuy, Jun 15, 2019"]

name: Meyer Lemon Gose
review: ['4.25/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4.25 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.25one of the better fruited gose types i have had in awhile, and frankly, its one of the better beers in the denver market right now, certainly the most unsung. its light and bright and refreshing with perfect proportionality. clear for the style, bright yellow, lighter than gold, with a foaming white head on top slowly settling back. it smells like lemons and oranges, the essence of the meyer lemon to me, zesty and really pretty robustly dosed, enhanced by the salt i can tell, even though i cant smell the salt necessarily, if that makes sense. the lacto side here is subtle, not acidic enough to cover up or break down the wheat, which i like, very clean and also enhancing of the lemon. the flavor is just like the nose, with the fresh meyer bursting forth from it, specifically meyer lemon too, a little sweeter with more of a tangerine twist worked into the sourness of the lemon, tangy and like just zested, very intense in such a light beer, almost a natural lemonade complexion. the lacto is perfectly sympathetic to that, the exact right amount of acidity, and the salt adds a brine sort of mineral complexion thats just gorgeous. this beer is like the first day of spring, its uplifting and sunny and the kind of satisfying that only can come after a long way. spry carbonation here, delicate body that still tastes like wheat, and a clean dry finish. this is impressive beer, i am surprised these guys havent gotten more attention for stuff like this...\xa01,467 charactersStonedTrippin, Jan 31, 2018']
