name: Margaritioactive Gose
review: ['3.55/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 2 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.25 | overall: 3.5definitely a weird one, actually brewed with tequila and triple sec, along with some lime juice to mimic the classic cocktail. it sure is peculiar, and really doesnt drink like a beer at all. its tart sure, they actually did a pretty reasonable job with the lacto souring, but i get almost no grain or yeast or hop elements to the beer at all, instead its limey, spicy from the tequila, and whatever the heck this red salt is they put on the rim is making it incredibly salty. looks like it could be a chili salt or something, and chunks of it float around the still looking brass colored brew, visually brutal, but we both like the taste. its really limey, but the tequila is obvious too, and there is a stone fruit sweetness here thats kind of cool, it definitely is margarita-esque with the salt too, and the sourness works with it, sort of at the same pitch as the lime. i wish it had more bubbles and a little more beer character, and i really dont like looking at it with all this salt and whatever else is on the rim floating around in it, but when i close my eyes and drink it, its refreshing and good. ill have to file this one away among one of the stranger beers ive had, but better this to be a little wonky when trying something so out there than a wonky basic hefe, which we also had in here...\xa01,308 charactersStonedTrippin, Oct 16, 2019']

name: Guayaba Chica
review: ['4.08/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4.25 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4Gose ale brewed with pink guava. Poured from a 16oz can into a New Belgium tulip. The pour is pale gold with a slight haze and a thin head with good retention for a sour brew. I definitely get the guava fruit on the nose, along with some grapefruit pulp, lemon, and a hint of honeydew melon.\n\nLight body with a soft feel and a refreshing, fruity flavor. Up front is a brief, faint, grainy sweetness that is quickly followed up by guava, some lemon, and a bit of salinity. It almost reminds me of citrus cooler-flavored gatorade. The guava and lemon intensify as the beer moves across the palate. The finish is fruity and a little dry. Overall, the beer is easy to drink and very thirst-quenching. It is true to the style, yet the guava gives a nice added dimension.\xa0765 charactersdeadonhisfeet, Jul 11, 2019']

name: Government Gose - Key Lime
review:
["4.11/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 4No can date
Pours a very large fizzy foamy head that fades quickly, medium retention low lacing, very clear slight chill haze golden straw color

Nose nice gose out front, tart lacto funk and acidity, little lemony but big key lime aroma as well, big juicy key lime

Taste starts quite sour, tart lemony lacto creamy acidity, light malt and straw, doughy bread but not cracker, big key lime juice again, like pure juice dumped in, bringing a tart acidity of its own, dry sight bready finish, little flemmy with lingering acidity and tartness, lemon lime lingering. Juicy and tasty, with a bit of salt

Mouth is med to lighter bod, bright acidity and a little flemmy, lower carb

Overall this was pretty good, nice gose base with good salt and lacto sour acidity, nice juicy key lime, could benefit from a bit more carbonation though, the can is carbonated but it doesn't suspend well due to lack of proteins/malt\xa0912 charactersjlindros, Aug 29, 2019"]

review:

Pours a clear straw gold, an inch of foam, some sticky lacing. 

Nose of mango, lightly salted, medium to medium light tartness judging from the smell. 

Mango tartness and yeah, the tartness is at a comfortable level. Light salt, light bodied without going watery. Seems like there's other fruit in here but I can't pull it out. 

Anywho, thoroughly enjoyable.\xa0408 charactersBitterbill, Oct 31, 2019"]

name: Seafarer
review: ['3.93/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4it seems like anymore these days every gose has to be spiked with some citrus or berry, lactose or vanilla, coffee or herbs, brett pitched or wood rested, its too much, and some of the beautiful simplicity and refreshment that brought the style back to prominence in recent years has been lost, at least in my opinion, so it was great to find this beer, a no frills gose, well made and summery, back to basics and very refreshing! just a very light pale yellow color, a lightly tart and briney nose and taste, simple wheat malt and a pils type barley underneath, piquant and lemony but not super acidic, but enormously clean and dry, like super well done on the lacto, the right balance of salt, faint coriander, earthy wheat, and uplifting tang, lemon character, even white wine elements, built for speed, and just delicious and well executed. i love the light body and high carbonation, and think this throwback is a direction more brewers should head in, sometimes less is more, and this is the proof!\xa01,004 charactersStonedTrippin, Jun 25, 2018']

name: Citrus Sales Guy
review:
['4.08/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4.25 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4So, a fruit salesman walks into a bar... and however that joke goes, the buyers for jolly pumpkin end up buying a ton of citrus fruit, and walah- Citrus Sales Guy is born.

A peppery nose carries overtones of sour citrus, white wine, cider and an earthen perfume of damp hay and weathered woods. Its pale golden hue with a wisping yet stable white froth leads in to a scant sweetness of wafer and lightly powdered sugar.

Its malty edge falls off and what's left of its wheaten character carries a creamy effervescence that highlights the beer's spicy side. Filled with fruit, its natural taste of lemon, lime, white grape and gooseberry is also deep with verbena and radiant orange peel. Seeming "young" in its fruit-forward display, the yeasty thumbprints of Jolly Pumpkin are all over the session with that spicy, yeasty, earthy and light medicinal notes. Hopped for tepid balance, a broad, woodsy and herbal bitterness links up with sourness for a bright and inquisitive drink.

Light in body, the beer's creaminess keeps the texture from absolute bone dryness. The salinity of the sea works with the salt for hints of a bitter margarita lurking in the recesses of complexity. Softly briny, bitter and acidic, the flavor and textures are short, crisp and refreshing.\xa01,270 charactersBEERchitect, Nov 17, 2016']

review:
['3.53/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.5 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.5On tap at Brewskival 2019.

Pours a bright red with some pink foam.

Smell is earthy and slightly sweet with huge notes of beets and a hint of grass.

Taste is earthy and slightly tart with notes of beets, citrus and a hint of pepper.

Mouthfeel is medium, well carbonated.

Overall, this really tastes like slightly tart beet soup. Very interesting!\xa0350 charactersJamFuel, Sep 01, 2019']

name: Chocolate Cherry Popsicle
review:
["4.23/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4.25 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4 | overall: 4.25On tap at The Answer as a Frozan.

Pours a dark red with a little bit of wispy foam.

Smell is chocolate covered cherries with a hint of tartness to it.

Taste is very much the same as the nose, with a little bit och citrus added. Very light acidity and a just a hint of salinity on the finish.

Mouthfeel is medium, well carbonated.

Overall, this is about as far from traditional as a gose goes, but it's very refreshing and very tasty.\xa0438 charactersJamFuel, Dec 08, 2018"]

name: A Room in Blue
review: ["3.59/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.5On tap at Beer O'Clock. Thanks, John!\n\nA rather clear deep blue-red with a lightly pinkish head, this beer looks solid. The nose is prominently sour and lactic with a strong blueberry character and a deep, mildly earthy and mineral-y sauvignon blanc character. Moderately tannic, calling to mind pomace, the grape character is interesting. Moderately salty as well. The palate opens with a bright and refreshing sourness, with the lactic and blueberry notes pairing nicely. The grape character is present on the mid-palate, more earthy and plum like than I was expecting - the lighter stone fruit notes seem to be whelmed by the blueberry and lactic sourness. Drying, sour and mildly salty on the finish, this beer does feel a little disjointed on the palate. All told, though, this beer is solid.\xa0797 charactersDefenCorps, Mar 20, 2019"]

name: Ourania - Pineapple + Coconut + Key Lime
review:
['4.6/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4.5 | smell: 4.5 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 5 | overall: 4.75On tap at Mortalis Brewing in Avon, NY.

This one pours a lightly hazy golden orange color, with a small head and lots of lacing.

This smells like tart lime, sour candy, coconut, pineapple fruit cup, and lemon.

I’m loving a lower alcohol take on their fruited sour, and one that’s not purely smoothie-esque. The coconut is light but adds a nice sweetness. The pineapple is fresh and juicy, tasting like those pineapple chunks from a fruit cup. The lime is the kicker, adding some light sourness. It’s a gose but I don’t really get any salinity.

This is light bodied and incredibly drinkable, with a super refreshing feel to it.

This is a nice change up from the usual Mortalis sour. It’s perfect for hot weather.\xa0726 charactersGreesyFizeek, Jun 27, 2019']

name: Fallen: Peach Apricot
review: ['3.62/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 4 | overall: 3.75Name to be changed soon, but this is the peach apricot gose variant.68 charactersWickedBeer, Oct 01, 2019']

name: Barrel Aged Fruited Gose
review: ['4.06/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.75 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 4a neat beer from grand teton, who really kills it with their barrel aged stuff. this is a gose in oak with cranberries and cherries, and is an awesome beer as we move into thanksgiving time. its pretty still and murky dense pinkish orange colored, with a piquant lactic nose and some jammy muddled cherry sweetness along with slightly sweetened puckery cranberry, both obvious in the aroma. i like this being a little stronger for the style, it comes with more body which i think is nice for the heavy fruit flavors and the bright acidity, both thrive in this bigger base beer context. the cherry and the cherry and the cranberry take turns being in the lead of one another, but its the cranberry that surprisingly enough comes through most overall, i think its to do with the acidity of the gose and the natural tartness of the cranberry mirroring each other. this could use more carbonation but the acid lightens it up, and the bacterial profile is fairly clean here. more barrel could also be in play, but overall i think this is well made and unique seasonal sour beer. another job well done by grand teton!\xa01,111 charactersStonedTrippin, Nov 20, 2017']

name: Hiveminder
review: ["4.19/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4Pours a translucent copper-yellow with a finger of white foam. Head does not linger long. Aroma is cellar stone, biscuity, grassy, nutty malts and a twinge of oak and honey. It smells very simple, with just a light twinge of lactic sour build-up at the back. Flavor profile brings about a little more nuance, with the initial honey, grassy, lemony, cellar stone qualities mingling with a touch of plum and fig towards the finish. While the opening isn't very sour, it takes a dramatic turn about mid-way, although it never cuts over the threshold of what is uncomfortable. Mouth feel is light and thin with a thin, moderate crispness. Overall, pieced together well folding together a little sweetness before a sour punch.\n\nServed in a 15.5oz Speigalau tulip from a 375mL bottle.\xa0778 charactersHarrison8, Nov 19, 2019"]

It has some really interesting flavors but it's not very intense and also a bit too flat.\xa0300 charactersCiocanelu, Aug 10, 2016"]

brewery: The Moon Under Water Pub & Brewery
name: Gila Gose
review:
['3.75/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.75Gose brewed with orange.

Can has an interesting quote:

"We were somewhere around Gila River, on the edge of the desert, when the Gose began to take hold"

Appearance - Pours a hazy sraw gold with four fingers of frothy bubbly white head.

Smell - orange, citrus peel, sea salt, sour aromas, spicy earthy hops, bready and biscuity malts, coriander, lemon, and earthy yeast. 

Taste - orange, citrus peel, coriander, and sea salt upfront. The sourness, spicy earthy hops, lemon, bready and biscuity malts follow suit. The earthy yeast rounds out the brew.

Mouthfeel - Medium bodied with high carbonation. Finishes sticky and tart with the orange peel and salt lingering.

Overall - A brew that displays the elements of the gose style well. An interesting concept using orange as one of the ingredients. A sessionable and respectable brew.\xa0839 charactersleaddog, Oct 06, 2019']

name: Vacation Island: Bahama Mama
review: ['4.26/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4 | overall: 4.5Pours a clear light rose with just a little fizz on top. Aroma is banana, pineapple, and coconut. It has a light and refreshing quality to its aroma. Flavor profile is coconut, pineapple, orange rind, and a touch of ginger. Mouth feel is light, crisp, and refreshing. Overall, a stellar refreshing session sour. Sour is a bit of a stretch. It has a light tartness to it, but no puckering lactic sour punch. \n\nServed in a 12oz snifter from a 22oz bottle.\xa0453 charactersHarrison8, Jan 10, 2018']

name: Gose
review:
['3.69/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.75On-tap 8/2/2015 at Natty Greene’s Tavern, in North Attleboro, MA served in a US tumbler pint glass.

A: The beer is a light gold color, with a large white head that fades slowly and leaves a thick lace on the glass.

S: The aroma is faint but contains wheat, esters, citrus and light caramelized malts.

T: The taste starts out with a citrusy burst of tartness which transitions into some sweetness. Then some mild breadiness comes in from wheat and a thin malt character creating a decent balance. The after-taste is slightly tart.

M: Crisp and a little smooth, light-to-medium body, medium carbonation, finish is clean.

O: Tasty, goes down easily, not too filling, mild kick, good representation of style, this is a solid beer to drink for a while if you’re in the mood for the style.\xa0792 charactersTheManiacalOne, Aug 02, 2015']

name: Leaping Llamas
review: ['4.03/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 416oz. can served in a willibecker. Best before end Sept. 2020. Pours a lovey, burnished orange with a slight haze to the clarity and a tight, one inch, bright white head embedded with pinpricks. Delicate swaths of lacing are revealed as the head recedes. Nose expresses citrus acid, sea salt and tropical fruit rind. Taste consistent with nose; however, notes of tropical fruit are revealed upfront; however, quickly dissipate as the rind, citric acid and salt crash like a wave over the palate. This Gose is puckeringly tart! Mouthfeel is light and bright with a pleasant creaminess due to the lactose. Acidity is pleasant and biting. Overall, an interesting and complex example of the style. A total flavor explosion.\xa0729 charactersJwale73, Nov 10, 2019']

Low ABV makes this very refreshing and sessionable, not an over whelming amount of tequila, not a boozy B.A. beer. Tasty!\xa0206 charactersrobotic_being, Nov 17, 2019']

Mouthfeel is medium, well carbonated.

Overall, a nice sour, maybe a little bit overreliant on the pineapple.\xa0388 charactersJamFuel, Dec 08, 2018']

name: Vacation Island: Blueberry Pina Colada
review: ['4.43/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4.5 | smell: 4.5 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.75Pours a ruby-pink with a pink foamy head. Head retention is good with good lacing left behind. Aroma is bright and blustery notes of blueberry, coconut, and rum. It smells like a delightful pina colada with mashed blueberries. Flavor profile is blueberry, and buttery coconut and rum. It has a light lactic sourness on the back end, but nothing near puckering levels. Mouth feel is a touch fizzy, and otherwise velvety, smooth, and crisp. It has a medium thickness. Overall, wow. The blueberry note is not at the least bit artificial, and tastes like a fresh mash of ripe blueberries. Coconut and rum are both present, and slightly buttery sweet. It sips so smooth, and would be equally at home on a sizzling hot beach, or a basement bottle share. \n\nServed in a 16oz snifter from a 22oz bottle.\xa0794 charactersHarrison8, Jan 18, 2018']

review: ['4.24/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.25this is awesome beer, better than i remember their previous gose being, this is more overtly salty, and the oak profile is really nice, its distinct to cascade, but still fits well within the style guidelines, just a little more flavorful and complex than a lot of these, more interesting on the fermentation side too. still insanely priced, like 16 bucks for the small bottle, seems high for what this is, but once i taste it i cant complain. its got a light golden color, good shine, and is pretty clear through most of the bottle, with a patchy white head and some slowly rising bubbles. the aroma here is puckery, lemony, lactic, and oak heavy, with subtle vanilla and coriander notes to it, really fresh somehow and mature at the same time, and there is some of the saltiness and minerals evident too, not apparently as sour as a lot of their beers are. the flavor is excellent, the brine character from the salt pops right away, the wheat malt base is clean with just a touch of floral honey sweetness through most of it, some nice wild funkiness on top of the tidy lacto souring, and not too much acidity or sting from it, mellowed well by the oak, hints of white wine, pear, coriander, lemon, and even elderflower. i love all the oak on it, and the salt that really picks up in the second half of it, drying, neat with the sourness, and kind of lasting, creating an earthy overall vibe for this. really solid example of the style, still overpriced, but downright delicious!\xa01,481 charactersStonedTrippin, Oct 19, 2019']

name: Barrel Aged Salty Bear
review: ["4.56/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4.5 | smell: 4.75 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4 | overall: 4.75750 ml bottle from Pilgrim's. Aroma is dark fruit, oak, caramel, lacto, gummy bears (not sure if the name of the beer is influencing that observation, but that's exactly what it smells like). Pours a deep dark brown with a long sustaining beige head. Taste is sour (7/10), acidic, salty and fruity. Like a bourbon barrel aged Duchesse De Bourgogne with salt and caramel. There's a faint sense of oxidation, but it's not obtrusive and it kind of compliments the flavors. Interesting concoction that's basically a salty Flanders Oud Bruin. This is really good and way exceeded my expectations.\xa0591 characterspoisoneddwarf, Jun 17, 2017"]

name: In the Hallway, With the Axe
review:
["3.23/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.5 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 3 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3473ml can - a 'Plum Gose', and also a reference to the board-game Clue, I presume, professor.

This beer pours a turbid, medium dishwater brown colour, with two fingers of puffy, finely foamy, and mildly bubbly off-white head, which leaves a bit of approaching headland profile lace around the glass as it quickly evaporates.

It smells of bready and doughy cereal malt, faint black stone fruit, a subtle earthy yeastiness, and very tame leafy, floral, and herbal green hop bitters. The taste is gritty and grainy caramel malt, some ethereal mixed pome and plum fruitiness, dead yeast cells, and more well-understated earthy, musty, and floral hoppiness.

The carbonation is adequate in its palate-supporting frothiness, the body a solid middleweight, and essentially smooth, with nothing going on here that might be a cause for concern at this particular juncture. It finishes off-dry, the Alberta malt running a one-man lingering show.

Overall - yeah, this one just doesn't cut it (pun initially unintended). It's not sour at all, you can barely detect the plum, and it winds up just seeming like an unfiltered amber ale. I'm tempted to take the titular advice with the rest of this, but I don't feel like cleaning up the attendant mess.\xa01,244 charactersbiboergosum, Jan 31, 2019"]

review:
["4.36/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4.5 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.5Poured from a 12oz can into a snifter at 50°F.

L: Cloudy, ruby red with a pink head that dissipates quickly leaving no head. Beautiful color.
S: Mild aroma dominated mostly by fruit, almost raspberry.
T: Tart, very juicy and fruit forward. Just enough salt with hint of breadiness on the finish. Don't get any coriander.
F: Medium carbonation, could use a bit more. Has that tingly, mouthwatering feel.
O: Fruit takes center stage on this Gose. Lovely fruit flavor and beautiful color with enough tartness and salt to still resemble a Gose and not a fruit beer. Absolutely delicious.\xa0585 charactersWA_Brian, Jan 05, 2019"]

review:
['4.24/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.25Appearance - Pours a hazy straw with three fingers of bubbly white head.

Smell - cucumber, lime, sea salt, coriander,lemon, bready malts, general fresh salad aromas, and earthy yeast

Taste - very pronounced cucumber and lime upfront. The sea salt, coriander,and bready malts come through next. The spicy earthy yeast finish off the brew.

A truly crushable brew on this mild evening here in Cowtown!\xa0722 charactersleaddog, Jun 30, 2019']

name: Kilauea Black Gose
review: ['3.88/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 4 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 4stumbled into front range sort of randomly to check it out, and for not having ever really heard anyone talk about these guys, i was super impressed with the two beers i had. this is a black gose with limes and fresno chilies, super unique recipe, nicely executed, and delicious. it doesnt look like much from the tap, deep dark brown but not real lively. aroma is great though, i smell the roast right away with a strong coffee similarity, and then the salt, high minerals and enough to make this properly salty. the pepper isnt there at all, which is the aspect i was nervous about, so thats all good. the limes are freshly zested it seems, and quite prominent. the flavor has a little of the pepper, all in the finish, fresh tasting too, super faint heat in the throat on the swallow, but the other elements of the beer are enough to put it out and refresh it almost instantly. the lime is prominent, the salt is earthy and awesome, and the surprising part for me is how well done the sour part is. its a fairly clean lacto sourness, medium on the intensity scale, but puckery, lemony, and fully appropriate. nicely done there! i love what the pepper adds, i feared itd be too much, fresnos are hot, but this is brilliant. i still wish the beer had more carbonation, its almost still and thats really my only critique. loving this flavor complexion, what a cool surprise of a beer! super enjoyable and different, great work here by front range!\xa01,447 charactersStonedTrippin, Aug 31, 2017']

name: Draper
review:
["4/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4L: Poured from a tallboy can to a cylinder glass. Had a yellow-brown color and a mostly clear consistency. There was a quarter inch of foamy / fizzy, somewhat long-lasting head. Not a whole lot of lacing.

S: A very nice aroma of citrus fruit, malt, spices, bourbon, vanilla, and sea salt.

T: Tasted of a small amount of malt (present throughout - not a big factor), a good shot of sea salt, some light bourbon notes (and the accompanying barrel, a hint of vanilla, a little citrus (tangerines), and spices (cinnamon). One of the more interesting gose flavors I've tried. The bourbon isn't terribly pronounced, but it's still a lively taste.

F: A well-carbonated beer with a somewhat slick finish. Light-bodied.

O: A well done, interesting take on the gose. Drinkable.\xa0771 charactersavalon07, Mar 11, 2019"]

name: The Sabatini
review: ['3.71/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.5 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.75they call it a shandy in house, but it is actually a blend of their gose and a ginger ale, pretty thoughtful summery concoction, still not sure why shandy and radler arent listed as a category here on BA. the sourness of the base gose is nicely cut by a natural sugar soda sort of vibe, and the ginger in here is spicy and fresh but not overdone, a little more assertive in the aroma than the flavor. usually this sort of thing is a turnoff for me, not beery enough, but in this case its mighty refreshing, seemingly naturally derived, and with enough of their delicious gose recognizable through it to work for me. it has nice balance, and still has some graininess to it, a bright lactic tartness, and enough salt remaining to help the finish be drier. on a hot or humid day, i could absolutely pound on these, the natural ginger and the low alcohol make it incredibly quenching and easy down, and its a nice blend. at this low abv, its infinitely sessionable, but maybe a touch too sweet for me personally to want to do that...\xa01,030 charactersStonedTrippin, Jun 26, 2018']

Pale golden yellow, thin head dissipates quickly into nothing, nose is fresh sour cucumber, tastes just like it smells, not bad, just sour cucumber. Might be gulpable on a hot day, but they should carbonate it more.\xa0258 charactersOregonGrown7, Dec 16, 2018']

name: Lexipolitan
review:
["4.16/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4 | overall: 4Great minds think alike. And when the two brewing minds of Blue Stallion and Ethereal come together, a fantastic beer is born just in time for Lexington's Craft Beer Week 2018. A pomegranate, lime and hibiscus gose shows no lacking in creativity, complexity nor intrigue.

Coming with the opaque and matte finish appearance of mauve, lavender and peach, a creamy eggshell froth builds while the overwhelming fruit aromas are berry-like, citrusy, cider-like and winey. Simple sweetness, creaminess and soft spice aligns on the tongue like fruit smoothies with hints of pastry, sourdough and saltwater taffy.

Like a gose on steroids, the natural apple and lime character is heightened with added actual lime flavor along with a rich pomegranate, cranberry, raspberry taste. Still tart with crabapple, lemon and sparkling white wine, the taste flirts dangerously close with wine cooler before an herbal and floral late palate of hibiscus, citronella, orange peel and faint grassiness trend tart, tangy and playfully acidic.

Medium bodied but quite full for gose, the lingering fruit sweetness and bready starchiness keeps the ale creamy, textural and weighted. Soothing hints of vanilla and cream soften the tepid sourness while a medium short aftertaste of macerated berries and sangria come with brief echoes.\xa01,310 charactersBEERchitect, May 25, 2018"]

name: Grapefruit Agave Gose
review:
['3.81/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.5 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 4 | overall: 4650ml bottle - part of their Tidal Series, which are apparently just their seasonal releases, this one for Summer.

This beer pours a slightly effervescent, pale golden yellow colour, with three chubby fingers of puffy, finely foamy, and mildly fizzy eggshell white head, which leaves a bit of sparsely-strewn, remote islet lace around the glass as it quickly sinks away.

It smells of grainy and bready cereal malt, saltine crackers, watered-down grapefruit juice (like the kind I give to my kid), simple syrup, and very, very subtle earthy, leafy, and floral green hop bitters. The taste is gritty and grainy pale malt, red grapefruit peel, ethereal saline solution, white sugar, and more understated leafy, herbal, and floral hoppiness.

The carbonation is average in its palate-propping frothiness, the body a decent medium weight, and generally smooth, with a nice airy creaminess arising as soon as things start to warm up a tad around here. It finishes off-dry, the malt and agave nectar exhibiting the most lingering fervour.

Overall - this comes across as a well-made version of the style, deftly balanced, and quite refreshing. Purists may have a certain truck with the additional sweetness, but it works for me, and I am going to enjoy the rest of this, as sunshine comes pouring through my windows.\xa01,314 charactersbiboergosum, Jun 20, 2018']

name: Gondola Gose
review:
['3.8/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 48oz glass at Beer Revolution YEG Oliver Square - made with cranberry and blood orange, apparently. 

This beer appears a slightly hazy, pale salmon colour, with a thin cap of wispy and bubbly off-white head, which leaves a few instances of rearing humpback whale pattern lace around the glass as things slowly progress. 

It smells of gritty and grainy cereal malt, thin cranberry juice, muddled domestic citrus rind, saltine crackers, and very faint earthy, musty, and dead floral hop bitters. The taste is grainy and crackery pale malt, some mixed dark fruitiness, saltwater, a hint of estery yeast, and more well-understated earthy, musty, and herbal hoppiness. 

The carbonation is adequate in its palate-assuring frothiness, the body a so-so medium weight, and generally smooth, with nothing really getting in the way of a refreshing time at this particular juncture. It finishes trending dry, the malt faltering in the face of the tart lingering frooty essences. 

Overall - this comes across as a pleasantly rendered version of the style, with the guest ingredients doing well to add and not detract from the whole experience. Crisp, and rather easy to put back on a sunny and unseasonably warm January afternoon.\xa01,220 charactersbiboergosum, Jan 20, 2019']

review: ['4.1/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4.532 ounce crowler into tulip glass, filled on 8/2/2019. Pours Lightly hazy golden/amber, light orange/pine color with a 1 finger fairly dense and rocky light pink head with great retention, that reduces to a thin cap that lingers. Nice spotty soapy lacing clings on the glass, with a light amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of big sour/tart/tangy cranberry, strawberry, hibiscus, lemon, lime, orange, peach, pear, melon, red/green apple, white grape/wine, sea salt, hay, straw, floral, grass, wheat, and white bread dough; with lighter notes of coriander, peppercorn, lacto funk, and yeast earthiness. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of hibiscus, fruity/acidic yeast, sea salt, pale/wheat malts, and light coriander notes; with big strength. Taste of big sour/tart/tangy cranberry, strawberry, hibiscus, lemon, lime, orange, peach, pear, melon, red/green apple, white grape/wine, sea salt, hay, straw, floral, grass, wheat, and white bread dough; with lighter notes of coriander, peppercorn, lacto funk, and yeast earthiness. Light-moderate lactic tartness, hibiscus tang, and light coriander spiciness on the finish. Lingering notes of tart/tangy cranberry, strawberry, hibiscus, lemon, lime, orange, peach, pear, melon, red/green apple, white grape/wine, sea salt, hay, straw, floral, grass, wheat, white bread dough, light pepper/lacto funk, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Awesome complexity, robustness, and balance of hibiscus, fruity/acidic yeast, sea salt, pale/wheat malts, and light coriander flavors; with an awesome malt/tart/sourness and tangy hibiscus balance; with no puckering/astringent flavors after the finish. Fairly crisp finishing. Light-moderate increasing dryness from lingering tart/sourness and tangy hibiscus. Medium carbonation and light-medium body; with a very smooth, moderately creamy/grainy/acidic/tangy, and fairly saline balanced mouthfeel that is great. Zero warming alcohol as expected of 4.7%. Overall this is an awesome flavored gose. All around awesome complexity, robustness, and balance of hibiscus, fruity/acidic yeast, sea salt, pale/wheat malts, and light coriander flavors; very smooth and fairly crisp/refreshing to drink with the mellowly acidic/tangy/drying finish; not overly lactic/salty. Awesome balanced juicy/jammy hibiscus and Lacto complexity; with a great pale/wheat malt backbone against acidity. Mild residual sweetness with crisp acidic/tangy dryness. A really enjoyable offering, and impressive spot on style example as expected. Not overwhelming on any aspect.\xa02,565 characterssuperspak, Aug 04, 2019']

name: Guava Gose
review: ['3.66/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.5 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.5not that this is unsuccessful, its fine, but it was hands down my least favorite of the beers i had at the denver brewery. its hazy as can be, heavy because of it despite the low alcohol content. i like the guava by itself, thats cool, seems like its always with so many other fruits that its own identity is lost in beers, but here its fleshy and juicy and pulpy and sweet, tropical, and summery. the problem is that the base beer is heavy and unrefined, wheaty and full of starch and protein, not light and refreshing like the style wants to be. the sourness is pretty clean, decent job there, but its pretty tart, and with all the body is a slow drinker as a result, which is not what i look for in a gose. the salt is mellow but adds some nice mineral character. more sweetness from the guava at the end than it needs too. i think this beer has a lot of potential, but right now it seems to me more like a work in progress, which was not the case with all the hoppy stuff that seems to dialed in already. not bad at all, im making it sound way worse than it is, but its not quite there yet...\xa01,096 charactersStonedTrippin, Nov 04, 2018']

Nice head, amber orange color. This is a delicious sour, one with the proper balance between tartness and lots of orange flavor. Much superior to the other sour that I sampled at Big Elm (Sol Crusher).\xa0309 charactersrorjets, Jun 06, 2018']

name: Zungen Brecher
review: ['4/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4 | smell: 4 | taste: 4 | feel: 4 | overall: 4actually a lichtenhainer, another style specific enough to probably deserve its own category here on BA. essentially a smoked gose, but i dont believe they traditionally incorporate wheat, and maybe not even salt, but it has similar german origins and probably drinks closer to a gose than anything else. this one is delicate on all counts, the smoke is very earthy and mild, the acidity is quite low, no more than lightly piquant, and the body and super light, this is a flavorful and interesting and well refined session beer, i wish more american brewers would make one. i like the light lemony lactic tang with the campfire smoke element, its rustic and delicious, earthy and refreshing somehow for being smokey. the dry finish almost suggests a lager yeast, and the high carbonation makes this incredibly drinkable, nice in warm weather, and very much alive. the smoke and the tart are cool together, and the malt base is simple, european, and almost has a table saison sort of vibe, rustic in that way. overall really well made beer, a style i wish got more attention, and something good enough to go back here for!\xa01,121 charactersStonedTrippin, Jun 20, 2018']

Flavors are the same, big tart body, with nice hints of apricot. Good body and feel. Overall, big sour, with nice fruit flavors.\xa0212 charactersvette2006c5r, Aug 12, 2019']

name: Keypunch - Key Lime Pie - Red Wine Barrel-Aged
review: ['3/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3 | smell: 3 | taste: 3 | feel: 3 | overall: 3kylehay2004, Sep 17, 2017']

name: Gozay
review: ['4.22/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.75 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4.25 | overall: 4.25a really cool beer here, imperial gose type barrel aged with grenache grapes in it. i am really starting to like these guys a lot, once i got over the absurd price points and started getting into their beers that is. this pours an almost still looking washed out pinkish orange color, some viscosity and a nice soft color, but visually unremarkable really. the grape influence is enormous, as this has a very vinous nose to it, not sure what kind of barrels this was aged in, but i would guess red wine, it has that berry and tart grape skin character, and whats more, is that it has an actual wine fermentation profile, some sharpness, tannins, astringency, and oak to it, as much wine in the nose to me as it is beer, but i can appreciate the lactic tartness and the salt for sure, as well as a dry but fuller wheat base. the flavor is equally wine forward, the grapes add a ton of flavor and texture without making it sweet, impressive! i love the almost gritty thing thats happening here, and there is a cool symbiotic back and forth between the fruit and the salt. not all lacto either it doesnt seem, some mature bretty funk to this, albeit behind the acidic elements, its a nice touch. a very complete beer that doesnt drink nearly as strong as it is and uses grapes in a really cool way. loved it!\xa01,305 charactersStonedTrippin, Oct 18, 2018']

name: Watermelon Wingman
review: ['3.79/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.75 | smell: 4 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.75i like how natural the watermelon is in this. thats really its best feature, and for how many watermelon beers there seem to be out there these days, most of them taste artificial or candy-like, but not this one, it has that juicy fleshy distinctive real watermelon freshness, especially in the aroma. the gose itself is pretty solid, not as clean as i like it, still a little sweet from the fruit, but thats really the only critique here, not as refreshing as it could be because of that, but the tartness is there without it being too acidic, i think the fruit helps with that too, and the salt is mild but enhances the watermelon nicely. the proportions are good here, especially if you like a lot of fruit in your gose, which i generally dont, but they got that part of this right. the lacto side of things could be a little more tidy, just a little sweatiness to it, but overall this is quite drinkable and good. very summery, something i want to drink on the fourth of july. also my first beer from devil wind, who appears to be pretty new. this is ambitious and rather well done for an operation still getting started. nice use of the watermelon here, better than most.\xa01,176 charactersStonedTrippin, Sep 27, 2018']

review: ['3.92/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 4 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 4Pours a medium gold coloration with a small, fizzy head. However, the bergamotte really comes through on the tongue, with a very rich bergamotte character that is reminiscent of earl grey tea. Mildly sour with citrus, multivitamin tablet and light herbal notes as well. Finishes dry and very mildly acidic, with a slight saltiness. Smooth mouthfeel with a light/medium body and medium/lively carbonation.\n\nThe strong bergamotte character certainly makes this unique and in a good way, although it may not be for everyone. Sourness is very mild for a Gose, quite a crisp and refreshing beer.\xa0691 charactersSnowcrash000, Jun 20, 2018']

name: Mad Gaz's Hot Toddy
review:
["3.64/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.75 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.75 | overall: 3.5A 330ml bottle with a BB of Dec 2016, so it's rather out of date. Acquired ages ago from Trembling Madness in York. The name and label are fairly cryptic and don't give much away - it's not clear why this is called Hot Toddy. Does it contain lemon, honey or spices? We shall see....

A: Poured into a Duvel tulip. Bottle conditioned. A deep, hazy marmalade-amber hue with fine suspended sediment and good carbonation. Yields a large head of creamy white foam that lasts for a minute or two before reducing to a patchy surface layer.

S: Aroma of tart, earthy yeast with hints of mild caramel malt, a touch of smokiness, faint lemon/citrus, vague stewed leaves and a delicate mustiness in the background. Acidic but otherwise very hard to place.

T: Tastes of sour lactic acid with notes of subtle caramel malt, earthy yeast, mild lemon, a twinge of honey, faint stewed leaves and a lingering mustiness. Pretty sharp and bone dry but no bitterness to speak of.

M: Mouthfeel is smooth, tingly and dry, with spritzy carbonation and good body. Somewhat astringent - strips the palate. Aftertaste of sourness, subtle lemon, a hint of malt and earthiness.

O: Drinkable but weird. This is classed as a Gose, which I guess is correct but there's nothing on the label to indicate this. Looks alright, while the aroma and flavour are dominated by lactic acid sourness, lemon, faint malt and earthiness. Decent body. Generally OK; I'm just a tad confused about what the brewer was aiming for. But perhaps that's how it is when the brewery is called Mad Hatter. No need to hunt it down unless you really like sour brews.\xa01,610 charactersjazzyjeff13, Oct 11, 2017"]

review:
["3.6/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 3.5 | smell: 3.5 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.5A: The beer is very hazy yellow in color and almost resembles peach fuzz when viewed from afar. review: ['4.61/5\xa0\xa0rDev 0%look: 4.5 | smell: 4.75 | taste: 4.5 | feel: 4.5 | overall: 4.75Orange hazy color with a thin white head. Smell bursts of citrus and peach....hard to distinguish fruit and hop as they meld so well. Taste is a lesson in nuance and balance, as the light salty tartness & slight hop bite adds another layer to what follows from the nose, bright & juicy citrus and peach flavors with dry finish. Like eating a peach at the beach after getting out of the ocean. \n\nA beautiful counterpoint to all the in-your-face fruit smoothies.....this beer is more about the subtle interplay of hop and fruit.\xa0529 charactersBeerness, May 21, 2018']
